story:
Our Mission Statement: 

Belchertown Justice Collaborative is a youth-led group that was formed in response to the murder of George Floyd to start anti-racist action and conversations in our own community. We recognize that racism is systemically built into institutions such as schools, the healthcare system, law enforcement, and government. We are dedicated to being a part of the action and conversation that examines, dismantles, and rebuilds these systems in Belchertown. We do this through education, policy change, research and data collection, forming connections with other local organizations and activists, and proposing new frameworks. We will change town culture to be more accessible, inclusive, and equitable for Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC). In our work, we strive to recognize, acknowledge, and convey intersecting identities and oppressions. Community is the backbone and starting place of all important change, and we are committed to doing this work with people and in places that make up home for us. Today, we are asking for your help funding our next projects so that we can get work supporting our community. 

 

What We Need & What You Get:

Right now we need to raise $1,000 in order to support our upcoming community projects!  This means we need 100 people to donate $10, 200 people to donate $5, or just 60 people to purchase Belchertown Justice Collaborative t-shirts! 

We are currently working on: 

  • Organizing anti-racist family movie nights
  • Creating accessible educational resources and activities 
  • Organizing virtual action hours to promote local and global justice 
  • Securing grants to promote community building through public arts

We are committed to making all of our projects, resources, and events free. Accessibility is vital to our anti-racist work, and we never want a pay wall to be the reason people do not have access to what we are doing. But, this means that we really on the generosity and engagement of our co-conspirators, allies, and community members to make our work possible. Today we are asking people to buy $15 or $20 t-shirts, or $2 stickers, to help support the accessibility and success of our next projects.

We are excited to be partnering with local Black owned business Paper City Clothing Company on the production of these shirts! They produced who produced amazing t-shirts for us at our June 25th Vigil, and we are thrilled to be able to support them again. 

We will be mailing all of our shirts through the USPS, and we will be covering the stamp costs of all stickers as a way to support the vital services the US Postal Service provides. 

So, to sum it up---When you donate today you are: 

  • Purchasing an awesome t-shirt made by a local Black owned business
  • Committing money to an anti-racist organization led by at least 50% BIPOC
  • Helping to promote community building through anti-racist programing in Belchertown MA
  • Supporting local youth activists and their work
  • Supporting the US post office

Other Ways You Can Help: 

We completely understand that not everyone can give right now! If you are not able to donate, no worries! Spreading the word about this fundraiser and our group is valuable support. Share this fundraiser with your friends! Or, like us on Facebook, follow us on Instagram, or join or mailing list to stay up-do-date on all of the work we're planning! 

 

With Solidarity and Gratitude, 

The Belchertown Justice Collaborative

story:
Kevin McGandy is a beloved member of our neighborhood, always quick to help a friend, neighbor, or even stranger.  He was recently diagnosed with Stage 4 colon cancer, which he has been fighting mightily … but he has bills to pay!


The community is coming together to put on a pasta dinner fundraiser for  him, like NO other!  On December 3rd, we are putting together a night to remember, with great food, great friends, and a great community. It's going to be a great event ... but we realize that geography can be an issue for some.  So, we had a genius idea:


We are making honorary "tickets" available here on Indiegogo, for our friends that live far away, or who are otherwise unable to attend our dinner in person.  You aren't simply donating cash, however - your "ticket" buys one (or more!) fresh, hot meals to be delivered to people in need, on your behalf!  We will be donating meals to 3 local shelters, benefiting the homeless, seniors, and women who have graduated from a substance abuse program.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate?  Please spread the word of this fundraiser!  How many times do you get the opportunity to help a great guy out with his medical and living bills in a hard time AND donate food to the needy... at the same time?

story:
Launch to the Frontlines

We are a nonprofit that sends undercover investigators to look for sex slaves, primarily in India and SE Asia. We have a network of police contacts, and always work with local governments. To date, we've helped rescue 252 victims from brothels. 

Right now, we have a volunteer who is heading to the field and needs your help. She is donating an entire year (at least) of her time to help current field teams (consisting of former military, private security, police) with crucial support on the ground in SE Asia. She has undergone training and an interview process, and the only thing between her and the field is the funding to get there. She will be assisting in basic surveillance, organizing evidence from lead investigators, managing field reports, and coordinating investigations. She may not actually kick down the door, but she'll be providing key support for those that do. 

Her name is  . . . well, for security purposes, we can't tell you her name. We'll let Lara (okay, Croft) be her alias, instead.  And we as a community need to launch her to the frontlines. 

What We Need & What You Get

Because we are a nonprofit that seeks to maximize donated funds for raids/rescues/investigative expenses, we are creative with how we fund other expenses necessary for operations-- expenses like the following which fall under this project for Lara:

  • Roundtrip Airline Ticket from USA to SE ASIA: $1700
  • Language School, Upon Arrival: $400 
  • Visas/Paperwork/Licenses: $300
  • Travel/Lodging Expenses, Month-Long Orientation in Colorado (April): $1,000
  • Travel/Lodging Expenses, Month-Long Orientation/Training in SE Asia: $1,600

Of course, Lara's work for the upcoming year will require much more funding than the above, but this money will cover getting her set up for a successful year of surveillance and support on the frontlines of the fight against sex trafficking. 

You can find out more about our organization by visiting our website here: www.theExodusRoad.com. We are a 501c3 in good standing with both the state and federal government. 

The Impact

To date, we have utilized undercover investigators around the world to fuel the rescues of 252 victims of sex trafficking, all with our local police partners in SE Asia and India. With more slaves today than at any other time in human history, we are strategically equipping an army of trained, skilled investigators to assist police conduct raids, rescues and arrests. 

The team Lara will be assisting is in dire need of help-- both in basic surveillance and in administrative support. They are currently working over 50 active cases of trafficking, underage prostitution, and pedophilia, and Lara will play a support role in organizing evidence, documenting cases, administrative tasks-- essentially, empowering our trained operatives to do what they do, more efficiently. 

In the course of the upcoming year, it is estimated that she will assist administratively with at least 40 cases of human trafficking which will likely result in the rescue of 15-30 individuals. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate financially to launch Lara to the field, help us by spreading the word! SHARE online via the indiegogo's share tools. 

You can also connect with The Exodus Road on Facebook (@The Exodus Road)  to get current updates by liking our page or following us on Twitter (@theexodusroad). 

If you'd like text updates to your phone of real-time raids and operations, text "ER" to #51555. 

FrontLine Footage

Check out this video of the type of work that Lara will be right in the middle of supporting:

story:
The RTW Veteran Center is 501(C)(3) Not-for-Profit privately funded veteran’s center located at 5536 S King Dr, Chicago, IL 60637. The two owners, Arnetha Gholston and Daniel Habeel fund the center with all of their own personal income, equating to over 90% of the monthly expense.

Open 7 days a week 360 days a year, our mission is to Remake The World (RTW) beginning with the community that we are located in and then spreading into other neighborhoods. We serve veterans and their families, the general public, and the youth by offering twelve different programs that operate out of the center.

We're different from any other veteran center in the country that we know of in existence. Opening in February of 2011 with a commitment that any veteran or anyone else who came to our doors hungry “Would Not Leave Hungry” we became a forward operating base (FOB) in the war against poverty, drugs, gangs, crime, violence, and terrorism in the community. The center serves over 4,000 free meals per month to Chicago's more than 8,000 homeless veterans and others.

We're Hurting. During the coldest time of the year, our furnaces failed and the subzero winter quickly froze our pipes. Pipes ruptured throughout the building causing water damage and making the repair job much more difficult. While volunteers were able to get our furnace back up, the irreversible damage has put the center on a path towards closure.

What We Need

We have never needed support as much as we need it now. We need just over $10,000 to fix the damage to our pipes and structure that occurred so we can get back up and running at 100%. The workers are ready but we have to purchase supplies and equipment for getting crucial work done. Once done, the work has to pass inspection.

What You'll Get

100% of the current donations we get go towards the center so we don't have a lot to offer. We've adjusted our fundraising to offer some perks that will be ordered once we raise enough money. For those offering $25 or more you'll get a center photo from the Veteran Center Staff. For $100 or more, you'll get a T-Shirt in addition to the photo. For supporters offering $1,000 or more in a donation gets a sweatshirt in addition to the t-shirt and photo.

The RTW Veteran Center is supported by multiple organizations and many hundreds of individuals and it's growing everyday.

  

  

   

If you can't donate to our Campaign then Please spread the word. We are trying to make a difference in the community and need various forms of support. Here's what you can do to assist our efforts:

Follow Us and Share Our Stories

Volunteer

Most Importantly...

...please spread the word.

story:
A Safe House for Mexico's Journalists?

Mexico is infamous for being one of the most dangerous countries in the world to be a journalist.

Authorities fail to protect journalists and at-risk and threatened reporters have nowhere to flee in safety.

That means Mexico's threatened journalists have to rely on the kindness of friends, family, colleagues or non-governmental organizations. It's not an ideal situation -- for the threatened journalists or the people close to them.

These informal support networks are often overwhelmed by the special dilemmas presented by a persecuted journalist. At-risk reporters often return to the place where they confront danger, or, they flee to places within Mexico that are not real places of refuge.

Tragic examples of a Failure to Find Safe Refuge:

- Photojournalist Rubén Espinosa fled Xalapa, Veracruz for Mexico City in 2015 where he could not find a permanent place to stay. On 1 August 2015 gunmen killed Espinosa and four women in the apartment of one of his friends in Mexico City.

- Acapulco reporter Martín Méndez Pineda fled the State of Guerrero after being threatened by police. He reported moving around Mexico from place to place, always feeling threatened. Early in 2017 he crossed the U.S.-Mexico border in El Paso and applied for asylum in the United States. Immigration authorities in the U.S. denied him asylum and he returned to Mexico where he fears for his safety.

- Javier Valdez, author of nine books, veteran journalist, and one of the founding editors of newspaper RíoDoce, confronted worsening threats in Culiacán, Sinaloa throughout 2017. Although he tried to leave Culiacán, a colleague reported he had no funds to go into exile and so returned to Sinaloa. He was murdered on May 15 in broad daylight.

Finding a Solution: Asking Journalists What They Want

One conclusion to be drawn from these examples -- and there are other examples, too -- is that an independent safe house might provide refuge for at risk journalists. If modeled on other safe houses for journalists around the world -- for example in Paris and Cádiz, Spain -- a refuge in Mexico would give a threatened reporter time away from terror, allowing them to receive professional attention (psychological, legal, and work-related), so that they can make a decision about what to do next. (The only known safe house in Mexico is not independent. Opened late last July, it is funded by the government of Mexico City.)

But it's impossible to know, as yet, if a house of refuge for Mexican journalists would work in their favor. Why? Nobody has ever asked them.

Over the past six years, as I've documented threats against reporters in Mexico, I've met many at-risk journalists in Veracruz, Chihuahua, Sinaloa, and Mexico City who all intimate the need for a house of refuge, independent of government influence. It's time to listen to these journalists about the support network they need.

The situation is urgent. As the crisis deepens, help me find out what reporters go through as they do their necessary work, and what their experiences suggest will help keep them safe. Do they want a place of refuge? And if so, what services do they know they will require?

The Campaign's Goals and Can I Achieve Them?

Since late 2011, I have provided human rights accompaniment to journalists in several Mexican states. For the past five years, I've been doing this work pro-bono. Getting to know and sharing experiences with Mexican journalists has enabled me to advocate for them through writing, publishing, and presentations, spreading the word about ongoing challenges to freedom of expression in Mexico.

This campaign to document what Mexican journalists want to keep them safe will result in:

1. a series of stories about how they practice journalism;

2. a longer report based in human rights norms; and,

3. presentation of the report to foundations and stakeholders interested in practical steps to defend freedom of expression in Mexico.

Previous Examples of My Work

You can see examples of my reporting about Mexican journalists for the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) as a Guest Blogger, here; and, as a freelance reporter for the website of the North American Congress on Latin America NACLA, here and here; the pro-bono Mexican Journalism Translation Project (which I edit), and the Freedom of Expression Project at the Trans-Border Institute at the University of San Diego. I also have translated from Spanish to English (notably for El País in English), and I've been a freelance journalist since 2002, with examples of publications at CounterPunch (2004 - 2016) and the Texas Observer (2002 - 2006).

I am technically qualified to produce a human rights report on this subject. In 2013, I was awarded a Master of Laws (LLM) degree in International Human Rights Law from the University of Essex, UK. I wrote a state-of-the-art thesis on the protection gaps for journalists in international human rights law. I focused on Mexican journalists at the Inter-American System of Human Rights. Freedom House reprinted part of the thesis in English and translated it into Spanish, for a book published in collaboration with the Comisión Nacional de Derechos Humanos.

I have a PhD in Latin American History from the University of Texas at Austin (2004). From 2015 to 2017, I have served as Lecturer in History at El Paso Community College, a position that has enabled me to publish articles on the history of the border and immigration enforcement with NACLA.

My Background as a Human Rights Investigator

After I obtained my doctorate in Latin American history and worked as a university professor for a few years, I moved to Mexico City to work for a drug policy non-profit. After a year of that work, an opportunity arose to work as a Human Rights Policy Officer at a European Union member delegation embassy in Mexico City.

That official experience provided me with a network of journalists and human rights activists in Mexico, and especially in Veracruz. It also exposed me to the inner workings of Mexico's state and federal governments, gave me key contacts in Mexico's federal human rights protection agencies, and has helped me understand the importance to democracy and civil society of local journalists who wage a fundamental fight against corruption, impunity and violence.

Since 2011 I have visited Veracruz more than a dozen times. I travel to Veracruz to interact with journalists, hear what challenges they face, and try to ascertain how things have improved or worsened for them. I have based myself in Mexico City when I do this work, also as a way to stay connected to journalists in the capital and in other states.

I am committed to working on the ground with journalists in Mexico. Documenting violations of freedom of expression through field work helps to combat impunity for reporters' murders and disappearances because it establishes a record that can be used for future action. Accompanying living journalists is also an attempt to protect their freedom of expression and earn their trust.

Hard Tacks: Human Rights Field Work Costs

But human rights accompaniment and documentation comes at a price. It's not hefty, but it's not something my academic position at a community college in Texas can support. It's that simple. To do this work of protecting journalists, I need your help.

I can only document these journalists' experiences with your financial support. Eventually, I will seek foundation support for the safe house, but right now this work of investigating informal methods of protection is urgent, necessary, and can be done for very little cost -- if you are willing to share just part of the burden. Together we can start to find practical, workable approaches to protecting Mexican journalists.

Funding for Seven Weeks in the Field: The Breakdown 

Return airfare from El Paso/Juárez to Mexico City ($500)
Bus travel throughout cities in Veracruz ($500)
Mexico City Preparation Two Weeks ($400)
Veracruz, 4 Weeks In the Field ($650)
Mexico City Draft Writing Week ($250)
Cell Phone & Newspapers ($200)

Total Request: $2,500

Impact: Stories, the Human Rights Report, Pitching Foundations

Stories

Taking stock through human rights documentation and journalism about what motivates journalists to become reporters willing to risk their lives in the context of the drug war will help English-language readers better understand the enormity of commitment to freedom of expression in Mexico. We also need a better understanding of the informal ways in which journalists seek to protect themselves, what actions have worked for them and not worked for them.
 
The Report
This will be a larger, more analytical presentation of what journalists report will keep them safe, will help shape the practical attempt to keep journalists alive, out of harm's way, and with their human rights intact.
 
The Pitch to Foundations and Stakeholders
Once I have documented the ways journalists keep themselves safe and what they say they need,  I will use the stories and the report to seek funding for establishing a safe house. The safe house must address the specific needs identified by Mexico's journalists but it must also be independent, hence the need to pitch foundations interested in protecting freedom of expression.
 

Risks & Challenges

For reasons of personal security and the safety of my sources and collaborators, the specific itinerary of places to visit and people to interview cannot be disclosed. That will come out in the stories and the report, with consent from key sources, or publishing with pseudonyms.

Many people think that what I do is risky. In actual fact, the risk comes to the people who are my contacts and sources. Therefore, one of the key strategies is always to work in a way that respects what the journalists want as they manage the risks confronting them, preserving their anonymity if they want it preserved, or helping them establish contacts inside and outside of Mexico that can keep them safe.

Over the past six years, as I've documented threats against reporters in Mexico, I've met many at-risk journalists in Veracruz, Chihuahua, Sinaloa, and Mexico City who all intimate the need for a house of refuge, independent of government influence. It's time to listen to these journalists about the support network they need.
The situation is urgent. As the crisis deepens, help me find out what reporters go through as they do their necessary work, and what their experiences suggest will help keep them safe. Do they want a place of refuge? And if so, what services do they know they will require?
The Campaign's Goals and Can I Achieve Them?
Since late 2011, I have provided human rights accompaniment to journalists in several Mexican states. For the past five years, I've been doing this work pro-bono. Getting to know and sharing experiences with Mexican journalists has enabled me to advocate for them through writing, publishing, and presentations, spreading the word about ongoing challenges to freedom of expression in Mexico.
This campaign to document what Mexican journalists want to keep them safe will result in:
1. a series of stories about how they practice journalism;
2. a longer report based in human rights norms; and,
3. presentation of the report to foundations and stakeholders interested in practical steps to defend freedom of expression in Mexico.
Previous Examples of My Work
You can see examples of my reporting about Mexican journalists for the Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) as a Guest Blogger, here; and, as a freelance reporter for the website of the North American Congress on Latin America NACLA, here and here; the pro-bono Mexican Journalism Translation Project (which I edit), and the Freedom of Expression Project at the Trans-Border Institute at the University of San Diego. I also have translated from Spanish to English (notably for El País in English), and I've been a freelance journalist since 2002, with examples of publications at CounterPunch (2004 - 2016) and the Texas Observer (2002 - 2006).
I am technically qualified to produce a human rights report on this subject. In 2013, I was awarded a Master of Laws (LLM) degree in International Human Rights Law from the University of Essex, UK. I wrote a state-of-the-art thesis on the protection gaps for journalists in international human rights law. I focused on Mexican journalists at the Inter-American System of Human Rights. Freedom House reprinted part of the thesis in English and translated it into Spanish, for a book published in collaboration with the Comisión Nacional de Derechos Humanos.
I have a PhD in Latin American History from the University of Texas at Austin (2004). From 2015 to 2017, I have served as Lecturer in History at El Paso Community College, a position that has enabled me to publish articles on the history of the border and immigration enforcement with NACLA.
My Background as a Human Rights Investigator
After I obtained my doctorate in Latin American history and worked as a university professor for a few years, I moved to Mexico City to work for a drug policy non-profit. After a year of that work, an opportunity arose to work as a Human Rights Policy Officer at a European Union member delegation embassy in Mexico City.
That official experience provided me with a network of journalists and human rights activists in Mexico, and especially in Veracruz. It also exposed me to the inner workings of Mexico's state and federal governments, gave me key contacts in Mexico's federal human rights protection agencies, and has helped me understand the importance to democracy and civil society of local journalists who wage a fundamental fight against corruption, impunity and violence.
Since 2011 I have visited Veracruz more than a dozen times. I travel to Veracruz to interact with journalists, hear what challenges they face, and try to ascertain how things have improved or worsened for them. I have based myself in Mexico City when I do this work, also as a way to stay connected to journalists in the capital and in other states.
I am committed to working on the ground with journalists in Mexico. Documenting violations of freedom of expression through field work helps to combat impunity for reporters' murders and disappearances because it establishes a record that can be used for future action. Accompanying living journalists is also an attempt to protect their freedom of expression and earn their trust.
Hard Tacks: Human Rights Field Work Costs
But human rights accompaniment and documentation comes at a price. It's not hefty, but it's not something my academic position at a community college in Texas can support. It's that simple. To do this work of protecting journalists, I need your help.
I can only document these journalists' experiences with your financial support. Eventually, I will seek foundation support for the safe house, but right now this work of investigating informal methods of protection is urgent, necessary, and can be done for very little cost -- if you are willing to share just part of the burden. Together we can start to find practical, workable approaches to protecting Mexican journalists.

Funding for Seven Weeks in the Field: The Breakdown 
Return airfare from El Paso/Juárez to Mexico City ($500)Bus travel throughout cities in Veracruz ($500)Mexico City Preparation Two Weeks ($400)Veracruz, 4 Weeks In the Field ($650)Mexico City Draft Writing Week ($250)Cell Phone & Newspapers ($200)
Total Request: $2,500
Impact: Stories, the Human Rights Report, Pitching Foundations
Stories
Taking stock through human rights documentation and journalism about what motivates journalists to become reporters willing to risk their lives in the context of the drug war will help English-language readers better understand the enormity of commitment to freedom of expression in Mexico. We also need a better understanding of the informal ways in which journalists seek to protect themselves, what actions have worked for them and not worked for them. The ReportThis will be a larger, more analytical presentation of what journalists report will keep them safe, will help shape the practical attempt to keep journalists alive, out of harm's way, and with their human rights intact. The Pitch to Foundations and StakeholdersOnce I have documented the ways journalists keep themselves safe and what they say they need,  I will use the stories and the report to seek funding for establishing a safe house. The safe house must address the specific needs identified by Mexico's journalists but it must also be independent, hence the need to pitch foundations interested in protecting freedom of expression.
 
Risks & Challenges
For reasons of personal security and the safety of my sources and collaborators, the specific itinerary of places to visit and people to interview cannot be disclosed. That will come out in the stories and the report, with consent from key sources, or publishing with pseudonyms.
Many people think that what I do is risky. In actual fact, the risk comes to the people who are my contacts and sources. Therefore, one of the key strategies is always to work in a way that respects what the journalists want as they manage the risks confronting them, preserving their anonymity if they want it preserved, or helping them establish contacts inside and outside of Mexico that can keep them safe.

story:
Things have gone terribly wrong

The Anti-Homosexuality Act of 2014 sparked unprecedented levels of intolerance, aggression, and persecution for LGBT folks across Uganda. While the homophobic and transphobic legislation has since been repealed, another anti-gay bill is in the works, and many have lost their jobs, been kicked out of their homes, or forced into hiding. As politicians, religious leaders, and media outlets continue to circulate LGBT intolerance for selfish gains, the lives of our Ugandan LGBT brothers and sisters have become increasingly precarious. 

We need to do something

What’s the one tool that can effectively stop intolerance, calm public fears, and help build a more inclusive society? 

Some would say it’s education. If society at-large can understand that being LGBT does not make a person anything less than human, they can open their hearts to loving and respecting diversity.

That’s close, but not exactly right.

Better able to build empathy rather than just educate. Nothing sways public opinion faster than storytelling. 

A little magazine went a long way

Kasha Jacqueline, one of the founders of the Ugandan LGBT movement, understood how powerful individual stories can be. She knew that a misguided perception of diversity as a “sickness”, “western import” or “perversion” could not withstand the test of closeness. Those who open their eyes to see what their neighbors, friends, and family members have experienced cannot justify discrimination (no matter what their religious leaders or politicians may say).

Kasha collected dozens of stories and printed the first edition of "Bombastic Magazine" in record time. She cut costs every way she could, editing the text herself and brokering deals with printers who took the risk of being prosecuted. Her team distributed the free magazine across Uganda, leaving it on doorsteps, car windshields, and other locations where its message would be heard. The results were beyond their wildest expectations. 

A powerful impact

Phone calls came in from across the country. Some had never known other people nearby were going through the same struggles.  Others opened their eyes to the reality that their own family members could be transgender. Some simply thanked her for helping them expand their awareness.

They printed about 20,000 copies and ran out faster than expected. Even police officers requested copies, as well as the Minister of Health and other high-ranking politicians. The magazine was prominently discussed in the Ugandan media.

Kasha saw something she could only sense before. Behind the bigotry, intolerance, and persecution – her movement had more allies than she knew.

Your help is key

More stories are pouring in, and more people are clamoring for a second edition. Kasha wants to print 30,000 copies and distribute them nationally. She wants to invest in a professional editor, and more formal operations for distribution.

Printing costs $10 per issue, a higher price than usual (charged by the printer who is taking legal risks to be involved in the project). This is her only choice, as printing outside of the country would lead to immediate confiscation upon crossing the border. She needs $5,000 to complete the funding and get started.

We are counting on your support to print and finance the second edition of Bombastic Magazine. 

As a donation to Kasha’s fiscal sponsor, The International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission, your contribution is 100% tax deductible. All proceeds will be used to fund the magazine.

Thank you for your generosity.

About OutRight Action International

OutRight Action International (formerly the International Gay and Lesbian Human Rights Commission) fights to protect and advance LGBTI peoples’ dignity and human rights as part of the global human rights movement. We empower people on the frontlines, hold leaders accountable and measure our impact through positive change in people’s lives.

Bringing decades of experience, our staff works alongside LGBTIQ individuals to help identify community-focused solutions and guide policymakers toward lasting change. 

For more information on Bombastic Magazine, visit www.kuchutimes.com

For more information on OutRight, visit www.OutRightInternational.org

story:
What's Going On...

We're Nilufa and Xyannie, 2 juniors from NYC iSchool and we're trying to go to the first ever annual one week Soapboxinc Feminist Day Camp. After taking Global Feminism this year, our really awesome teacher, Ms. Jenkins, who taught the course, encouraged us both to enroll in it. It is the perfect opportunity for us both to continue that feminist fire that kindled within us when we first took the course. We are both really excited about it and determined to go, but the only thing holding us back was the price.

In Case You Didn't Know..

Feminism is the social justice movement to gain equality between men and women. Unlike common misconceptions, it isn't about misandry or refusing to make your boyfriend a sandwich. It's about equal pay and opportunity. It's about wearing whatever I'd like and behaving as I'd like without being called any slurs. It's about respect.

Feminist Camp...

Is a camp where feminists can gather and, in our case, inspire the next generation of feminists. Over the course of one week, high schoolers from around the country, maybe even the world, will work together in workshops, discussions and tackle an issue regarding the theme of that day. That way we can touch upon all issues within feminism.

What We Need...

The entire original price for the camp is $1000 a person. But we already live in New York, so Ms. J was able to get us a really awesome low rate of $250 per person. That means we'd need $500 for us both to go.

$500 will get us both

  • a metro card for the entire week
  • lunch and dinner for the week
  • and a really awesome opportunity to hone our leadership skills and meet inspiring activists!

If we don't reach the goal, whatever money we do raise will be split between us to pay for our enrollment. 

If we happen to pass the goal, the extra money will probably pay for any extra stuff not included in the price to attend the camp.

The Impact...

Global Feminism was one class that left an impact greater than all the other classes we've taken in school. We were introduced to issues that we were astounded to believe were actual issues like honor killings and sex trafficking. This chance to go to the camp would be such a stellar opportunity to continue what we learned, to keep that flame alive. For the first time ever, we've been introduced to something we care about and are thrilled about and actually want to pursue. 

We'd be meeting a bunch of women who have experience in activism. We'd be surrounded by other kids our age who share our interest. We will get to give to our school what we have learned and maybe inspire the next generation of NYC iSchool students to attend next year. We would both come back from this camp stronger and more firm in our beliefs. We'll be courageous enough to destroy the patriarchy!

It will be an experience we will both treasure.

Other Ways You Can Help

TELL YOUR FRIENDS! TELL YOUR FAMILY! SPREAD THIS CAMPAIGN LIKE NUTELLA! TELL PEOPLE ABOUT FEMINISM! BE AN ACTIVE FEMINIST! WEAR WHAT YOU WANT AND DON'T SHAME ANYONE FOR LIVING HOW THEY WANT! BE A NICE PERSON!

story:
The Reclaim Your Freedom Fund is a stand to notify municipalities and ultimately update laws that violate the rights granted to 'We the People' by the US Constitiution and the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights.

 

Our goal is two-fold;

1) Stop the Raids on our Temples, and

2) Stop governing restrictions of earth-based, ceremonial practices

 

As we approach new milestones in the race to save our planet and humanity we see movements sprouting up everywhere.

 

  • Reclaim Your Freedom Fund - Advocates the right to gather, believe, practice earth-based ceremonies for purification.
  • 2012 Mayan Calendar ends - From Pinchbeck to Star Knowledge, integration of spirit and matter
  • OCCUPY Wall Street - Established a stand for the 99% for economic justice
  • American Indian Movement - Established to stop cultural genocide and reinstate human rights

 

The underlying current in these movements is that the people are tired of being molded into drones of a small majority; tired of being controlled, manipulated and oppressed by corrupt governance.  A good example of a failed movement is the War on Drugs, a trickle-down method to feed a system of power, corruption and greed through mass incarceration of our youth and underprivelaged.

 

To Date we have raised $20,700 of which 94% of funds went directly to attorney fees and 6% to expert consultants.  Our current campaign is at 137% going toward attorney fees and we need your help to raise the full amount toward these early stage educational efforts.  Please contribute today so that we can raise the endorsements for the bigger picture, an annualized movement to reclaim our freedoms!  

Cultural Genocide is happening again, only it now targets the 99%, Reclaim Your Freedom! 

 

Background:

After a 20+ year career transition (corporate burnout) I settled into a “cause”, a spiritual retreat center in Sedona where my skills quickly found a home supporting a worldwide vision to free this planet of the guilt, fear and shame of a corrupt world order.  As I busied myself establishing our educational distinctions, our center attracted diverse talent from across the globe. 

 

Our Founder was engaging hundreds of practitioners and teachers in over 30 countries each year to gather and share their knowledge and skills supporting spiritual, sexual and shamanic consciousness, in a nutshell, an alternative healing support organization based on a blend of Hindu, Buddhist, Taoist and Tantric practices.

 

We established the International School of Temple Arts (ISTA), were ordained by the Madonna Ministries and established headquarters for the ONAC of ISTA Native American Church (ISTA-ONAC).  Each of these organizations shared the Temple and common vision of transforming people’s lives by shedding old paradigms and getting back to the ancient and natural ways of the world.

 

What happened in Arizona?

Our Temples were harassed by City Planning then raided By a State-led SWAT assault, followed by other Arizona shut-downs of earth-based ceremonial practices.

 

To learn more and read about what happened in Arizona and how funds are allocated follow this link... 

http://www.ista-onac.org/reclaimyourfreedom

 

Overview

Who:  The Reclaim Your Freedom Fund is established by the international non-profit organization ISTA-ONAC, who supports indigenous, earth-based and sex-positive cultural practices.

 

What:  The Fund is allocated for the purpose of standing for US Constitutional and UN Declaration of Human Rights to gather and practice ceremonial arts (Temple Arts).  The distribution will be allocated to attorney fees (50-75%), experts (10-30%) and administration (10-20%).

 

Why:  The Fund's purpose is to put municipalities on notice and ultimately enforce and update laws to support US Constitutional and UN Declaration of Human Rights to gather and practice ceremony.

 

When:  Fourth round funding is taking place Nov-Dec 2012 (see fund calendar in the Arizona link above)

 

How:  Round four funds will be allocated to the attorneys and experts who will put Arizona municipalities on notice and lay the groundwork for a Federal effort to stop the harassment of alternative practices.

story:
It started with one person… and now a group of friends have shown up to help cook and deliver meals for the past 14 years – the first year, 28 homeless were fed! The next year more showed up and over fifty meals went out. The following year we reached the 100 mark and fast-forward to last year when we were able to feed over 10,000 homeless across multiple cities in the USA.

Gobble Gobble Give has become an incredible example of what a community can do to make change. If you are reading this, you have been invited to join us!

WE NEED YOUR HELP

This year GGG is making a bid to reach out to more cities and to help more people.  But we need your help first!

We’re using IndieGoGo to raise money for our annual multi-city potluck.  Gobble Gobble Give is a 501c3 non-profit and all funds go towards providing food, supplies, and any relevant facility costs to those that host our event.  Anything left over just rolls into the next year.

Every Thanksgiving we try to expand our ability to help feed the homeless, and every Thanksgiving we’re floored by the outreach of support (from our on-the-day volunteers to the companies that donate their goods to clothe the homeless).  This year we think we can do even more!

THE NITTY GRITTY

We’re asking for $10,000 from the community.

We are able to scrape by each year with a few thousand dollars in our collective budget, and we’ve reached maximum bang for our buck.  With your support we can expand our operation to cover the costs of including more cities and providing more food and supplies to those in need. 

Funds that we raise go into a GGG general fund that we use to buy supplies and food for each location hosting a potluck event on Thanksgiving. 

THE ‘NOT SO SECRET’ SECRET

Helping to feed and clothe someone over the holidays is an amazing experience.  The person in need receives some love and support, yes, but the real transformative experience comes from the volunteers that give their time and energy to step away from their holiday obligations to help others.  We’ve seen friendships form and lives change with one service.

If and when GGG can expand, this experience can be offered not only on Thanksgiving, but throughout the year!

BUT WAIT, THAT’S NOT ALL

In exchange for helping fund an amazing event, we’re offering a unique set of perks that are as diverse and eclectic as our GGG family.  From a permanent thank-you on our website to a deluxe spa package courtesy of The Raven Spa, golfing with Billy Zane (yes this is for real) and even a signed catalogue by Ed Ruscha! Please see what perk level strikes your fancy.  If you really want to be a rockstar (or at least prepare meals next to one), come join in on the fun for a couple of hours on Thanksgiving morning!

KEEP CALM AND GIVE ON

Gobble Gobble Give offers the potluck event for volunteers every year.  If you can’t donate, spread the word and better yet come help out!

This year we plan to host potluck events in the following cities on Thanksgiving:

  • Los Angeles, CA - Echo Park
  • Los Angeles, CA - Santa Monica
  • Harlem, NY
  • San Francisco, CA
  • Austin, TX
  • Las Vegas, NV

Visit our website at www.gobblegobblegive.com to see the details, and thank you very much!

event on Thanksgiving.  
THE ‘NOT SO
SECRET’ SECRET
Helping to feed and clothe someone over the
holidays is an amazing experience.  The
person in need receives some love and support, yes, but the real transformative
experience comes from the volunteers that give their time and energy to step
away from their holiday obligations to help others.  We’ve seen friendships form and lives change
with one service. 
If and when GGG can expand, this experience
can be offered not only on Thanksgiving, but throughout the year!
BUT
WAIT, THAT’S NOT ALL
In exchange for helping fund an amazing
event, we’re offering a unique set of perks that are as diverse and eclectic as
our GGG family.  From a permanent thank-you on our website to a deluxe spa package courtesy of The Raven Spa, golfing with Billy Zane (yes this is for real) and even a signed catalogue by Ed Ruscha! Please see what perk level strikes your fancy.  If you really want to be a rockstar (or at least prepare meals next to one), come join in on the fun for a couple of hours on Thanksgiving morning!


KEEP CALM
AND GIVE ON
Gobble Gobble Give offers the potluck event
for volunteers every year.  If you can’t
donate, spread the word and better yet come help out! 
This year we plan to host potluck events in
the following cities on Thanksgiving:


Los Angeles, CA - Echo Park

Los Angeles, CA - Santa Monica
Harlem, NY

San Francisco, CA

Austin, TX

Las Vegas, NV



Visit our website at www.gobblegobblegive.com to see
the details, and thank you very much!

story:
--> Scroll the page to read the english description! <--

Di cosa si tratta?

Alok Vaid-Menon descrive così il suo spettacolo "Femme in Public":

"Quale parte femminile di te hai dovuto distruggere per poter sopravvivere in questo mondo? A che punto la femminilità diventa sinonimo di scusa? Chi ha fatto del male alle persone che ti hanno fatto del male?" 

Una serata di poesia, stand-up comedy, drag e molto altro per indagare il personale e il politico della realtà delle minoranze transgender e gender non-conforming. 

Lo spettacolo sarà in lingua inglese. Non sono previsti interpreti per non interferire nello svolgimento della performance ma verrà fornito del materiale al pubblico per facilitare la comprensione. 

Alok Vaid-Menon e Grace Dunham

Alok Vaid-Menon è un* artista e performer. Si occupa di scrittura creativa, poesia e formazione. Negli ultimi dieci anni Alok ha lavorato con i movimenti femministi, queer e trans di tutto il mondo. Il suo stile eclettico e la sfida poetica al binarismo di genere sono riconosciuti a livello internazionale. 

Alok ha collaborato con HBO, MTV, National Geographic, le riviste The Guardian e The New Yorker e molto altro. 

www.alokvmenon.com

Grace Dunham è una scrittrice e attivista americana. Ha recitato nei film Tiny Furniture (2010) di Lena Dunham e Happy Birthday, Marsha! (2016) di Reina Gosset e Sasha Wortzel. Scrive articoli per il New Yorker e Buzzfeed in cui si occupa di diritti delle persone queer e transgender e storia del movimento transgender.

Nel 2016 pubblica la sua prima opera di poesia e saggi che si intitola The Fool, disponibile gratuitamente online.

 

Come verranno utilizzati i fondi?

I fondi raccolti verranno utilizzati interamente per coprire le spese dell'evento: cachet degli artisti, location, pubblicità cartacea e su internet.

Se le offerte dovessero superare la soglia prevista, il denaro restante andrà a finanziare i prossimi progetti del collettivo Starfish.

 

Il nostro modo di dire grazie: le ricompense

 

25 €

Donando 25 euro riceverai:

  • una tote bag del Collettivo Starfish con grafica esclusiva a cura di Michele Bruttomesso.
  • nr. 1 ingresso ridotto allo spettacolo "Femme In Public" di Alok Vaid-Menon del 30/07/2017.

50 €

Donando 50 euro riceverai:

  • una tote bag del Collettivo Starfish con grafica esclusiva a cura di Michele Bruttomesso.
  • nr. 1 ingresso gratuito allo spettacolo "Femme In Public" di Alok Vaid-Menon del 30/07/2017

100 €

Donando 100 euro riceverai:

  • una tote bag del Collettivo Starfish con grafica esclusiva a cura di Michele Bruttomesso.
  • nr. 1 ingresso gratuito con posto riservato allo spettacolo "Femme in Public" di Alok Vaid Menon del 30/07/2017.
  • una copia della locandina dell'evento (formato A3) autografata da Alok Vaid-Menon e Grace Dunham

 

Chi c'è dietro al progetto?

Starfish è un piccolo collettivo che vive e opera in provincia, precisamente a Schio (VI), dal 2014. Il nostro messaggio si identifica con quello del cosiddetto femminismo intersezionale: sessimo, razzismo, fascismo, classismo, eteronormatività non sono indipendenti tra loro ma agiscono insieme. È necessario scardinare questo intero sistema per affermare che ognuno può e deve essere sé stess*.

Vogliamo costruire in città e nei dintorni una discussione attiva attorno ai temi del femminismo intersezionale, delle questioni di genere, dei diritti LGBTQI, della lotta contro omofobia e transfobia.

Organizziamo conferenze, concerti, spettacoli teatrali, dibattiti pubblici, cineforum, workshop e laboratori. Collaboriamo con associazioni, cooperative, fablab e scuole per proporre attività, corsi e laboratori che pongono l'attenzione sulle questioni di genere: dall'inclusione delle ragazze nei mestieri uniformemente considerati "da uomo" all'educazione di genere nelle scuole, passando per la discussione attiva contro il linguaggio sessista e sensazionalista dei media, la difesa della legge 194 e i diritti delle persone transgender e gender non-conforming. Nel 2015 e nel 2016 abbiamo lavorato a Meltdown Fest, un festival queer e femminista che ha visto numerosi ospiti provenienti da tutta Italia. Siamo tra le realtà promotrici della manifestazione annuale "Schio Contro l'Omofobia". 

Il nostro lavoro coinvolge il territorio di Schio e dintorni perché crediamo che anche in provincia sia tempo di affrontare le questioni di genere e di abbattere dubbi, pregiudizi e discriminazioni relativi ad esse. 

Alcune realtà con cui abbiamo collaborato: Soft Revolution Zine, NarrAzioni Differenti, Pasionaria.it, SAT Pink Verona, Cooperativa Samarcanda, Megahub, Non Una Di Meno, Amnesty International, MigraBO, Associazione "Trama di Terre", Il Referendum, Monique Honeybird Mizrahi, Progetto InterGrace, Comitata Giordana Bruna

Altri modi per contribuire:

Se non puoi contribuire economicamente ma vorresti comunque darci una mano:

  • Condividi questa campagna sulle tue pagine Facebook, Twitter, Instagram
  • Metti like alla pagina facebook di Starfish per rimanere informat* sui nostri prossimi eventi

Il nostro progetto è ambizioso e per portarlo avanti abbiamo bisogno del vostro contributo. Per qualsiasi informazione ulteriore non esitate a contattarci! Grazie!

 

____________________________________________________________________________________


Starfish is a small collective based in the city of Schio (VI), Italy.  We work on the themes of intersectional feminism, LGBTQI rights, fight against omophobia and transphobia and all the gender-related issues. 
We believe that even in small towns/suburbs/province it’s necessary to start talking about all these things, in order to destroy prejudices, doubts and discriminations connected to them. 


For the first time in Italy, a performance about the gender identity: with your donation you can help us realize this project!

 

What is it?


Alok Vaid-Menon, describing their performance “Femme in Public”, says:
“What feminine part of yourself did you have to destroy in order to survive in this world? At what point does femininity become synonymous with apology? Who hurt the people who hurt you? Let's figure it out.”

An evening of poetry, stand-up comedy, drag and more to analyze the personal and political aspects of the life of transgender and gender non-conforming minorities.


The performance will be in English.


Alok Vaid-Menon and Grace Dunham


Alok Vaid-Menon is an artist and performer.
Their work includes creative writing, poetry and education/formation. In the last ten years Alok collaborated with feminist, queer and transgender movements from all over the world. Their eclectic style and their poetic challange to the gender binarism are recognized internationally.
Alok worked with HBO, MTV, National Geographic, The Guardian, The New Yorker and more.
www.alokvmenon.com


Grace Dunham is a writer, actress and activist based in Los Angeles.
She appeared in the movies Tiny Furniture directed by Lena Dunham and Happy Birthday, Marsha directed by Reina Gossett and Sasha Wortzel
She writes for the New Yorker and Buzzfeed about queer and transgender rights and the history of the transgender movement.
In 2016 she published her first collection of poems and essays, The Fool, available online for free.

How your donations will be used?


All the collected funds will be entirely used to cover all the expenses of the event: artists’ cachet, location, marketing.
If the donations will exceed the threshold, the remaining money will fund the next projects of Starfish collective.
 


How we will thank you:
 


20 €
Giving 20 euros you’ll get:
- 1 Starfish tote bag with exclusive graphics made by Michele Bruttomesso
- 1 reduced-price ticket to the performance “Femme in Public” of Alok Vaid-Menon

50 €
Giving 50 euros you’ll get:
- 1 Starfish tote bag with exclusive graphics made by Michele Bruttomesso
- 1 free ticket to the performance “Femme in Public” of Alok Vaid-Menon


100 €
Giving 100 euros you’ll get:
- 1Starfish tote bag with exclusive graphics made by Michele Bruttomesso
- 1 free ticket with reserved seat to the performance “Femme in Public” of Aloc Vaid-Menon
a copy of the poster of the event (A3 format) signed by Alok Vaid-Menon and Grace Dunham
 


Who's behind the project?

Starfish is a small collective based in Schio, Italy. Our feminism is intersectional. We believe that sexism, racism, fascism, classism and eteronormativity are not independent issues: they act together, so it’s necessary to demolish this entire system in order to state that everyone can and has to be him/her/themself. 
We want to start in our territory an active and free discussion around themes like feminism, gender issues, LGBTQI rights, omophobia and transphobia. 

We organize conferences, concerts, theatrical shows, public debates, cinema clubs and workshops. By collaborating with cooperatives, fab-labs, schools and other organizations we are able to bring to the people activities, classes and workshops that pay close attention to the gender issues.


In 2015 and 2016 we focused in the creation and development of a queer and feminist festival, Meltdown Fest, that engaged many guests and artists from all over Italy. We also are in the organizing commitee of the annual event “Schio contro l’omofobia” (“Schio against Omophobia”)

Some of the organizations and institutions we worked with: Soft Revolution Zine, NarrAzioni Differenti, Pasionaria.it, SAT Pink Verona, Cooperativa Samarcanda, Megahub, Non Una Di Meno, Amnesty International, MigraBO, Associazione "Trama di Terre", Il Referendum, Monique Honeybird Mizrahi, Progetto InterGrace, Comitata Giordana Bruna

 

With you help we will be able to do something great and important. Please consider donating! For any information you can reach us at: starfish.schio@gmail.com

Thank you!
