story:
http://www.veterans4veteransamerica.com

Veterans for Veterans AmericA, Inc. was established by three disabled Veterans who witnessed far too many homeless Veterans on the streets of America. They devised a transitional housing/service support program plan to turn a vacant building into a service support center for homeless Veterans while assisting these Veterans at their local Veteran Administration Medical Center for needed medical treatment and vocational rehabilitation as the plan for their return to productive citizenry and self-sufficiency.

 

The U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) states the nation’s homeless veterans are predominantly male, with roughly five percent being female. The majority of them are single; come from urban areas; and suffer from mental illness, alcohol and/or substance abuse, or co-occurring disorders. About one-third of the adult homeless population are Veterans.

 

According to the National Coalition for Homeless Veterans, America’s homeless Veterans have served in World War II, the Korean War, Cold War, Vietnam War, Grenada, Panama, Lebanon, Afghanistan and Iraq (OEF/OIF), and the military’s anti-drug cultivation efforts in South America. Nearly half of homeless Veterans served during the Vietnam era. Two-thirds served our country for at least three years, and one-third were stationed in a war zone.

 *About 1.5 million other Veterans, meanwhile, are considered at risk of homelessness due to poverty, lack of support networks, and dismal living conditions in overcrowded or substandard housing. 

WHY YOU SHOULD CARE

These are our fellow Americans who answered America's call for defense (through a draft or a volunteer system). 

23% of the homeless population are Veterans

33% of the male homeless population are Veterans

47% served Vietnam-era

17% served post-Vietnam

15% served pre-Vietnam

67% served three or more years

33% were stationed in war zone

25% have used VA homeless services

79% reside in central cities

16% reside in suburban areas

5% reside in rural areas

76% experience alcohol, drug or mental health problems
 
46% are age 45 or older, compared to 20% non-Veterans

Service needs cited include:

45% need help finding a job

37% need help finding housing

 Homeless Veterans need transitional housing/service support programs just like this one. With community support and local Veterans advocates forming the same mentoring and bonding relationships shared (squads, platoons, company elements) during their active duty time in the military, the initial problems that these Veterans are facing (traumatic brain injury, denial of the extent of service-connected injuries, post-traumatic stress disorder, combat fatigue, inability to readjust to normalcy of life after combat, etc.) can be addressed with the proper medical treatment and Veteran advocate assistance. 

 *Returning Soldiers today, are expected to have multiple combinations of these combat-related problems due to reoccurring deployments since 9/11. (That's almost a decade of multiple deployments)

WHAT WE NEED

This nonprofit needs $55,000 to purchase a Veteran Development Center to support the service needs of these homeless Veterans. The center focuses on the immediate programs (i.e. discharge upgrade processing, a food closet, financial literacy workshops, job skills development, support for VA disability and compensation, etc.) 

WHAT YOU GET

$25 Donors - get a Certificate of Appreciation sign by the three disabled Veterans co-founders of Veterans for Veterans, AmericA, Inc. (and a tax-deductible letter of thanks for the IRS 2010 tax year). 

 

$50 Donors - get a "Homeless Veterans need a HAND UP not a HAND OUT!" Campaign T-shirt (please indicate size in donor information) (and a tax-deductible letter of thanks for the IRS 2010 tax year). 

 

$100 Donors - get a Certificate of Appreciation sign by the three disabled Veterans co-founders of Veterans for Veterans, AmericA, Inc. and a lapel pin with the Veterans for Veterans logo(a tax-deductible letter of thanks for the IRS 2010 tax year).

 

$500 - get a Certificate of Appreciation sign by the three disabled Veterans co-founders of Veterans for Veterans AmericA, Inc., a "Homeless Veterans need a HAND UP not a HAND OUT!" Campaign T-shirt (please indicate size in donor information) (and a tax-deductible letter of thanks for the IRS 2010 tax year). 

 

$1000 and more - get name of donor engraved in a bronze plate denoting the date of transitional home program establishment and ‘made possible by donations from the following...(your name) The plate will be cemented on the property of the home just below the American flag pole that commemorates all past and present Veterans. Remembering that “All gave some and some gave All."  (and a tax-deductible letter of thanks for the IRS 2010 tax year). 

HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP

We ask all donors and those who can't give at this time to support this cause by getting the word out. Log onto your email accounts, Facebook, and other social media outlets and connect this cause with your friends, family and people.

We ask that you support and continue to support all 9/11 Commemorations, Veterans Day (Nov 11th), Memorial Day(last Monday in May), Homecoming Parades for returning Soldiers (from Afghanistan and Iraq) in your state and other Veteran causes.

Contact your local elected officials and tell them to visit the Veterans Administration Medical Centers in their states and ask about the Homeless Veteran program (successes and failures). Help us to end homelessness amongst Veterans, some of America’s greatest patriots in five years (2015).

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Cindy Zelman. I am a writer, a working stiff, a quiet philanthropist and an activist for gay rights. Over the past few years, I have gotten to know a number of gay and lesbian Ugandans and learned of their horrific living conditions in a country where it is illegal to be gay. I have used my personal funds to help a number of them escape to more tolerant countries.  I have come to realize that I need help from others if I am to continue to help these persecuted people on an on-going basis.

  • Imagine if you once held a decent job, had a partner, a place to live, and played soccer for recreation. Sometimes you marched for Gay Rights in your country. You were a good person living your life. Now, just because you are gay, you are thrown in jail, beaten, or left to starve in the slums of Kampala. This is not an exaggeration. For quite awhile, the LBGTI population of Uganda lived in fear of a "Kill the Gays" bill that would have imposed the death penalty. What has passed is the Anti-Homosexuality Bill, which imposes up to life sentences for being gay, with additional penalties (prison sentences) to anyone who knowingly rents an apartment or hires a gay person. Families are throwing their gay children out on the streets. Gays are being routed out of public internet cafes by mobs of people.  A government does not need to officially pass a "death penalty" to impose such on a group of people. This is what Uganda has done to its LBGTI population. 

  • In this campaign, we will help two young men experiencing persecution in Uganda to escape to South Africa or to another country where they can live without fear for their lives. Harold is currently wandering aimlessly in Uganda and starving. Bryan is imposing on a friend and living in a one room shack in the slums of Kampala. I am sending money from my personal account just to keep them fed as I can. Bryan and Harold are not their actual names because I cannot publicize that -- should the Ugandan authorities find out they are trying to escape, they will be immediately jailed. But they are two real people I have come to know.

  • By contributing $5 or $10 to this campaign, you will help me to get Bryan and Harold to a place where they can find work, rent an apartment, and begin life anew, without fearing for their lives just for being themselves. I know that in this new age of crowd funding, we are asked to give money for everything from helping those who are ill with medical bills to someone's latest fantasy about producing a film about the mating habits of goats. This is why I am asking for just $5 - $10 per person. If I can get 300 people to give in those small amounts, you will will have saved the lives of two deserving gay Ugandan men. Of course, if you want to give more, that is always welcome.

What We Need & What You Get

  • For $550 each, I can get Bryan and Harold safely to South Africa where gays are protected under the law. It takes about $300 to travel there which includes bribes to border guards, bus fare, and food. The other $200 is to get them started with food and an apartment (shared with other Ugandan refugees) once they enter South Africa. South Africa is the only country in Africa I know of where the  government is offering asylum and refugee status to persecuted LBGTI people of Uganda. In large part, this generosity is due to the late Nelson Mandela. The other $50 is to cover fundraising fees on Indigogo so we net out at least $1,000.

  • If you can give $12, I will send you a copy of my new chapbook (when it is available for print, date to be announced in 2014, titled What's in A Butch's Purse and Other Humorous Essays .  (If you are interested in purchasing the book on your own, all the proceeds will go to this fundraising campaign. It is a slower way to raise money, but still a way. You can purchase the book here: http://www.wingedcitychapbooks.com/ ) Again, you can also receive this book as a perk for a $12 donation.

  • If we don't reach the entire goal with this campaign, I will place the money that we do raise (minus the Indigogo fee) into an account I have set up for Bryan and Harold. I will continue to try to feed these young men, and I will start a new campaign to raise the rest of the money until I have enough to move them to freedom.

The Impact

  • Your $5-$10 (or more) donation will directly impact and save the lives of two men who are living under persecution in Uganda just because they are gay. There is a good chance they will be beaten or starve if they cannot get out soon. Their names and faces have been published in the tabloids so they are recognizable as gay men to the populace and to the police.

  • Using my own funds, I have helped a lesbian couple and two gay men escape to Kenya (which is better than Uganda for gays but not as safe as South Africa.) I have also, using my own funds, helped two gay men successfully escape to South Africa, where they now have an apartment and jobs and are making a new life. They are generously offering to help house Bryan and Harold if we can get them to the country.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't afford to give any money, I urge you to share this campaign on your social networks because others may have the means to help. Your contribution in just sharing this campaign is worth its weight in gold.
  • You are free to use the  Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Friends,

We would like to inform that right now, Chile is living a catastrophe!!!! Because of heavy rains and other weather conditions there are entires cities under water and mud, with hundreds of people missing.

People that had been in situ, inform us that there are dead people all around and that there are places where no one have been yet, that the dimension of this catastrophe is worst than any other natural disaster from before in Chile.

We are doing a fund raising to help this people from the north of Chile, we will buy tools, health supplies and water at low cost and we will send a truck to the north, finally we will deliver this supplies to a very well known foundation experts on disasters in Chile, named "Un techo para Chile".

So please help us to make this happen!

story:
JOIN US FOR THE 10th ANNUAL CHRISTMAS ONCE AGAIN!
SHARE CHRISTMAS WITH THE HOMELESS...VOLUNTEER...DONATE...

PLUS an OPTIONAL WORKSHOP and SHELTER TOUR!

 

For many of us, Christmas time means a holiday off school and work; a perfect time to relax and enjoy good music, food and prepare for the new year.  Each year in most major cities around the world, hundreds of people are living on the streets without adequate food, clothing, shelter and hope.  Christmas time is one of the hardest times of the year due to the cold weather and that establishments are closed.

Our goal is to share with them, some love, hope, items, and hopefully some fun.  It will be a great opportunity for us to talk with them and spread the true meaning and joy of Christmas.  We believe that the event will not only provide hope, happiness and a memorable experience for the homeless, but also allow us to learn about people with different backgrounds.

Join us on Sunday, December 18, 2016 to deliver gift bags to the homeless of downtown Toronto!

 

Optional Workshop and Shelter Tour:

Want to learn more about the homeless? Want to hear first-hand from those on and streets and in shelters? Join us on an optional workshop where you will watch videos and discuss about our prior experiences with the homeless on the streets. We will then head to a local shelter for a tour where you can see a shelter first-hand. Afterwards, you will be able to interact with the homeless directly on the streets! If you are interested in this option, please arrive at 11am instead of 2pm, but you must register ahead of time via email to edwardchoi@alumni.qmul.net and roybok@hotmail.com


Meeting location:
Wilfrid Laurier University's Downtown Toronto Office
Exchange Tower
130 King Street West
Toronto  ON  M5X 1C9
(upon arrival at the office, please ask for Christmas Once Again)

Meeting time: 2pm (for approximately 3 hours. If you wish to join us for the optional workshop and shelter tour, please meet at 11 am)

Transportation:
TTC: St. Andrew Station
GO Transit/VIA Rail: Union Station (5 minutes walk)​
Parking is available at a fee.
Directions available upon request.

SIGN-UP TO VOLUNTEER TODAY!
E-mail:  Edward Choi or Roy Wong
edwardchoi@alumni.qmul.net or roybok@hotmail.com

DONATE TODAY!
Please donate on this site (note: Indiegogo has a service fee), or alternatively, you may arrange with us to make your donations.
Donations must be made or pledged on or before December 16, 2016 to allow adequate time to purchase the materials.

Watch our Christmas Once Again 2016 video on: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zUTN3i9iE4E
Or our introductory video (with last year’s interviews) on: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gRITk82WHwM

Thank you in advance for your support.  Let it be, Christmas Once Again!

Edward Choi & Roy Wong,
Organizers of Christmas Once Again 2016

edwardchoi@alumni.qmul.net
roybok@hotmail.com

story:
Short Summary

The average life expectancy of a trans woman in Peru is 35. By 35, many women of our community lose their lives to violence, illness, and hunger. Our community faces discrimination, harrasment, and violence on a daily basis, and in the district of Lima East, trans women have no resource or refuge to turn to. 

We are a group of trans women from Lima East, dedicated to helping our community. In partnership with the LGBTIQ advocacy organization, Presente, we will launch Lima East's first home for trans women. This home will be staffed and managed entirely by trans women from Lima East, and we will meet a variety of the needs of our community. For trans women in Lima East experiencing homelessness, we will provide a safe place to live with the warmth and support of a family. The home will also feature a beauty salon for trans women and a clinic to offer rapid HIV tests. We will run a number of community projects the home, and our partners at Presente will offer our community members workshops in personal development and employment training.

What We Need & What You Get

For the home to get up and running, we will need 10,000 USD. Here is a breakdown of our projected budget:

Construction: 5,000 USD - We are building the home from the ground up. This amount will cover the construction of the house, including materials and contractors.

Administration: 3,000 - The home's administrative costs will cover our community activities, materials for our workshops, rapid HIV tests, and set-up costs for the beauty salon.

Salaries: 2,000 - Two staff members of the home will be paid a monthly salary of 600 USD. 

The Impact

Our home will give trans women in Lima East the chance to build a life. Not only will the home meet our community's basic needs, but we will also work tirelessly to empower these women to face the daunting challenges of their lives. We are investing in these women for the long term, and we are confident we have the passion, the dedication, and the capacity to establish a home that will serve the trans women of Lima East for decades to come. 

Risks & Challenges

Not surprisingly, we will face particular challenges in founding the Trans Home in Lima East.  

Firstly, we will need to ensure the sustainability of the home. For the home to achieve its mission, our staff must be equipped to administer and manage all the numerous aspects of our project. We will rely on capacity-building training from our partners at Presente, who have extensive experience in running community projects. The financial sustainability of the home is similarly critical to its success. Our goal for is to secure a variety of funding sources for the home to ensure its smooth operation in the first year. We are seeking individual and corporate donors and applying for a number of grants. While donations and grants will provide the bulk of our funding for the first year, we plan to generate income to cover a significant percentage of the home's costs through its beauty salon. Within two to three years, we aim to make the home financially self-sustainable.

Another pressing concern is the safety of the home and the women belonging to it. Our home will be officially registered with the municipality of the district, and we will advocate the district mayor to guarantee permanent police protection of the home. The safety of our community is our top concern, and our home will be a place of refuge.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand not everyone is able to give financially. If you are inspired by our project, we will launch a facebook page for the home very soon! Please check back for the link and like our page!

story:
HI! MY NAME IS MARYA-- I’m the founder of ABQ Zine Fest, (now in its 4th year) The Albuquerque Zine Library, and a co-founder/curator of The Tannex, a DIY performance clubhouse, in this outpost, in the high desert of New Mexico. I love my creative community, and I do a lot to support and nurture it. I’m asking for your support as I embark on a new project that expands my love for zines, self-publishing, and storytelling . . .


THE PAMPHLETEER PROJECT MISSION: to help diversify existing zine collections, or help establish new ones by presenting women/feminist focused, people of color influenced, gender-inclusive zines and comics to groups and collectives around the world.

YOUR CONTRIBUTION TO THE PAMPHLETEER PROJECT will help me get to Sweden to present a pop-up zine library and free workshops at the TITWRENCH Stockholm Festival-- a women’s music festival. The fest was founded in Denver by Sarah Slater in 2008. TITWRENCH Stockholm is the first satellite of the original fest. After the event, I will donate 100-200 zines to a collective in the city. 



Here's a short video to show my appreciation for the support flowing in. THANKS SO MUCH!!

..............................................................................................................................................

YOUR GENEROUS FINANCIAL SUPPORT will:

  • Cover airfare to Stockholm.
  • Pay for simple materials to set up the zine library. 
If we surpass the goal of $2,500, this will allow me to take this pilot program and expand its reach to other collectives within the punk/zine community and beyond. Someday, I imagine this project being able to support other zinesters interested in delivering zines to groups and communities.

.............................................................................................................................................

WHY STOCKHOLM?

To spite our perceptions of Sweden being a utopia, The country is more diverse than the media reflects. Along with the changes to this nation comes unrest. Last year, Stockholm experienced 5 days of rioting.  On March 8th of this year, an act of fascism in the form of a knife attack occurred on the night of International Women’s Day, injuring several women taking part in a Reclaim the Night demonstration. These are acts of violence, but they are also acts of ignorance. The Pamphleteer Project supports the independent voice by presenting diversity as a means of and solidarity with local communities striving for peace through mutual acceptance. 

UPDATE: Please read this blog post that explains WHY Stockholm is the pilot city for The Pamphleteer Project: http://bit.ly/TheRevolutionWillBeCataloged

..............................................................................................................................................

WHY ZINES?

I know zines to be a form that can open pathways to self-expression when other avenues are blocked, guide people through difficult conversations, and fuel strong political actions in communities through the power of the independent voice. Most importantly, zines can connect us to the human intimacy of storytelling.

The earth, the bark, the tree, the ZINE. It can all mean something. Let's make our words and our actions meaningful! Please support this project!

.............................................................................................................................................

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

+ Due to time constraints, and optimum ticket-buying, please donate to the project via paypal. I know, I know. . . your donation via credit card is also appreciated!  

+ If you can't contribute $$ please donate ZINES that fit the criteria mentioned in the project description. Please email me at pamphleteerproject at gmail dot com to find out where to submit your zine! 

THANK YOU!

PS-- Please follow The Pamphleteer Project on Tumblr: http://thepamphleteerproject.tumblr.com/

story:
ALL DONATIONS MATCHED UP TO $1000


This project has one mission: 

HONOR OUR VETERANS

We're a grassroots agroforestry nonprofit based in San Bernardino County 
We're giving everyone the opportunity to honor veterans in a  lasting and meaningful way by planting a tree in their legacy. 


________________________________________


Each $50 raised=1 tree for a veteran 

(perks increase with funding levels)

________________________________________

How it all started:

Our organization...

The Incredible Edible Community Garden 

...received an 8,500 tree donation from 

Southern California Edison 

that has grown into a...

 10,000+ tree nursery. 

_________________________________________

Now 

We want to Dedicate 

each Tree 

in the name of a VETERAN, living or deceased, past or present.

_______________________________________________________________


For more information, visit www.IECGarden.org

______________________________________________________________

If our funding goal is not met, all funds raised will go to the planting of these trees AND we will plant these trees. We will complete our mission. IECG will contact donors by phone or email to retrieve veteran or veterans information for the tree.

story:
The WorldPride Human Rights Conference

An extraordinary gathering of activists, artists, educators, journalists, policymakers, students and academics engaged in LGBTI human rights around the world. This conference provides a unique opportunity for global dialogue about LGBTI human rights, ranging from performances to presentations, politics to policies, and activists to academics. The WPHRC14 is organized by WorldPride and the Bonham Centre for Sexual Diversity Studies.

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to cover the costs of transportation and accommodation for the 175+ presenters that will be participating in the conference. Your support will help leading LGBTI activists from countries including Uganda, Russia, Nigeria, Indonesia, India, China and many others attend the conference.

The Impact

This is a chance for the LGBTI community to come together to discuss the issues that matter to us and to further the human rights of LGBTI people around the globe. Your support will help provide opportunities for important dialogue between grassroots leaders and contribute to this growing international movement.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have money to spare? That's okay, there's lots of other ways you can help including volunteering your time or joining in our facebook conversations. Share the news with your friends, the WorldPride Human Rights Conference 2014 is coming!

story:
Short Summary

We are collecting sponsorship to subsidise the entry fee for players entering the 2013 Hampshire Judo Championships. Please consider donating to our fund and if you donate over £25 you can have your name (or business) associated with one of the 37 categories.

All donors will be publically thanked on our website (unless anonymity is requested).

 

The 2013 Hampshire Judo Championships is a chance for Hampshire's Judo community to compete against each other to decide who is the best in the county.

This year we are running running the event in Southampton and we are aiming to run two contest areas to enable us to deliver a competition for juniors 8-15 years old and adults 16 and over.

This campaign is to obtain funding to cover the costs of running the event so that we do not have to pass all the costs onto the competitors.

What We Need

Our expenses include:

  • Hall hire
  • Medals for players
  • Catering
  • Certificates
  • Trophies
  • First Aid coverage
  • Expenses for officials
  • Equipment

The Impact

This competition will have a large impact on Judo in Hampshire. Judo was able to contribute two medals at the London2012 games and those medalists started their careers competing in local events like ours. We shall provide an opportunity for players to compete and test their skills.

The Hampshire Championships will provide the following benefits to Hampshire:

  • Encourage the existing players to compete
  • Promote the sport of Judo in Hampshire
  • Encourage health through participation in sport
  • Provide volunteering opportunities

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please promote this campaign
  • Please promote our event
  • Please volunteer in the running of the event

Thank you for visiting this campaign and for supporting the sport of Judo in our county.

 

Please donate via this site and help us keep the price we charge for athletes low.

story:
Short Summary

What About The Children in Haiti, Inc is a nonprofit organization dedicated to helping the less fortuunate children in Haiti.

With our small blessings in a backpack fundraiser we were able to raise over 70 backpacks filled with school supplies for a afternoon school for restavec children in Croix-des-Bouquets, Haiti. With this fundraiser donors donated backpacks filled with school supplies but included a personalized note to the child and in return they will get a personalized thank you note from their child along with pictures. Now we need your help shipping the donations over and helping a group of volunteers accompany us to Haiti this summer to visit the school and pass out the backpacks to the children.

What We Need & What You Get

We need a minimum of $2,000 to help pay for airfare and hotel stay for 4 days in Haiti for a group of 5 volunteers. You can sign up for our newsletter and stay current with our progress.

The Impact

The children at Institution Mixte le Sel are known as restavecs. They are Haiti's forgotten children basically day laborers. They are sent to work for families because their family can no longer support them. Many of them never attend school and cannot read or write. Institution Mixte le Sel is the only school in Croix-des-Bouquets, Haiti that allows them to attend school in the afternoon free of charge. Getting these backpacks to the children would be all the motivation they need for the 2013-2014 school year in Haiti, it let's them know that somebody out there believes in them.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help spread the word about our organization, set up fundraisers etc. Contact us for more information.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

Bioflyer Productions and steveNyou Presents are co-sponsoring the exciting 2nd Annual fund-raiser and talent competition and for anyone 13 years or older and living in WNC who wants to strut their stuff in front of a live audience in the tradition of America’s Got Talent and X Factor.

Three winners will be awarded: $500 for first place, $300 for second place, and $200 for third place. Contestants will also receive professional feedback from local celebrity judges. The event is a benefit for Eblen Charities and the steveNyou non-profit restaurant fund.

This year's showcase will be at 7pm on March 15th at JUBILEE, 46 Wall St. in downtown Asheville.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to raise funds we need to attract fantastic local talent--just like those you see in above video from last year--so we can award them with scholarship prizes that acknowledge their achievements and encourage their artistic careers. Once the prize money and venue rental is secured thru your contributions then all proceeds from ticket sales go to the Eblen Charities and SAUTE' non-profit restaurant fund: "A Place To Learn, Dine, and Build Community!"

Perks for your contributions include meal vouchers to SAUTE' "community cafe" which will feature on-the-job training for disadvantaged and disabled workers as well as comittment to reducing food waste through appropriate food portions, encouraging healthy food choices, and careful seasonal meal planning with preparation to help eliminate food insecurity in our community. 

Other perks for the musically inclined are the raffling of two excellent new guitars which you could win simply by donating to our cause.

Impact

BIOFLYER PRODUCTIONS was initially created by Rock Eblen in 2004 as his personal way of contributing to the family’s charity in Western North Carolina. The Eblen Charities is constantly seeking viable partnerships and alliances with other organizations which help reach out to those in need. Rock has built a reputation for producing unique and exciting theater which draws upon a diverse group of local talent who volunteer long hours to create uplifting entertainment.

Steven L. Liebenhaut of steveNyou Presents has been organizing events and raising funds for local nonprofits for over 5 years and has raised $30,000 so far. If you would like to know more about what a non-profit restaurant looks like and how it operates, please view this video about Jon Bon Jovi's Soul Kitchen in NJ:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lX1G6Zzwhes

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can’t contribute a lot, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Please ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

Just use the Indiegogo share tools on this page!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Bioflyer Productions and steveNyou Presents are co-sponsoring the exciting 2nd Annual fund-raiser and talent competition and for anyone 13 years or older and living in WNC who wants to strut their stuff in front of a live audience in the tradition of America’s Got Talent and X Factor.
Three winners will be awarded: $500 for first place, $300 for second place, and $200 for third place. Contestants will also receive professional feedback from local celebrity judges. The event is a benefit for Eblen Charities and the steveNyou non-profit restaurant fund.
This year's showcase will be at 7pm on March 15th at JUBILEE, 46 Wall St. in downtown Asheville. 


What We Need & What You Get
In order to raise funds we need to attract fantastic local talent--just like those you see in above video from last year--so we can award them with scholarship prizes that acknowledge their achievements and encourage their artistic careers. Once the prize money and venue rental is secured thru your contributions then all proceeds from ticket sales go to the Eblen Charities and SAUTE' non-profit restaurant fund: "A Place To Learn, Dine, and Build Community!"
Perks for your contributions include meal vouchers to SAUTE' "community cafe" which will feature on-the-job training for disadvantaged and disabled workers as well as comittment to reducing food waste through appropriate food portions, encouraging healthy food choices, and careful seasonal meal planning with preparation to help eliminate food insecurity in our community. 
Other perks for the musically inclined are the raffling of two excellent new guitars which you could win simply by donating to our cause.


Impact

The Eblen Charities is constantly seeking viable partnerships and alliances with other organizations which help reach out to those in need. Rock has built a reputation for producing unique and exciting theater which draws upon a diverse group of local talent who volunteer long hours to create uplifting entertainment.

story:
Short Summary

We're a small grassroots group, made up of pro-indy Catalans and Scots living in both nations. We feel it is important to give a voice to those of us who support freedom for our nations, because we wish to see Scotland and Catalonia governed by the people who care most about our future. And that's why we need to spread the word and get more supporters! 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Being honest, this campaign says we need 500 euros because it is the minimum required by IndieGogo, but with just 10 euros we can  create ads about the posts of the page, so any donation will have a great impact...

 

The Impact

With your help we can reach thousands of people who probably don't know what's happening in Catalonia, and we will make them know the truth and know the repressive and fascist attitude of the Spanish Government.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

OK, so not everyone can afford to donate, but you can still help us:

· Get out the word about the Catalan cause. Spread the word, join our Facebook group, "like" our Facebook page, follow us on Twitter, etc.

· Contribute to the debate! If you're a proud supporter of the democratic pro-independence movement you can attend demonstrations, talk to your family, friends and neighbours - don't be afraid to get the word out.

story:
Raising the Bar

our first goal was to help Galib and Ibrahim with their legal expenses. Now we want to help all the people of Kufr Qaddum. In order to start the Kufr Qaddum Legal Aid Fund we are aiming now to 10,000 USD.


Background

At 1975 the illegal settlement of Kedumim was formed on Kufr Qaddum's agricultural lands. On 2003 Israel blocked the main and only road leading to Kufr Qaddum at the time.  More agricultural lands were stolen and the access to most of the lands around that road became restricted for 350 days a year. Only at July 2011 the people of Kufr Qaddum started to maintain a weekly non violent demonstrations on fridays. 


The Struggle

At July 2011 the people of Kufr Qaddum started to maintain  weekly non violent demonstrations against the closure of the road and the stealing of lands. Even though that during the last 3 years there wasn't even one attempt to get outside the village borders, the Israeli army, Border police and the Israeli security service are utilizing their full abilities to fight the weekly demos. Including night raids, arbitrary arrests and terrorising detainees, filing false charges and false achieving false indictments in biased military courts and trying to prevent the peaceful demonstrations with brutal force including the use of live ammunition, tear gas, rubber coated bullets, skunk water trucks and so on.


What will be done with the money


All the money donated to the Kufr Qaddum Legal Aid Fund will be used  by Kufr Qaddum popular struggle committee to stand the legal campaign Israel and the Israeli occupation forces is conducting against Kufr Qaddum and it's people in their desperate attempts to suppress the rightful, democratic and peaceful struggle of Kufr Qaddum against the stealing of it's lands and the closure of it's roads.
 At this timethere are more than ten palestinian prisoners from Kufr Qaddum in different stages of prosecution by the Israeli occupation courts. 


The Arrest

Galib and Ibrahim were arrested at a weekly demonstration at Kufr Qaddum. They did nothing wrong. explanations in hebrew why they can't be guilty here. Still the IDF court sentenced them to 8 months in jail and a 275 USD fine each. In Palestine it is a lot of money.

On April 11th 2014 Galib and Ibrahim were arrested at the weekly demo against the blocked around Kufr Qaddum and the stealing of it's lands. while they were arrested a wedding march was taking place. at 0139.org our friend wrote why it is impossible for Galib and Ibrahim be guilty in the dubious charges the IDF accused them in.

  1. Taking part in an illegal march: since 1967 there wasn't even 1 march or demo that was authorised by the Israeli regime. even they israeli court ruled that since there wasn't even one "legal" demonstration since 1967 all demos ARE LEGAL.
  2. Incitement: Since Galib and Ibrahim speak only arabic and the witnesses against them speak only hebrew it is impossible that they could have understand a word of what they said IF they really said anything. you can see the video of the arrest and judge by yourself if in the noise of the wedding and the shooting of tear gas anything could be heard at that time.
  3. throwing stones and gas canisters at the soldiers using a sling: no sling was found in the belongings of Ibrahim and Galib. these two men are students and have a lot to lose if caught breaking the law. as their friend I have never seen them holding a stone or a sling. 
  4. rolling a burnt tire at the troops: the hands of both Galib and Ibrahim were clean. when you touch a tire, especially a burning one, your hands become black with sooth.

story:
WHO AM I

 

 

 

 

THE CAMPAIGN

 

THE TARGET

 

THE COST

 

 

 

IF TARGET IS NOT MET:

Fighting any Social Evil is actually creating a momentum to establish Good.

  • Number of kids supported may go less than planned, however; WWH will happen

Next Steps: 

  • One by One i will put all my 24 stories on Indiegogo to save as many as children i can.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

EACH CONTRIBUTION WILL HELP

 

https://www.facebook.com/worldwithouthunger

Risks & Challenges

I Anticipate Two Challenges:

           Time. If, I get late in finishing my work, then more children will give up on education        before they complete high school. 

           Inflation. Due to ever increasing population in India and the scarcity of water, cost of vegetables and fruits is continuing to grow. Where I live is 7th most expensive cities of India. In next few campaigns i intend to equip schools with water and start growing vegetables on campus.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Let's Pray that each of us is able to contribute in our own best way to end child labor across world.
  • This being my first campaign i can reach to a limit. I urge all to spread the word and boost my confidence to pull children out of child labor.

Thank You Each One!!!

story:
Stand Up for Children!

Help us prevent child sexual exploitation and abductions in Texas.

 

1) GIVE 25 

There are 7 million children in Texas -- help us protect more of them!  We need your financial support to provide children with the knowledge and skills to stay safer on- and off line. 

2) TAKE 25

Take 25 minutes to talk to children in your family about child safety.  Take the Take 25 pledge and get age-appropriate tips and talking points at http://www.take25.org.

3) TELL 25

Tell 25 of your friends via Facebook or email to TAKE 25 and GIVE 25 by sending them the link to this website!

 

Prevention works.

The National Center for Missing & Exploited Children works with  law enforcement to help rescue children from abduction and sexual exploitation.  We provide prevention education to children and their families, schools and communities through NetSmartz®, our online interactive program that teaches children of all ages how to be safer on- and offline. 

The value of child safety training cannot be overstated.  Children listen, process and remember safety tips.

         

"Miss, can I tell you something?"

Maria (not her real name), a 7th grader in South Texas, had been communicating with someone she thought was a friend and was asked by this person to send a nude photo of herself.  Fortunately, Maria had attended one of our NetSmartz® presentations, where she learned how far a single image could spread on the Internet.  Because of what she learned, she chose not to send the nude photo of herself.  She instead confided in her school counselor, who discovered that a high school student had been sending Maria the requests.

story:
Sleepless in Seattle is back to provide every person on the streets of Seattle and King County with a sleeping bag and winter care package. We'll need all of us to get there. Join us in caring for our neighbors with your financial support and your time as meet, serve, and befriend those in greatest need directly on the streets (volunteer interest form).

In the Press

Press links at bottom of page.

The Story

Sleepless in Seattle (SIS) was founded in fall 2014 by a group of Seattle-based volunteers led by Eddie Wang in response to the glaring needs of homeless people they passed every day in the U-District, most without so much as a sleeping bag.

The team galvanized financial and volunteer support from individuals, corporations, and nonprofits who shared a similar desire to see their street-side neighbors acknowledged, warm, and cared for. In the end, the team raised over $75,000 to purchase and distribute 3,500 sleeping bags throughout King County with the help of 220 volunteers and 17 nonprofits. 

This year, the need is even bigger, and we're inviting you to join us in supporting the overlooked and  misunderstood in King County through sleeping bags, winter care packages, and neighborhood teams committed to caring for their own communities on an ongoing basis.

The Problem in 2015

One year later, the challenge is every bit as formidable. On any given winter night, at least 3,800 people in King County sleep unsheltered, a 21% increase over 2014. 

We can argue and debate homelessness, but that doesn’t help the person who is homeless tonight. We have to meet basic human needs first to have any hope of getting people back on their feet again. 
-Redmond Mayor John Marchione on Sleepless in Seattle

Table from the King County Coalition to End Homelessness's One Night Count. 

The Sleepless in Seattle 2015 Plan

Short-Term Efforts: Sleeping Bags, Winter Care Packages & Volunteering at the "Big Give"

Sleepless in Seattle will be purchasing sleeping bags and winter care packages (containing warm socks/hat/gloves, food, and water) with funds raised from this campaign. We will need your help to get there. 

"We make a living by what we get, we make a life by what we give."
-Winston Churchill

Curious what 3,500 sleeping bags looks like? Take a look.


3,500 sleeping bags from 2014's Big Give at Serve Seattle. Sleepover anyone?

This year, we are shooting for 4,000 sleeping bags and 4,000 winter care packages with warm socks, gloves, hats, food, and water - all in a compact drawstring bag (see FAQ for why we are buying sleeping bags again this year). $25 will cover the cost of one sleeping bag, one winter care package with warm socks/hat/gloves. 100% of funds will go towards sleeping bags and care package supplies for the homeless in Seattle & King County. 

Don't worry. We've done the math for you:

1,000 * $100 = $100,000. Teamwork makes the dream work! 
Alternatively... 1 * $100,000 = $100,000. Does anyone have Mr. Gates' number?

These sleeping bags and winter care packages will be distributed at our "Big Give" on Saturday 11/21 at University Christian Church (See 2014 Big Give). Over 200 volunteers, broken into 50 teams, will gather and then be dispersed across the streets of King County to serve those in need. Early registrants and donors will be given priority access to attend the Big Give as a volunteer. Please signup through this volunteer interest form if you would like to attend the Big Give. 

Sleepless in Seattle Volunteer Team at the 2014 Big Give. Look, they're smiling!

Long-Term Efforts: Neighborhood Teams

Sleepless in Seattle will be training and launching "neighborhood teams" following the Big Give on 11/21. These teams will be led by experienced leaders and will care for homeless people in specific neighborhoods (see map below) on an ongoing basis through direct personal contact on the streets. 

Neighborhood Teams Downtown Map

Over the next few months, we will blanket the entirety of King County with volunteer teams so that every homeless neighbor is routinely met by a community of people who will:

  1. Build relationships and make friends.
    We believe that in the context of friendship, "people happen." Friends provide emotional support and empower one another to make healthy life choices. 

  2. Meet immediate needs.
    Teams will help provide basic life essentials like food, water, sleeping bags, as needs arises.

  3. Make referrals to appropriate social services.
    Teams will partner with appropriate nonprofits, businesses, and social services to make referrals (e.g. long-term housing options).

The world needs dreamers, and the world needs doers. But most of all, the world needs dreamers who do. - Sarah Ban Breathnach

Would you consider dreaming with us and doing with us? Please sign up through our non-binding volunteer interest form.

Neighborhood Teams - Meeting needs and making friends!

Partnerships

Sleepless in Seattle is proud to partner with a host of nonprofits and companies in the area. If you would like to partner with us, please email us at sleeplessinseattlegiving@gmail.com.

Nonprofit Partnerships

If you want to go quickly, go alone. To go far, go together. -African Proverb

Nonprofits will receive leftover sleeping bags from the Big Give to meet the ongoing need in our community throughout the winter. A special out to Operation Sack Lunch who will be providing food for our care packages - thank you so much! 

Corporate Partnerships

Louder Rewards - Louder Rewards is our 2015 lead financial sponsor. They have generously contributed $5,000 to the cause. Louder Rewards is a free iOS and Android app designed to help you earn gear for your favorite local sports teams (e.g. Seahawks, Mariners, etc.) for things you already do (e.g. read sporting news).

Canlis - Canlis will be giving away three $250 dinner-for-two gift certificates to three community heroes (excluding Sleepless in Seattle core team members) who are leading the fight against homelessness in King County as nominated and voted on by you. Please submit your nominee through this short form.

Relief Bed/Thermarest - Relief Bed will be providing at least 200 of their proprietary "relief beds" (self-inflating, durable, portable foam mattresses) to be given away in conjunction with the sleeping bags at the Big Give. Thermarest produces the foam behind Relief Bed's goods and will be providing the foam in-kind.

Exxel - Exxel, a US based sleeping bag manufacturer and distributor, will be providing discounted sleeping bags for the Big Give.

Image Source - Image Source will be providing discounted, reusable drawstring bags for the winter care packages.

Simplicity Decor - Simplicity Decor offers "east meets west" home design and decor elements. 15% of proceeds for everything sold at their annual Holiday Open House in Kirkland on Saturday 11/14 will go to Sleepless in Seattle.

PinkaBella Cupcakes - Pinkabella will be providing financial support and cupcakes for volunteers at the Big Give on 11/21.

Greater Good - Greater Good will be providing indirect financial support through their cause-related network of websites.

Point B - Point B is a leading regional management consulting company. They will be providing financial support.

Columbia Sportswear - Columbia will be providing 300 warm beanies.

Stories from Sleepless in Seattle 2014

Thousands of stories came out of Sleepless in Seattle's 2014 Big Give when 220 volunteers met 2,300 people on the streets with simple acts of kindness. Here are just three snapshot stories:

The One with the Red Gloves

-Kim (volunteer from Sleepless in Seattle Big Give 2014)

"I experienced a few moments towards the end of our mission that will be forever in my mind and heart. We saw several homeless men sleeping on the ground under an overpass in Pioneer Square and we pulled over to offer sleeping bags and a caring word.

I woke someone covered head to toe in blankets. The face that peeked out was that of an elderly gentleman who appeared to me to be in his eighties. He gave me a sleepy smile and nodded that he would like the sleeping bag I offered. I asked if we could open it and cover him with it and he nodded again. He then nodded towards a red hat and gloves that a prior Good Samaritan had left. I asked if I could help him put them on, and he said no that they were for me... I tried several times to politely decline and he implored me to take them as his Christmas gift to me." 

The One with the Joy Ride Home

-Dianna (volunteer from Sleepless in Seattle Big Give 2014)

"My most impactful experience was the trip back from South Seattle (where I was distributing sleeping bags) to Wallingford (where I live). We handed out 50 sleeping bags ourselves and felt like we reached most of the homeless in White Center. On my way back home, I passed through Central Downtown and every homeless person I saw had a sleeping bag. Later, when I went to the grocery story in Wallingford, the homeless folks outside also had the sleeping bags. It was awesome seeing how thoroughly a community could bring change to a region as large as Seattle in a single day."

The One with the One

-Eddie Wang (Co-Organizer of Sleepless in Seattle)

During the Big Give, one of my privileges was greeting volunteers who were returning from the streets. I remember encountering one team who had just come back from Redmond. I asked them how many people they had been able to serve on their trip (teams that had been going to downtown had often served 50-100). The team replied that after crossing the 520 toll and roaming Redmond for hours, they found one young man outside the Redmond library that they were able to meet with a sleeping bag and a friendly conversation. They concluded this with the statement: "And it was all worth it."

Perhaps more than any other story, this vignette captures the heart of Sleepless in Seattle. Countless hours had been poured into planning every aspect of fundraising, logistics, and direct contact work - all to bless one person with the simple gift of warmth and friendship. Call it the "Saving Private Ryan" effect or call it a miracle, but whatever "it" is, I truly believe we need more of "it" in our community.

FAQ

Do people who are homeless need sleeping bags?

Yes. The Sleepless in Seattle team has reached out to over a dozen local nonprofits who work with homeless populations to assess the need. These nonprofits have responded with an assessment of significant need with one nonprofit estimating that 80% of the homeless on the streets do not have access to sleeping bags.

"The unfortunate reality is that we do not have the capacity to house all of the homeless youth in our community. Having resources, like sleeping bags, is critical to helping them survive the night and helps us start the conversation forward to get them off the streets." 
-Melinda Giovengo, PhD, Executive Director of Youth Care

We need the whole community engaged to solve homelessness. The Sleepless in Seattle effort is a compassionate way for people to help others stay warm, and to raise awareness for the need for more homes for the homeless.  
Mark Putnam - Executive Director of All Home King County (formerly the King County Committee to end Homelessness)

Is Sleepless in Seattle an accredited 501(c)(3) nonprofit?

Yes. The Sleepless in Seattle team has partnered with Urban Hands, an existing Seattle-based 501(c)(3) nonprofit which provides meal partnership and second chance job opportunities in the Seattle area. This unique relationship affords the Sleepless in Seattle team the advantages of legal recognition as a nonprofit while greatly reducing all administrative costs.

Can I give by check?

Yes. If you would prefer to bypass the Indiegogo fundraising tool, please mail a check to "Sleepless in Seattle - 8420 Greenwood Ave N. Seattle WA 98103" paid to the order of "Urban Hands" with memo "Sleepless in Seattle." 

Are donations tax-deductible?

Yes. Donors can expect to receive an email from payment processor FirstGiving with a tax-deductible receipt from the nonprofit Urban Hands. 

Where exactly is the money going?

The money is going directly to the purchase of sleeping bags and winter care packages. Everyone serving on this project is serving in a volunteer capacity. The minimal administrative costs to cover accounting operations are covered out-of-pocket by the Sleepless in Seattle team.

What happened to last year's sleeping bags?

1) The One Night count reported at 21% increase in homelessness in King County between 2014 and 2015 meaning many of those currently on the streets have never received a sleeping bag.

2) The homeless population tends to be very transient. A significant portion of homeless persons in King County have entered the region while others have left.

3) Many sleeping bags will not be able to last a full year when faced with the challenging conditions of everyday use on the streets. General street abrasion, water damage, and theft all contribute to challenges in long-term use. 

4) Housing a homeless person in emergency shelter often costs $20/day or more. Every option has a cost. Sleeping bags will not end homelessness, but they will help bridge the gap for those who simply need a blanket for the winter.

If sleeping bags won't last a full year, then why do the campaign at all?

Food and shelter are basic necessities that we believe every individual is entitled to. Everyday, thousands of free meals are served across King County. These meals cost money. Likewise, caring for the shelter-oriented needs of individuals costs money. As the King County's homeless shelters do not have adequate space to take in every homeless person, the Sleepless in Seattle team is committed to bridging the gap. We truly believe that $100,000 is a bargain to keep every homeless person in King County warm for the winter.

What specific sleeping bags & winter care package goods will be purchased?

The sleeping bags will be purchased in bulk from American-manufacturer Exxel Outdoors. The specific sleeping bags are mummy-style and rated to +5F. Winter care package socks, gloves, and hat will be purchased from Dollar Days. Each care package will come in a reusable drawstring cinch backpack. The $25 will cover the cost of a sleeping bag, a winter care package essentials, a draw string bag, and per-unit shipping costs. 

Is Sleepless in Seattle religiously affiliated?

Sleepless in Seattle was founded on the life example and teachings of Jesus to love others. We are committed to partnering with anyone with a desire to help others and are committed to serving every person we meet to the highest degree possible.

Why can't those who are homeless help themselves?

Homelessness is a complex issue with interrelated causes including addiction, domestic violence, mental illness, job loss and unemployment, foreclosure, relational brokenness, etc. 

No one ever got to be President of the United States or CEO of a Fortune 500 company without a little help along the way. The same is true of those who are working their way off the streets. Judgment is the duty of the courts. Compassion is the duty of everyday citizens.

Questions & Contact

To get in contact with the Sleepless in Seattle team, please email us at sleeplessinseattlegiving@gmail.com. 

Spread the Word

Here are some suggestions to rally your community:

  • Share the Indiegogo campaign link over social media and email. Be sure to use the #sleeplessinseattle hashtag.
  • Connect with Sleepless in Seattle on Facebook and Twitter.
  • Invite your friends to volunteer with us.

Press

Press from Sleepless in Seattle 2015

KING 5 - 'Sleepless in Seattle' works to give sleeping bags to homeless.

My Northwest - Why give sleeping bags when urban camping is such a problem?

Press from Sleepless in Seattle 2014

Seattle Times - Showing Seattle's homeless a little warmth

KING 5 / Evening Magazine (TV show) - Seattle man launches campaign to give homeless sleeping bags

KOMO News (Seattle Refined) - Sleepless in Seattle: The movement not the movie

KOMO 1000 AM - 4 Minute Interview

Mercer Island Reporter - A Warm Place to Sleep

Bellevue Reporter - Group hopes to provide warmer nights for King County homeless

Redmond Reporter - Redmond native Wang's Sleepless in Seattle project helps homeless population

NW Asian Weekly  - COMMENTARY: Sleepless in Seattle – the city gives back (and bags)
story_txt:
Sleepless in Seattle is back to provide every person on the streets of Seattle and King County with a sleeping bag and winter care package. We'll need all of us to get there. Join us in caring for our neighbors with your financial support and your time as meet, serve, and befriend those in greatest need directly on the streets (volunteer interest form).
In the Press

Press links at bottom of page.

The Story
Sleepless in Seattle (SIS) was founded in fall 2014 by a group of Seattle-based volunteers led by Eddie Wang in response to the glaring needs of homeless people they passed every day in the U-District, most without so much as a sleeping bag.
The team galvanized financial and volunteer support from individuals, corporations, and nonprofits who shared a similar desire to see their street-side neighbors acknowledged, warm, and cared for. In the end, the team raised over $75,000 to purchase and distribute 3,500 sleeping bags throughout King County with the help of 220 volunteers and 17 nonprofits. This year, the need is even bigger, and we're inviting you to join us in supporting the overlooked and  misunderstood in King County through sleeping bags, winter care packages, and neighborhood teams committed to caring for their own communities on an ongoing basis.

The Problem in 2015

One year later, the challenge is every bit as formidable. On any given winter night, at least 3,800 people in King County sleep unsheltered, a 21% increase over 2014. 
We can argue and debate homelessness, but that doesn’t help the person who is homeless tonight. We have to meet basic human needs first to have any hope of getting people back on their feet again. -Redmond Mayor John Marchione on Sleepless in Seattle


Table from the King County Coalition to End Homelessness's One Night Count. 
The Sleepless in Seattle 2015 Plan
Short-Term Efforts: Sleeping Bags, Winter Care Packages & Volunteering at the "Big Give"
Sleepless in Seattle will be purchasing sleeping bags and winter care packages (containing warm socks/hat/gloves, food, and water) with funds raised from this campaign. We will need your help to get there. 
"We make a living by what we get, we make a life by what we give." -Winston Churchill
Curious what 3,500 sleeping bags looks like? Take a look.

3,500 sleeping bags from 2014's Big Give at Serve Seattle. Sleepover anyone?
This year, we are shooting for 4,000 sleeping bags and 4,000 winter care packages with warm socks, gloves, hats, food, and water - all in a compact drawstring bag (see FAQ for why we are buying sleeping bags again this year). $25 will cover the cost of one sleeping bag, one winter care package with warm socks/hat/gloves. 100% of funds will go towards sleeping bags and care package supplies for the homeless in Seattle & King County. 
Don't worry. We've done the math for you:



1,000 * $100 = $100,000. Teamwork makes the dream work! Alternatively... 1 * $100,000 = $100,000. Does anyone have Mr. Gates' number?
These sleeping bags and winter care packages will be distributed at our "Big Give" on Saturday 11/21 at University Christian Church (See 2014 Big Give). Over 200 volunteers, broken into 50 teams, will gather and then be dispersed across the streets of King County to serve those in need. Early registrants and donors will be given priority access to attend the Big Give as a volunteer. Please signup through this volunteer interest form if you would like to attend the Big Give. 

Sleepless in Seattle Volunteer Team at the 2014 Big Give. Look, they're smiling!
Long-Term Efforts: Neighborhood Teams
Sleepless in Seattle will be training and launching "neighborhood teams" following the Big Give on 11/21. These teams will be led by experienced leaders and will care for homeless people in specific neighborhoods (see map below) on an ongoing basis through direct personal contact on the streets. 


Neighborhood Teams Downtown Map

Over the next few months, we will blanket the entirety of King County with volunteer teams so that every homeless neighbor is routinely met by a community of people who will:


Build relationships and make friends.We believe that in the context of friendship, "people happen." Friends provide emotional support and empower one another to make healthy life choices. 
Meet immediate needs.Teams will help provide basic life essentials like food, water, sleeping bags, as needs arises.
Make referrals to appropriate social services.Teams will partner with appropriate nonprofits, businesses, and social services to make referrals (e.g. long-term housing options).

The world needs dreamers, and the world needs doers. But most of all, the world needs dreamers who do. - Sarah Ban Breathnach

Would you consider dreaming with us and doing with us? Please sign up through our non-binding volunteer interest form.


Neighborhood Teams - Meeting needs and making friends!Partnerships
Sleepless in Seattle is proud to partner with a host of nonprofits and companies in the area. If you would like to partner with us, please email us at sleeplessinseattlegiving@gmail.com.
Nonprofit Partnerships




If
you want to go quickly, go alone. To go far, go together. -African
Proverb

Nonprofits will receive leftover sleeping bags from the Big Give to meet the ongoing need in our community throughout the winter. A special out to Operation Sack Lunch who will be providing food for our care packages - thank you so much! 
Corporate Partnerships

Louder Rewards - Louder Rewards is our 2015 lead financial sponsor. They have generously contributed $5,000 to the cause. Louder Rewards is a free iOS and Android app designed to help you earn gear for your favorite local sports teams (e.g. Seahawks, Mariners, etc.) for things you already do (e.g. read sporting news).
Canlis - Canlis will be giving away three $250 dinner-for-two gift certificates to three community heroes (excluding Sleepless in Seattle core team members) who are leading the fight against homelessness in King County as nominated and voted on by you. Please submit your nominee through this short form.
Relief Bed/Thermarest - Relief Bed will be providing at least 200 of their proprietary "relief beds" (self-inflating, durable, portable foam mattresses) to be given away in conjunction with the sleeping bags at the Big Give. Thermarest produces the foam behind Relief Bed's goods and will be providing the foam in-kind.
Exxel - Exxel, a US based sleeping bag manufacturer and distributor, will be providing discounted sleeping bags for the Big Give.
Image Source - Image Source will be providing discounted, reusable drawstring bags for the winter care packages.


Simplicity Decor - Simplicity Decor offers "east meets west" home design and decor elements. 15% of proceeds for everything sold at their annual Holiday Open House in Kirkland on Saturday 11/14 will go to Sleepless in Seattle.
PinkaBella Cupcakes - Pinkabella will be providing financial support and cupcakes for volunteers at the Big Give on 11/21.
Greater Good - Greater Good will be providing indirect financial support through their cause-related network of websites.

Point B - Point B is a leading regional management consulting company. They will be providing financial support.
Columbia Sportswear - Columbia will be providing 300 warm beanies.



Stories from Sleepless in Seattle 2014

Thousands of stories came out of Sleepless in Seattle's 2014 Big Give when 220 volunteers met 2,300 people on the streets with simple acts of kindness. Here are just three snapshot stories:
The One with the Red Gloves
-Kim (volunteer from Sleepless in Seattle Big Give 2014)

"I experienced a few moments towards the end of our mission that will be forever in my mind and heart. We saw several homeless men sleeping on the ground under an overpass in Pioneer Square and we pulled over to offer sleeping bags and a caring word.
I woke someone covered head to toe in blankets. The face that peeked out was that of an elderly gentleman who appeared to me to be in his eighties. He gave me a sleepy smile and nodded that he would like the sleeping bag I offered. I asked if we could open it and cover him with it and he nodded again. He then nodded towards a red hat and gloves that a prior Good Samaritan had left. I asked if I could help him put them on, and he said no that they were for me... I tried several times to politely decline and he implored me to take them as his Christmas gift to me." 
The One with the Joy Ride Home
-Dianna (volunteer from Sleepless in Seattle Big Give 2014)
"My most impactful experience was the trip back from South Seattle (where I was distributing sleeping bags) to Wallingford (where I live). We handed out 50 sleeping bags ourselves and felt like we reached most of the homeless in White Center. On my way back home, I passed through Central Downtown and every homeless person I saw had a sleeping bag. Later, when I went to the grocery story in Wallingford, the homeless folks outside also had the sleeping bags. It was awesome seeing how thoroughly a community could bring change to a region as large as Seattle in a single day."
The One with the One
-Eddie Wang (Co-Organizer of Sleepless in Seattle)
During the Big Give, one of my privileges was greeting volunteers who were returning from the streets. I remember encountering one team who had just come back from Redmond. I asked them how many people they had been able to serve on their trip (teams that had been going to downtown had often served 50-100). The team replied that after crossing the 520 toll and roaming Redmond for hours, they found one young man outside the Redmond library that they were able to meet with a sleeping bag and a friendly conversation. They concluded this with the statement: "And it was all worth it."
Perhaps more than any other story, this vignette captures the heart of Sleepless in Seattle. Countless hours had been poured into planning every aspect of fundraising, logistics, and direct contact work - all to bless one person with the simple gift of warmth and friendship. Call it the "Saving Private Ryan" effect or call it a miracle, but whatever "it" is, I truly believe we need more of "it" in our community.


FAQ

Do people who are homeless need sleeping bags?
Yes. The Sleepless in Seattle team has reached out to over a dozen local nonprofits who work with homeless populations to assess the need. These nonprofits have responded with an assessment of significant need with one nonprofit estimating that 80% of the homeless on the streets do not have access to sleeping bags.
"The unfortunate reality is that we do not have the capacity to house all of the homeless youth in our community. Having resources, like sleeping bags, is critical to helping them survive the night and helps us start the conversation forward to get them off the streets." -Melinda Giovengo, PhD, Executive Director of Youth Care
We need the whole community engaged to solve homelessness. The Sleepless in Seattle effort is a compassionate way for people to help others stay warm, and to raise awareness for the need for more homes for the homeless.  Mark Putnam - Executive Director of All Home King County (formerly the King County Committee to end Homelessness)

Is Sleepless in Seattle an accredited 501(c)(3) nonprofit?
Yes. The Sleepless in Seattle team has partnered with Urban Hands, an existing Seattle-based 501(c)(3) nonprofit which provides meal partnership and second chance job opportunities in the Seattle area. This unique relationship affords the Sleepless in Seattle team the advantages of legal recognition as a nonprofit while greatly reducing all administrative costs.
Can I give by check?
Yes. If you would prefer to bypass the Indiegogo fundraising tool, please mail a check to "Sleepless in Seattle - 8420 Greenwood Ave N. Seattle WA 98103" paid to the order of "Urban Hands" with memo "Sleepless in Seattle." 

Are donations tax-deductible?
Yes. Donors can expect to receive an email from payment processor FirstGiving with a tax-deductible receipt from the nonprofit Urban Hands. 
Where exactly is the money going?
The money is going directly to the purchase of sleeping bags and winter care packages. Everyone serving on this project is serving in a volunteer capacity. The minimal administrative costs to cover accounting operations are covered out-of-pocket by the Sleepless in Seattle team.
What happened to last year's sleeping bags?
1) The One Night count reported at 21% increase in homelessness in King County between 2014 and 2015 meaning many of those currently on the streets have never received a sleeping bag.
2) The homeless population tends to be very transient. A significant portion of homeless persons in King County have entered the region while others have left.
3) Many sleeping bags will not be able to last a full year when faced with the challenging conditions of everyday use on the streets. General street abrasion, water damage, and theft all contribute to challenges in long-term use. 
4) Housing a homeless person in emergency shelter often costs $20/day or more. Every option has a cost. Sleeping bags will not end homelessness, but they will help bridge the gap for those who simply need a blanket for the winter.
If sleeping bags won't last a full year, then why do the campaign at all?
Food and shelter are basic necessities that we believe every individual is entitled to. Everyday, thousands of free meals are served across King County. These meals cost money. Likewise, caring for the shelter-oriented needs of individuals costs money. As the King County's homeless shelters do not have adequate space to take in every homeless person, the Sleepless in Seattle team is committed to bridging the gap. We truly believe that $100,000 is a bargain to keep every homeless person in King County warm for the winter.

What specific sleeping bags & winter care package goods will be purchased?
The sleeping bags will be purchased in bulk from American-manufacturer Exxel Outdoors. The specific sleeping bags are mummy-style and rated to +5F. Winter care package socks, gloves, and hat will be purchased from Dollar Days. Each care package will come in a reusable drawstring cinch backpack. The $25 will cover the cost of a sleeping bag, a winter care package essentials, a draw string bag, and per-unit shipping costs. 

Is Sleepless in Seattle religiously affiliated?
Sleepless in Seattle was founded on the life example and teachings of Jesus to love others. We are committed to partnering with anyone with a desire to help others and are committed to serving every person we meet to the highest degree possible.
Why can't those who are homeless help themselves?
Homelessness is a complex issue with interrelated causes including addiction, domestic violence, mental illness, job loss and unemployment, foreclosure, relational brokenness, etc. 
No one ever got to be President of the United States or CEO of a Fortune 500 company without a little help along the way. The same is true of those who are working their way off the streets. Judgment is the duty of the courts. Compassion is the duty of everyday citizens.
Questions & Contact
To get in contact with the Sleepless in Seattle team, please email us at sleeplessinseattlegiving@gmail.com. 

Spread the Word
Here are some suggestions to rally your community:

Share the Indiegogo campaign link over social media and email. Be sure to use the #sleeplessinseattle hashtag.
Connect with Sleepless in Seattle on Facebook and Twitter.
Invite your friends to volunteer with us.

story:
We are Rainbow Refugee 

Rainbow Refugee has been supporting LGBTIQ+ people fleeing persecution because of their Sexual Orientation, Gender Identity or HIV status since 2000.

First of all we want to thank you for considering to supporting us making refugees more visible during Vancouver Pride March. 

We have less than 24h to raise more funds for our visibility campaigns, helping others who come in Canada and seek refuge as they are escaping from being prosecuted because of their sexual orientation or gender identity.

From visitor to refugee http://www.vancouversun.com/entertainment/Pride... 

The Impact

You probably want to know what difference your contribution will make:

  • Your donation is very important to our members, to us and our visibility.
  • We are organization of volunteers and every $ you donate is going to our activities to make all refugees who come to us feel safe, welcomed and part of our community.

Also, please share this link as much as you can and use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Baseball is a beautiful sport with a whole ton of flaws. We've watched a rapturous as hell postseason unfold, and yet it's continually marred by the fact that MLB - as an organization - has a lax as heck domestic violence policy. We've seen this with Osuna, Chapman, Russell, and many more - organizations prioritise the pursuit of the commisioner's trophy over the moral imperative of employing folks that *don't* beat the hell out of their partners.

Let's try to give back as best we can - any profits from this campaign will be going to the Middle Way House, a 24/7 30+2 emergency bed shelter providing resident and legal advocacy for survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault and human trafficking. More info about them can be found below.

Plus, who doesn't want noodle rat swag.

GIVE US THE GOODS, WHAT DOES THE SHIRT LOOK LIKE

Like this!

...okay, but what's with the Noodle Rat?

Damn good question. Let's try to explain.

The good folks over at Effectively Wild - arguably the best baseball podcast that exists - maintain a Facebook community for their listeners and general baseball fans. A few years back during the playoffs, a gameday thread was started, and the Noodle Rat was added as the lead image on the post. Why? Who knows. Regardless of why, we've been noodle ratting every playoff game since, and it's turned into a goofy meme for a great group of folks. What's better than turning that goofy meme into funds for a good cause? Nothin', that's what.

ABOUT MIDDLE WAY HOUSE

We’re a 24/7 30+2 emergency bed shelter providing resident and legal advocacy for survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault and human trafficking. We also run a nationally accredited daycare for children of clients, a 28 3-bedroom unit transitional housing facility for survivors where rent is based on income, a 5 days a week year round youth program that involves trauma informed mentoring and emotional development work in addition to tutoring, STEM clubs & activities, and games. We also run a program called “Building healthy relationships” that goes to area schools and teaches kids what healthy emotional boundaries look like and how to identify abusive behavior. At least several times a year students realize their household is abusive and are able to come to us for help. That program presents to thousands of students every year. We do all this with a full and part time staff of about 65 people and a rotating small army of volunteers, so every single cent helps. MWH serves all survivors regardless of orientation, gender, race, religion, etc.

We also run a 24/7 crisis line and have a service called on scene advocacy where we’ll send an advocate to meet you at the hospital or the police station for an interview/rape kit and exam, etc and will intercede on your behalf with medical staff and law enforcement if you feel overwhelmed or unable to deal with the logistical nightmare that is the reporting process.
