story:
Short Summary

Hey there! I'm Tahmyrah Lytle, a college student and dedicated, progressive grassroots activist in the Northern Iowa area! It's rough out here for Democrats (my congressman is Steve King, if that tells you anything...) so I need all the help I can get to be as effective as possible in bringing on the Blue Wave. I've already take the Wellstone Grassroots Organizer course in Minneapolis, and look forward to expanding my skill set with the Wellstone Digital Organizer course in Washington D.C. so I can be a force to be reckoned with in the field and online!

My Work:

A year and a half ago I founded a grassroots activism group called 'Where Do We Go From Here?' that has since provided a place of discussion for my fellow politicos and activists, as well as a source of inspiration for those that felt disenfranchised and hopeless after that fateful election in 2016. We've hosted candidate forums, protests and rallies, festivals, fundraisers, town halls, etc., to promote informed voting, as well as uplift issues that affect everyday Iowans. I am also on the executive committee for my local Democratic party and the Iowa Democratic Wing Ding, where I work as their social media/graphic design person and event coordinator. I also work part-time as a field organizer for 4th district congressional candidate J.D. Scholten, who is working to unseat Steve King!

In My Community:

I believe that it isn't enough to just be politically involved; you have to give back to your community!I just recently joined the North Iowa Farmer's Market board, with the hopes of contributing to the healthy living movement here in Mason City. My partner and I have a community garden plot with the hopes of providing for ourselves, as well as selling produce and plants at our farmer's market. I also volunteer for Mason City Pride Fest, and intend to be a vendor this year. I'll be selling buttons (I make them myself!) and patches with the intention of donating 40% of sales to MC Pride to keep it going! My day job is with First Congregational United Church of Christ, which is one of two Open and Affirming churches in town and home to Transcend's support group and Trans Clothing Closet, as well as a market-to-street food trailer, mindfulness and meditation classes, and my grassroots group! 

What I Need:

This crowd-fundraiser is intended to help me get to Washington D.C. to gain more knowledge of the grand world of political organizing! Every dollar contributed goes towards supporting me in my efforts to be the most effective community activist I can be to unseat politicians like Steve King, as well as promote progressive values and uplift Iowans that have been trampled on by special interests during this administration.

***EDIT***: Due to the kindness of those in my community, I have found supporter housing for my trip to D.C., and have successfully fundraised $475 offline! This has allowed me to purchase my plane ticket, and has saved me hundreds of dollars for lodging. For this reason, I have lowered the amount needed to $500, to cover the costs of food and transportation for the 7 days that I will be out there. I've already been accepted on full scholarship into the program, so those two things are my only costs. If you support me, you'll be contributing to the grassroots movement starting here in Mason City, Iowa. I plan to continue working towards the goal of advancing progressive values, and need your help! Steve King won't unseat himself!

story:
If you're reading this, hi! 


The Together Project is a fundraiser created by 10 young artists, wanting to support migrant workers in Singapore.


What's Going On with Migrant Workers?

Migrant workers often endure long hours doing heavy, high-risk manual labour for unfairly low wages, while having to live in improperly-maintained, overcrowded dorms, miles away from family. Living in conditions like these leaves them vulnerable to illness, financial issues, as well as extreme emotional distress. 


In fact, the poor standard of living has heavily contributed to the disproportionately high number of Covid-19 cases amongst migrant workers in Singapore, with cramped dorms allowing for the virus to spread easily. To make things worse, many cannot afford to pay for medical treatments and housing improvements by themselves because they aren't even paid on time, or even enough. 


So we've decided to help them out and raise some money! 


Why Your Donation Matters

Donating is also an important symbol of recognition of how their hard work plays a significant role helping our society grow. Migrant workers are human too, and they deserve to live in more humane living conditions. 


If you donate a minimum of SGD$15.00, you'll get one pack of 10 cute construction animal stickers, which we will send via postal mail! 


If you can't afford to donate that much, we'd still be really thankful for a smaller donation. It's the thought that counts, and we still acknowledge and deeply appreciate your intention to help. You can also share our campaign to spread awareness, which helps too! 


All profits will go to TWC2 (Transient Workers Count Too), an organization which helps migrant workers in need. Details about the organization are on their website so you know exactly how your donation will be put to good use. Here's a link to their site: https://twc2.org.sg/ 


Sticker Art Lineup



 


 


 

All sticker sets will be sent out after the funding period!
We do hope you join us in our efforts to make the world a little brighter through art!
story_txt:
If you're reading this, hi! The Together Project is a fundraiser created by 10 young artists, wanting to support migrant workers in Singapore.What's Going On with Migrant Workers?Migrant workers often endure long hours doing heavy, high-risk manual labour for unfairly low wages, while having to live in improperly-maintained, overcrowded dorms, miles away from family. Living in conditions like these leaves them vulnerable to illness, financial issues, as well as extreme emotional distress. In fact, the poor standard of living has heavily contributed to the disproportionately high number of Covid-19 cases amongst migrant workers in Singapore, with cramped dorms allowing for the virus to spread easily. To make things worse, many cannot afford to pay for medical treatments and housing improvements by themselves because they aren't even paid on time, or even enough. So we've decided to help them out and raise some money! Why Your Donation MattersDonating is also an important symbol of recognition of how their hard work plays a significant role helping our society grow. Migrant workers are human too, and they deserve to live in more humane living conditions. If you donate a minimum of SGD$15.00, you'll get one pack of 10 cute construction animal stickers, which we will send via postal mail! If you can't afford to donate that much, we'd still be really thankful for a smaller donation. It's the thought that counts, and we still acknowledge and deeply appreciate your intention to help. You can also share our campaign to spread awareness, which helps too! All profits will go to TWC2 (Transient Workers Count Too), an organization which helps migrant workers in need. Details about the organization are on their website so you know exactly how your donation will be put to good use. Here's a link to their site: https://twc2.org.sg/ Sticker Art Lineup
 
 
 

All sticker sets will be sent out after the funding period!We do hope you join us in our efforts to make the world a little brighter through art!

story:
Justice Hunt. Running towards Greatness. 

Justice Hunt is a young man that has overcome many obstacles in his young life. He has overcome his mom's unfortunate addiction, homelessness and unspeakable instability. Thanks to his sister and a few other loving saints and prayer warriors, Justice has stood strong in the storm and has seen his mom recover and become his rock of love and support. Glory be to God, Justice is now in his first stable permanent home in three years. 

Justice has also achieved Greatness while "riding thru the storm". He graduated from Malcolm X Shabazz High School in June, has won many track medals each year, and was so outstanding he was invited to the Down Under International Track and Field Games taking place in Australia.

The costs for his trip was $5000 dollars. Rather than allow Justice to miss this once in a lifetime opportunity, his mom began the "Running for Justice Fundraiser. At the recent inauguration of Newark Mayor Ras Baraka many notable community leaders heard Justice's story and have stepped up to raise $3500 of the fees but Justice needs our help to finish his race.

Let's rally around this awesome young man who is out running the negative statistics and becoming a Superstar in Our Community. We can do this! We must do this for Justice. Your generous support is deeply appreciated. Bese Saka. Thank You.

 

BESE SAKA

"Sack of Cola Nuts"

Akkan symbol of Affluence, Power, Abundance, Plenty, Togetherness and Unity.

The Cola Nut played an important role in the economic life of Ghana. A widely-used cash crop, it is closely associated with Affluence and Abundance. 

Kingdom Capital, LLC believes in the principles of BESE SAKA as a means of "Building Generational Wealth" in our communities.  We thank you for your generous support and welcome your participation. BESE SAKA!

story:
Camp KC

Camp KC is a free week long summer camp for children infected and/or affected by HIV provided by Cascade AIDS Project to provide a fun, safe, stigma-free space for kids to play, learn, and build relationships that support them throughout the year. 

At Camp KC, kids ages 5-15 spend the week swimming, at arts & crafts, dance classes, on nature hikes, ropes courses, and many other creative opportunities that educate, build confidence, and give them time to just be kids. Our campers have 24 access to medical attention at Club M.D., and we send all of our campers home with supplies they can use throughout the year, like school supplies and cold weather clothes.  

                                             

What We Need

Camp KC is free for all children impacted by HIV, and funded entirely through donations and small grants.

  • We need your help to pay for the campground facility rental fee. The campground is on the Oregon coast and has cabins, a ropes course, a pool, a lake, and many other wonderful amenities that keep our campers safe and happy, but we need to raise $5,000 more to be able to cover the cost. With your help we can surpass this goal, and any additional money we raise will help pay for all the supplies we need to make camp a success, like stocking Club M.D., where our campers have 24 hour access to medical attention, arts & crafts, and transportation for the campers. 

The Impact

Your support will give a stigma-free week to amazing kids where they can have a safe space to learn, be themselves, make friends, and most importantly just be kids. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Get the word out to your networks by sharing this page on your social media or by sending out an email to friends and family.
    • Check out the Indiegogo share tools on this page - Sharing a good cause with your networks has never been easier!

story:
Hello Indiegogoers! My name is Josh Kirby and I'm here to ask for your help. As you know with the current state of the economy, everyone is cutting corners. Some of us may be going out less or being more frugile at the grocery store. Others may be eating one less meal a day, or not paying the rent to feed themselves or their family. This shouldn't be happening. 

The homeless population here in miami is unbeleivable. We have people sleeping on public benchs, eating out of trash cans, and stealing just to keep themselves alive. I want to put a stop to this! The treasure Trove boutique is my answer.

The Treasure Trove Boutique is going to be a high-end consignment store carrying many of the top designer items. Say you have a pair of shoes or a shirt that have been sitting in your closet for months getting eaten by moths or collecting dust. Bring these items that you no longer need to the Treasure Trove and we will sell them for you! Once the item sells the profit will be devided 60/40. 

With the majority of the profit that we receive we will fight to end Homelessness in Miami and eventually all over the United States. It all starts with you!

The profit will be divided into 3 major categories; Food, travel, and clothing. I have teamed up with Publix supermarket to give out food vouchers to the homeless. Also, I have contacted the Miami Dade transit to provide discounted bus passes that I will be able to distribute to the homeless here in the city. The Treasure Trove will also accept donations that we can use to clothe people who may not be able to afford the outfit needed to go to an interview. 

My intent is to have a successful business that allows me to form a network with the local VA of Miami, that can help veterans get to appointments, assistance of any kind that also helps them to be self reliant, all without losing what is left of their dignity.

 

What we need

My goal is to raise $6,000 with your help. I plan to use this site as well as fundraise in the community. The $6,000 will be used for:
  • $650/month rent in a high foot and car traffic area (First, Second, Last, and Deposit) =$2,600
  • Permits, business license, water, electricity, and internet = $1,000
  • Advertisement and signage = $1,000
  • Furniture, racks, hangers, and cash register = $1,000
  • Miscellaneous items including pens, paper, bathroom items, price tag, pricing gun, etc. = $400

Total = $6,000

If the $6,000 goal is not reached all of the money raised will be donated to the Camilas homeless shelter + everything over the goal if it is reached. Also, %1  of the goal will be donated to the wonderful Camillus house for all of the help and support they have given to us.

 

The Impact

This project will benefit three groups of people. The seller, buyer, and the family sleeping under the bridge. The seller will be able to sell their gently used clothing without doing hardly any work. The buyer will be able to get very nice clothing at far less than retail value. Lastly, the homeless family will be able to have a couple healthy meals, enouragement to find a job with their new clothes and a way to get there. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

 

Please donate if you are financially able. This week I sat on the corner holding a sign, NOBODY donated a dollar. Now is your chance to do something good. Even if it's only a dollar or two, every cent counts. Be the change you want to see in the world. 

Also, Please share us on every socal media site that you have (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Myspace) and tell all of your friends and family!

*Update* We have also paired with Camillus House. They are so graciously going to help us raise funds as we are giving them %1 of our goal when fully funded. Thank you Camillus House for your generosity!

 

*Update* ‎Shannon Petrucci, an independent sales consultant, and a total stranger until today, has offered to donate 15% of sales of Scentsy products from this link, clicking on the Treasure Trove campaign from her page. These make great gifts people, not to mention make ur house smell great. Please, check her out as she is helping us out! Thanks for all the love!

- Thanks for your support!

story:
Thank you to all those who have made this fundraiser a success! If you're still interested in purchasing shirts and merchandise (in very limited quantities/sizes), email feministcomingoutday@gmail.com for more information on our remaining stock. If you represent an organization or student club, we do offer bulk discounts and are keeping a waiting list for group orders.

We are OUT of XS, XL, & XXL shirts. Read the t-shirt FAQs on sizing measurements (below) before ordering.  IndieGoGo does not allow size selection, so do not forget to email feministcomingoutday@gmail.com immediately after you make your contribution to reserve your size (SM-LG).

Our Story

When a queer student group and a feminist club teamed up at Harvard University to raise awareness about gender equality, the resulting 2010 campaign, Feminist Coming Out Day, brought together not only the two organizations, but also the campus community. Inspired by National Coming Out Day, a holiday which encourages awareness of issues affecting the queer community, our event was an opportunity for alliance, collaboration, bridge-building, and inclusion. This school year, we want to expand the Feminist Coming Out Day to high schools and colleges throughout the United States, so we're partnering with Bitch Magazine and taking the campaign online!


Last year at Harvard, we put a face to feminism by donning buttons and t-shirts that said "This Is What A Feminist Looks Like" and holding a photo exhibit called the Feminist Portrait Project. Now we're making this merchandise available to feminist and LGBT student organizations across the country, so that they can plan events like this on their own campuses. Bitch Media is helping us get the word out, and all the profits for this merchandise will help fund feminist media. Even if you’re not in school, you can still participate. Put a "This Is What A Feminist Looks Like" sticker on your laptop, snap a photo of yourself in our t-shirt, send in your feminist manifesto as a submission to our online Feminist Portrait Project, and tell your friends and colleagues about our campaign to show the diversity among supporters of gender equality.


The Impact

From now until the end of March, we'll be featuring "portraits" of participants on our website, as well as photos from student-run Feminist Coming Out Day celebrations. Individual sales make it possible for us to offer merchandise at discounted rates to student and non-profit organizations.

All proceeds of this campaign go to fund our charitable partner, Bitch Media, the nonprofit organization that publishes "Bitch: Feminist Response to Pop Culture", a magazine which has subscribers in 46 countries and all 50 states. They'll be rewarding our biggest donors with subscriptions as well as shout-outs on their website. So help us publicize this effort on Twitter, Facebook, and your blog, and start snapping photos to start your own Feminist Portrait Project. Check out our official website for supporters participating from around the world and for updates on the Feminist Coming Out Day events taking place on different campuses.

What We Need & What You Get

In exchange for your contribution, you'll get a sweet set of gear to don on March 8th and a post-event rundown from other folks doing the same from across the country. Have a group of feminist friends or want to hold your own event? Go big with your contribution and get a bulk set of merchandise at a discounted rate for groups. But whether you only have a few bucks of your own or several hundred in grant money for a rally, anything you contribute will help us coordinate a national campaign that hopes to represent the full spectrum of feminist identities. Even if you can't afford to donate, you can still participate for free and get your voice heard on our website. Send in your story, thoughts, and opinions about gender equality  to our site to be included in our online Feminist Portrait Project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Get some of your friends together for a bulk order or organize an exhibit on March 8th with a student group on campus. Are you interested in raising money for your club or cause with your own Feminist Portrait Project or t-shirt sale? Contact Lena at lena [at] lenachen [dot] com to find out how we organized this campaign!

T-Shirt & Merchandise FAQs

1. What does the design for this year's merchandise look like?


Check out the image above. For an enlarged version, click here.


2. How does the sizing work? Can guys wear these shirts?

Anyone can wear them, since they're not made specifically with women in mind! Remember to size up since these are fitted tees that are not as large as your traditional loose-fit unisex t-shirts. If you prefer a loose fit, add two sizes to your normal size. ("Fitted" means that the shirts are made of stretchier material.) Shirts are available in XS, SM, MED, LG, XL, XXL on a first-come, first-served basis. We are out of XS and XL shirts. A measurement guide:


SMALL | Widest point (bottom of waist): 16 inches across | Narrowest point (center): 14 inches across
MEDIUM | Widest point (bottom of waist): 17 inches across | Narrowest point (center): 14.5 inches across
LARGE | Widest point (bottom of waist): 19 inches across | Narrowest point (center): 15 inches across
XLARGE | Widest point (bottom of waist): 19.5 inches across | Narrowest point (center): 16 inches across


3. How many shirts are available?

We've made a limited run of 1,000 tees for 2011. Reserve your shirt by pledging a minimum $20 contribution and by emailing feministcomingoutday@gmail.com with your name, t-shirt size, and address (if it is a different shipping address than the one entered in IndieGoGo). If you are ordering as a group, please send all sizing information (as well requests for extra buttons and stickers) under one email, and specify an address where the bulk shipment can be received. If you live outside of the U.S., please contact us before making a contribution for international shipping rates.


4. Why does the shirt cost $20?

We wanted to make something that could last you year after year for many Feminist Coming Out Days to come. The "This Is What A Feminist Looks Like" Shirt is a V-neck collar fitted, sheer jersey cotton tee that was made in America by Royal Apparel and printed in Wisconsin with a custom design in a 2-color water-based ink. The price of your tee ($15 for groups, $20 for individuals) pays for the material, custom screen-printing, and shipping/handling charges, and allows for a contribution to Bitch Magazine.


5. Will you be printing more shirts after you sell out all 1,000 tees?

Because of the huge upfront cost, we can't guarantee that we'll be printing more tees once we sell out, nor can we guarantee what the quality or price of any future merchandise will be. Groups should notify us of potential bulk orders and desired sizes as early as possible (even if you have not yet finalized a donation), so that we can reserve enough merchandise.


6. Why should I order with a group?

Individuals pay $20 per tee, but groups get discounted rates. (Tees are $18/ea for five, $17.50/ea for 10, and $15/ea for 20+). A student club or organization ordering 20 or more shirts can also enjoy a complimentary subscription to Bitch Magazine. Plus, it's more fun to wear your Feminist Coming Out Day gear together!


7. When can I expect to receive my shirt?

Because Feminist Coming Out Day is March 8th, we'll be sending out stickers, buttons, and tees to our first round of donors in mid-February and shipping to early contributors first. We advise student groups holding events to place final orders by February 20th and to notify us of intent to order ASAP. After the event, we'll be taking orders for remaining t-shirts until March 31st or until they run out.


8. What should I do when I receive my package of "This Is What A Feminist Looks Like" gear?

Take a photo or make a video of yourself wearing it and add it to our Feminist Portrait Project, along with your feminist manifesto! Put it on your Facebook profile or share it with your Twitter followers. Give your button to a sibling. Tell your friends about our website. The possibilities are endless!


9. What if I want extra stickers or buttons?

For every dollar you donate that exceeds the minimum contribution for a "perk" level, you can receive your choice of a button or a sticker. (For example, if you donate $21, you can receive a shirt, a button, a sticker, AND either an extra button or sticker.) Please indicate your preference in your email to feministcomingoutday@gmail.com. (Due to shipping costs,  we can only provide extra merchandise to those who pledge at least $5.) Are you a campus group or an organization? We offer stickers and buttons at significantly reduced bulk rates if they are used for a public event or as part of a Feminist Coming Out Day celebration. Please contact us for more details.


10. What if I want to order shirts in X quantity?

If you're ordering 5-9 tees, add $18 to your minimum contribution ($90) for each additional shirt. If you're ordering 10-19 tees, add $17.50 to your minimum contribution ($175) for each additional shirt. If you're ordering 20+ tees, add $15 to your minimum contribution for each additional shirt. We are not able to offer price breaks for smaller orders.


Other questions? Contact us at feministcomingoutday@gmail.com!


Lena Chen
Women’s Events & Outreach Chair Emerita
Harvard College Queer Students & Allies

Abby Sun
Co-President
Harvard College Radcliffe Union of Students

LARGE | Widest point (bottom of waist): 19 inches across | Narrowest point (center): 15 inches across

XLARGE | Widest point (bottom of waist): 19.5 inches across | Narrowest point (center): 16 inches across


3. How many shirts are available?
We've made a limited run of 1,000 tees for 2011. Reserve your shirt by pledging a minimum $20 contribution and by emailing feministcomingoutday@gmail.com with your name, t-shirt size, and address (if it is a different shipping address than the one entered in IndieGoGo). If you are ordering as a group, please send all sizing information (as well requests for extra buttons and stickers) under one email, and specify an address where the bulk shipment can be received. If you live outside of the U.S., please contact us before making a contribution for international shipping rates.

4. Why does the shirt cost $20?


We wanted to make something that could last you 
year after year for many Feminist Coming Out Days to come. The "This Is 
What A 
Feminist Looks Like" Shirt is a V-neck collar fitted, sheer jersey 
cotton tee that was made in America by Royal Apparel and printed in 
Wisconsin with a custom design in a 2-color
 water-based ink. The price of your tee ($15 for groups, $20 for 
individuals) pays for the material, custom screen-printing, and 
shipping/handling charges, and allows for a contribution to Bitch Magazine.

5. Will you be printing more shirts after you sell out all 1,000 tees?
Because of the huge upfront cost, we can't guarantee that we'll be printing more tees once we sell out, nor can we guarantee what the quality or price of any future merchandise will be. Groups should notify us of potential bulk orders and desired sizes as early as possible (even if you have not yet finalized a donation), so that we can reserve enough merchandise. 

6. Why should I order with a group?
Individuals pay $20 per tee, but groups get discounted rates. (Tees are $18/ea for five, $17.50/ea for 10, and $15/ea for 20+). A student club or organization ordering 20 or more shirts can also enjoy a complimentary subscription to Bitch Magazine. Plus, it's more fun to wear your Feminist Coming Out Day gear together!

7. When can I expect to receive my shirt?
Because Feminist Coming Out Day is March 8th, we'll be sending out stickers, buttons, and tees to our first round of donors in mid-February and shipping to early contributors first. We advise student groups holding events to place final orders by February 20th and to notify us of intent to order ASAP. After the event, we'll be taking orders for remaining t-shirts until March 31st or until they run out.

8. What should I do when I receive my package of "This Is What A Feminist Looks Like" gear?
Take a photo or make a video of yourself wearing it and add it to our Feminist Portrait Project, along with your feminist manifesto! Put it on your Facebook profile or share it with your Twitter followers. Give your button to a sibling. Tell your friends about our website. The possibilities are endless!

9. What if I want extra stickers or buttons?
For every dollar you donate that exceeds the minimum contribution for a "perk" level, you can receive your choice of a button or a sticker. (For example, if you donate $21, you can receive a shirt, a button, a sticker, AND either an extra button or sticker.) Please indicate your preference in your email to feministcomingoutday@gmail.com. (Due to shipping costs,  we can only provide extra merchandise to those who pledge at least $5.) Are you a campus group or an organization? We offer stickers and buttons at significantly reduced bulk rates if they are used for a public event or as part of a Feminist Coming Out Day celebration. Please contact us for more details.

10. What if I want to order shirts in X quantity?
If you're ordering 5-9 tees, add $18 to your minimum contribution ($90) for each additional shirt. If you're ordering 10-19 tees, add $17.50 to your minimum contribution ($175) for each additional shirt. If you're ordering 20+ tees, add $15 to your minimum contribution for each additional shirt. We are not able to offer price breaks for smaller orders.

Other questions? Contact us at feministcomingoutday@gmail.com!

Lena ChenWomen’s Events & Outreach Chair EmeritaHarvard College Queer Students & Allies
Abby SunCo-PresidentHarvard College Radcliffe Union of Students

story:
Summary

San Diego Mayor Kevin Faulconer has proclaimed June 26th 2014 as Marriage Equality Day in San Diego, as a way to commemorate the Proposition 8 and DOMA rulings at the United States Supreme Court.  We are raising $2500 to manufacture the Marriage Equality Flag for the celebration in San Diego.

The Marriage Equality Flag is believed to be one of the first flags created for the marriage equality cause and is just one of two flags that was recognized in 2008 by the North American Vexillological Association (NAVA).  

This flag is a re-designed version from one originally created in 2002 by Eddie Reynoso and Nick Profaizer to protest Nevada's Question 2.   In March of 2004 it was altered when it became apparent that marriage equality rights would need to be won on a state-by-state basis.  

The United States Marriage Equality Flag is similar to a flag created by Alice Paul during the Women's Suffrage Movement, in which women were granted the right to vote on a state by state basis.  As the 19th amendment made its way through the approval process the ladies sewed a star on their flag each time another state ratified it.   Similarly to the Womens Suffrage Flag, when a new state grants its citizens marriage equality protections-  a pink start will be sewn onto the Marriage Equality Flag. 

Funds from this project will be used to manufacture a 12 ft by 18 ft flag.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $2,500.   By helping us raise the money to produce the flag, you get an opportunity to raise the flag in San Diego!

$1500.00 will be used for the creation of the flag and it's additional 50 pink stars.  The Flag will be made by Sunward Flags a local San Diego flag producer, that manufactures the current Hillcrest Pride Flag.

$500.00 will be used for development (Website, Graphics)

$500.00 will be used for legal (paying our copywriter, patents and fundraising fees).

Additional funds raised over our goal will be used to create small versions of the flag that will be made available for purchase in 2014.   100% of the profits of those funds will be donated to the maintenance and upkeep of the Hillcrest Pride Flag.

The Impact

San Diego Mayor Kevin Faulconer has proclaimed June 26th 2014 as Marriage Equality Day in San Diego.  His staff will be on hand to assist with the flag raising as we mark the one year anniversary of the DOMA and Prop 8 United States Supreme Court rulings.

The raising of the Marriage Equality Flag will mark the first time any city has flown the symbol of the marriage equality struggle in the United States.  It will serve as a powerful reminder that although slow, the march towards equal rights for the LGBT community continues to make important gains -- even if we must do so on a state-by-state basis.

https://www.facebook.com/events/674803922592808/

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help.

    Help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign:  Share it on your Facebook walls, Tweet it and if you know any LGBT publications- ask them to write a story about it!

    Visit and SHARE our Facebook page: www.facebook.com/MarriageEqualityFlag

    Visit and SHARE our website: www.PrideConstellation.com

story:
We need your help today to support survivors of Human Trafficking!  No one is immune: the person who is advertised on the street or on the internet could be your mother, daughter, sister, niece or granddaughter. 

Human sex and labor trafficking is a serious and very present problem in the San Francisco Bay Area. In 2013 alone, the National Human Trafficking Hotline received over 3,000 calls, 105 emails, 74 SMS threads (launched in 3/28/2014) and 184 online tips from the State of California.

The SAGE Project provides trauma-informed, integrative healing services and support to adult and youth victims of human trafficking (including labor and sex trafficking). SAGE works to educate the community and increase awareness by provide free trainings to build capacity and bring essential services needed in our community.

SAGE’s Anti-Human Trafficking staff members participate in the San Francisco Collaborative Against Human Trafficking (SFCAHT) and are represented on the National Human Trafficking Resource Center’s Outreach Advisory Board. 

SAGE supports survivors of Human Trafficking in accessing housing, food, clothing, family support, legal advice, and immigration assistance. We work with qualified survivors of Human Trafficking to obtain T- visas and financial assistance through our partnerships with the National Human Trafficking Victim Assistance Program and the United States Committee in Immigrant and Refugee (USCRI).

Every dollar helps!  Your gift will go a long way to make a difference in the life of an individual survivor:

  • Your gift of $50 will provide clothes, hygiene products and personal items survivor of Human Trafficking.

  • Your gift of $100 will provide groceries and household items for a survivor of Human Trafficking

  • Your gift of $250 will provide phone cards for one month so a survivor of Human Trafficking will be able to communicate with and receive support from friends and family far away.

  • Your gift of $500 will provide rent for one month so a survivor of Human Trafficking will have a safe and dignified place to live while rebuilding their life.

Each survivor served by SAGE is a unique individual with unique needs.  Rather than through a “cookie cutter” or one-size-fits-all approach, SAGE works to provide and build a seamless web of services for our clients. 

o  “SAGE has been a life-saving, transformative place that helped me get beyond ‘victim’ to be a powerful survivor with hope for the future." -- Anonymous survivor of domestic human trafficking

o  “When we met our case managers from SAGE it felt like we were stranded in the middle of the ocean and they were the ship that came to rescue us.”  --Anonymous survivor of intenational human trafficking

In the face of the changing economy of San Francisco, many small non-profits have been forced to close their doors.  As an organization created by and for survivors, SAGE remains committed to continuing to provide much needed services to our clients in San Francisco and throughout the Bay Area.

For addtional information on Human Trafficking, please see the resources listed below.


[1] South Bay Coalition to End Human Trafficking website www.sbcteht.com

[2] http://www.justice.gov/oig/reports/FBI/a0908/chapter4.htm

story:
Alzando la voz en Washington! 

La Comisión Interamericana de Derechos Humanos (CIDH), un organismo internacional que revisa las situaciones de derechos humanos y recibe denuncias sobre graves violaciones de los derechos básicos en el continente, realizará una audiencia sobre la situación de Puerto Rico después del paso del huracán María.

La audiencia se llevará a cabo el 7 de diciembre (se puede ver en vivo en su sitio web en http://www.oas.org/en/iachr/) a las 8:30 a.m.. Sin embargo, necesitamos apoyo para ayudar a que lideresas comunitarias de los pueblos de Loíza y Peñuelas lleguen a Washington a testificar directamente ante la Comisión. Tu contribución es esencial para hacer posible este viaje para dos mujeres lideresas. Necesitamos recaudar fondos suficientes para cubrir los costos del viaje a Washington y asegurar que este organismo pueda escucharlas directamente a ellas y a las comunidades que ellas representan. Estas y otras comunidades en Puerto Rico, continúan siendo extremadamente vulnerables, sufriendo las consecuencias, no solo del  desastre ambiental, sino del desastre y la violencia facilitada por el estado y la falta de servicios públicos adecuados.

Es importante que la gente pueda hablar por sí misma y contar su propia historia. Además de la audiencia ante la CIDH, estas lideresas comunitarias y defensoras de derechos humanos también se reunirán con varios grupos y oficinas de funcionarios electos en Washington para hablarles directamente de sus necesidades y demandas de acción.

¡Ayúdanos a llevar a estas líderes de la comunidad puertorriqueña a Washington y alzar sus voces!

Raising our voice in Washington!

For the third year in a row, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR), an international body that reviews human rights situations and hears complaints about violations of basic rights across the Americas, will hold a hearing on the current situation of human rights in Puerto Rico after the passage of Hurricane Maria. 

The hearing will be held on December 7 (and can be viewed live on their website at http://www.oas.org/en/iachr/) at 8:30 a.m.. However we need support to help bring community leaders from the communities of Loiza and Peñuelas to testify directly before the Commision. That's where your contribution comes in. We need to fundraise to cover their travel to Washington so that this body can hear directly from them and the communities they represent, which continue to be extremely vulnerable communities that have suffered not only from this disaster but from state facilitated violence and lack of adequate public services. 

It is important that people be allowed to speak for themselves and tell their own story.  In addition to the hearing before the IACHR, these community leaders and advocates from the island will also be meeting with various groups and elected officials' offices in Washington to directly discuss their needs and demands for assistance. 

Help us bring Puerto Rican community leaders to Washington and lift their voices up!

story:
RICOCHET: A film about one of the most celebrated trials of our time, and the international debate over immigration policy in the U.S.

Hi. I'm Jeff Adachi, the writer and producer of two award winning PBS feature documentary films  asking for your help to raise funds to complete the film.

RICOCHET is a feature length film about the tragic death of Kate Steinle. Kate was walking on Pier 14 in San Francisco with her father when a shot rang out. Seconds later, she was dead. An undocumented immigrant, Jose Garcia Zarate, was arrested and accused of murder. Within hours, then candidate Donald Trump used the case to justify his immigration policies, stating that the death of Steinle was caused by San Francisco's sanctuary city policies.  The trial of the case was one of the most watched and commented on trials of decade .

Matt Gonzalez, Chief Attorney of the San Francisco Public Defender's Office, is assigned the case and develops the evidence through a fascinating analysis of video evidence, forensic science and witnesses, including Garcia-Zarate.   Gonzalez is assisted by Francisco Ugarte, who heads the office's immigration unit, and the defense team.

The film is directed by Jeff Adachi, who has made several award winning films including "The Slanted Screen" and "You Don't Know Jack Soo," and edited by Emmy nominated Chihiro Wimbush ("Dogtown Redemption"). 

SFWeekly /Emily Wilson / Mon Apr 10th, 2017 

How You Can Help Me

I believe in this project and made a feature film that addresses the critical issues of our time, but I need your help. I need to raise $20,000 to complete editing the film. 

Please donate whatever you can to support our film and help make this film possible! Thank you!

story:
Hello, we are David, Daniel, and Patrick Nelson, founders of i'mME. The three of us went on our first international mission trip together as brothers in July 2012 with Coreluv International. The trip proved to be a pivotal turning point in each of our lives, and we were enthused with passion to end the vicious epidemic we call the orphan cycle in Haiti. Before the trip the three of us weren't close, but we experienced the congruent power of God's love and passion each day that brought us closer than ever. We were being confronted with our true identities both individually and collectively as brothers. We were being invited to embrace the purpose that was originally intended for us from the beginning. Each day we spent with the orphans in Haiti, our hearts grew closer to the reality of our purpose and destiny. How could we say no? Four months later we decided to launch this organization with a mission to shelter, love, feed, care, and empower the orphans of Haiti to find their identity and purpose just as we did.

This campaign is very significant to us, because the funds we raise will allow us to cement our presence on Haitian soil. Up to this point we have relied upon other organizations to house and transport us to the places we need to go. Because of this, we haven't been able to travel to Haiti as often as we would like.

The concept of a traditional orphanage institution will not be cultivated through the efforts of i'mME, rather the implementation of cottages that portray the heartbeat and atmosphere of family. Our vision is to have 7-8 orphans and a housemother in each cottage. The housemother will fulfilling the role of a mother by catering to their every need and showering them with love. Each day the children come home from school, they will feel like they are home and belong to a family. 

In order to effectively begin our work in Haiti, we must have a place of residence. We cannot purchase land, attain legal guardianship over children, or assemble a Haitian staff without Haitian residency. Once we have a place in Haiti to operateout of, we will be able to acquire a Haitian residency and take the next step in what God has in store for us.

With the ability to travel and stay in Haiti as much as needed, we will need to have our own source of transportation. Renting a car in Haiti is extremely expensive, and borrowing vehicles is a hassle. With Haitian Residency, we will be able to buy our own car. Having a house and car in Haiti will give us the ability to put God's vision for us into action.

There is so much need in Haiti, and every little bit goes a long way.

To provide a financial breakdown for you: $17,000 will provide 12 months of rent and utilities; $23,000 will allow us to purchase a vehicle for transportation; $5,000 to furnish the house; $5,000 for hiring translators and Haitian staff.

David has been blessed with the opportunity to play professional football, and the platform that comes with it. However, the vision will not become a reality without the help of people like you. Together we can do significantly more than we can individually. Join us in our efforts and pledge a dollar amount to defend the cause of the orphan.

If you aren't able to contribute financially there are other ways you can help. Share this link on your social media platforms or email blasts, and tell your friends and family about it. We take great pleasure in hearing about how people take ownership in the efforts of i'mME. We want you to call this "MY MISSION."

David, Daniel, and Patrick (Founders of i'mME)

We take great pleasure in hearing about how people take ownership in the efforts of i'mME. We want you to call this "MY MISSION."
David, Daniel, and Patrick (Founders of i'mME)

story:
Our Story

We are out to make a real impact on peace for the planet.

We believe that the ‘Alliance for Peace Building’, as an organization can have one of the biggest impacts on peace. The Alliance (an Umbrella entity for international peace-building organizations around the world) works with over 70 companies worldwide and not only raises funds for communities, they provide organizations with education, they connect policy makers with advocacy groups and strive to create peace before atrocities actually occur.

We are raising funds to create an impactful short film featuring celebrities and their children reciting the poem - THE TIGER AND THE DRAGON to raise awareness for peace and funds for the Alliance for Peace Building. 

The Tiger and Dragon is the playful story of 2 strong characters who discover the possibility of forgiveness and peace when they push their fear of each other aside. Animation and music will be used to illustrate the colorful story, appealing to both adults and kids.

The Impact 

Ultimately our team hopes not only to raise funds and awareness for the Alliance for Peace building but also to inform people about the many organizations actively promoting peace around the world. The short film will be made available to global peace organizations to promote their individual peace efforts.

Please contribute to make this project a reality. We believe that one by one, we can make a difference and cause a shift for peace on the planet.

For more information visit www.tigeranddragonthepsa.com

What We Need & What You Get

We need to generate $5000 to bring the fully formed live action and animated short  video to life. Money raised will go towards lighting, animation, green screen, studio time and other services.

See our list of perks for different contribution levels!

story:
Illegal Detention

Every year in the UK 30,000 migrants and refugees are held in a prison-like environment without a trial. The majority are seeking asylum who fear persecution in their home country, often victims of human trafficking or fleeing persecution, torture and sexual violence. 

Why are these people in detention? The Home Office decides to deprive these people of their liberty while they process their cases. Yet there is no limit on how long the government can hold them in immigration detention. Migrants lose months and even years of their life held in detention centres. 

The only way to get released is to mount a legal challenge, which can be complicated. These people need a laywer, but many are destitute and cannot afford legal fees. Also, in 2014 the government cut legal aid making it access to justice more difficult. Approximately 40% of detainees do not have representation. 

What We Do

We are the Habeas Corpus Project, a non-profit organisation devoted to challenging unlawful detention of migrants and refugees in the UK.  We provide legal representation for free and have already enjoyed several successes.

                                          

We are defending the liberty, the rule of law and the values set down in Magna Carta  800 years ago which states that no freeperson shall be detained without trial. The UK is the only western European country to practice indefinite detention of migrants. Our current government practice needs to be challenged.

Here is a picture of our team at our office in London:

 Our Charity registration number in the UK is 1159689 and ourwebsite for further information is http://www.habeas-corpus.org.uk. Please call us on +44(0)207 112 5370 if you would like to discuss our work before donating.

How You Can Help

We are looking for £10,000 to cover our core costs such as rent and office supplies throughout 2016. We are also looking to open a weekly legal clinic at Yarl's Wood IRC, a women's only removal centre recently described as a "cause for national concern". your contribution will make a huge contribution to these vulnerable people's lives.

Thank you for your support. Please share our campaign with your friends and family and bring justice for migrants and refugees.

Perks

To thank you for your donations, we have a variety of gifts including fridge magnets, mugs and posters to show our appreciation. Here is what our mugs look like:



and here is what our posters look like:

story:
Who We Are

Focusing on repair rather than punishment, our mission is to create a cultural, heart-led shift in the ways we respond to sexual violence.

I am Marlee, the founder of this movement and the human featured in the video above! If you watched, you know that my sexual assault case concluded with a powerful restorative justice process in 2019. The man who raped me went through extensive therapy before we met in a mediation circle, focused on accountability, transformation and closure.  After experiencing more healing through this process than I even knew I needed... I am advocating for a world in which restorative justice is an accessible and well-known option following sexual assault. 

 

What We Do

We provide education on the power of restorative justice to centralize accountability, rehabilitation, transformation, and the voices of survivors. We raise awareness and enhance access to restorative justice for sexual violence, within the context of gender reconciliation. Through public speaking, advocacy, workshops, conferences, educational media content, and more, we uplift cultural standards of empathy and break the chains of dehumanization. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

With your support, we can cover the startup costs required to make major impact. By contributing to this movement, you can help create a world that believes in people's capacity for transformation, centres survivors voices, lessens incarceration and enhances public safety. 

  • We are asking for funding to cover start-up costs, including: legal (incorporation and charity registration), graphic design (website and logo), media content (creation of educational videos to build awareness, such as the one included here), merchandise, accountant costs, payment for delegated roles (ie. donor relations, outreach), and more. 
  • PERKS: We are excited to offer Marlee's poetry e-book, sharing her journey through sexual violence, long-distance energy healing and online courses.

 

The Impact

After experiencing sexual violence, survivors options are limited;

1) Report to the police and trudge through the criminal justice system or 2) Don’t report at all. The former path consists of often re-traumatizing trials, scripted statements, hyper-focus on punishment, and the conclusion of either incarceration or acquittal. The latter can be disempowering as silence is normalized and sense of safety may be threatened.

Acquittal rates are absurdly high and the failed promise of prison is clear within rates of recidivism. Restorative and transformative justice offer a powerful and much-needed alternative to these options, in which the focus lies on repair, closure, healing, accountability, and lasting transformation. CLICK HERE to learn more... 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Firstly, we want to remind you that ALL SIZE donations are GOOD SIZE DONATIONS. Anything you are able to contribute is met with great value and appreciation. 

  • Share this campaign! Help us build awareness and spread our message by sharing through your social media platforms, newsletters, and networks. 
  • Individual/Corporate Sponsorship: Want to give back in a bigger and more sustainable way? Email us for information regarding sponsorship. 
  • Become an ambassador: For public figures with resonant hearts and far-reaching platforms, we have a program in place promoting collective rising. Click here to request more info.
  • Book us! You can book us for public speaking or workshop facilitation. Visit our website to learn more about the work we do.

story:
Women's Forum

The Women’s Forum is an independent, non-governmental organization founded in January 2001 in Tetovo, North Macedonia. Our activities focus on raising awareness and advocating for gender equality through 2 main program areas:

1. Economic empowerment of women;
2. Protection and promotion of human rights, focusing on women’s rights.

The Center for Free Legal Aid for Survivors of Domestic Violence is lead by an expert lawyer and coordinator who provide free legal advice in the Women’s Forum office and conduct educational training in the community.  Since the Center was founded in 2003, over 600 women have visited the center for free legal advice.

Our Impact

The Center for Free Legal Aid for Survivors of Domestic Violence has:

  • Provided free legal aid to 648 women survivors of violence, since 2003
  • 60% of who were able to successfully file legal paperwork
  • A vast majority of these survivors have children, proving that 1,000s of people in the Tetovo region are affected by family violence

One day, we hope that there will be an end to violence against women. For now, we are helping survivors break the cycle of violence by advising them how to access their rights against abusers. Please consider supporting the Center so we can continue to be there for survivors who need us.

The Ask

Over the years, it has become increasing challenging for the Women's Forum to find funding from international donors to support our activities. During March, Women's History Month, we are asking our friends, supporters, and community members to help fund the costs to operate Center for Free Legal Aid for Survivors of Domestic Violence.

  • $20 donation covers the cost for 1 hour of legal counseling
  • Our goal is to raise $500
  • Every little bit helps!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to donate at this time, you can still help our cause by

  • Sharing this campaign with your friends and family via Facebook or email
  • Like the Women's Forum Facebook page to stay up to date about our activities
  • Volunteering with the Women's Forums (email info@forumi.org.mk for details)

story:
Our Project

The mission of The Black Bookshelf Project (TBBP) is to provide our diverse and vibrant communities with easy access to anti racism resources that focus on the joy, pride, and rich cultural backgrounds of Black people, Indigenous people, and people of color; helping underline commonalities of the human experience.

We want to prepare our future allies to engage in tough conversations that come with anti racism work. By providing our communities with some of the basic tools required to have the difficult and sometimes uncomfortable discussions that surround race and racism (all from the comfort of their own homes) through the development of a centralized resource database that all of TBBP community members will have unrestricted access to. We hope to facilitate families and communities in building the foundations required to confidently advocate for, and uplift, all members of our local and global communities; inspiring learners of every age to continue in their anti-racism journey after coming into contact with our bookshelf.

 

Our Plan & Our Future

We plan to commence our work with select schools in Beaumont and Edmonton once we have acquired the necessary funds, sometime within the next 3 months.  We are offering our books and shelves at no cost to schools. Our only  requests will be that:

  1. The books on the bookshelves are catalogued for ease of access.
  2. The Black Bookshelf Project sticker remains on the spines of the donated books so that they are easily returned to the same area. Schools will be provided with extra spine stickers to replace damaged or worn ones.
  3. The books donated by The Black Bookshelf Project are placed, together, in a prominent location in the school, along with the signage provided by TBBP.

We will be creating a waitlist for communities that are excited by this project and eager to welcome it into their libraries. We are also working towards the goal of becoming approved vendors for multiple school boards within the Edmonton Area.

Our goal is to continue to grow throughout the summer by collecting monetary donations through the sale of our merchandise. We will compile and collect resources for each Black Bookshelf one at a time and deliver and assemble the unit to each school or childcare center once it has been completed!

Knowing that the anti-racism movement is rooted in the idea of inclusion. We fully intend on expanding our libraries as our access to resources increases. We are in the process of applying for Not-for-Profit status. Once we are able to gain that status, and apply for access to the funding that is associated with it, we are hoping to expand the range of books that we are able to provide to our communities! Our hope is to one day add books that aim to celebrate and educate students on the subjects of:

  • gender identity
  • neuro-diversity
  • ableism
  • consent
  • mental health awareness
  • environmental awareness

Our list is not limited to only the subjects mentioned above. Our list will grow and evolve as the people involved grow and evolve. We firmly believe that good things take time and plan on providing our communities with as many diverse resources as we can to set them up for success in working through the important issues within our modern society.

Our Challenges

Anti-racism is a tough subject to broach. The stigma surrounding racism and upholding systems of racial oppression, intentionally or not, can be a tough realization for people to come to. It may not be a realization that some ever come to. We know we won't be able to reach everyone, but we hope to reach everyone that who is willing to learn more and grow with us.

We plan to approach this subject in a way that showcases the flaws in our system and focuses the blame on these systems rather than putting the blame on individuals within our community. We are also hoping that by making resources available online for families to access from the comfort of their own homes, they will approach this information in a less guarded manner, knowing that they are getting credible information from reliable sources without the feeling of shame or the fear of judgment that they may anticipate having during a face to face discussion.  

We also know that teachers and families are overwhelmed right now - which is why we will be providing book summaries and discussion points for families and teachers to be able to access quickly if they are approached by a young learner to have a conversation about a book that they have accessed on a Black Bookshelf. The system will not be perfect initially, but it is better than nothing. We are invested in making this project work - time and resources will be put into modifying and adapting the project and the necessary resources as we uncover issues and bumps along the way.

The Funds

Each bookshelf costs approximately $1100.00 CAD. Whether or not we are able to meet our end goal of $7000.00 CAD, the funds will be spent on the following, listed in order of importance:

  1. Books 
  2. Bookshelves
  3. Signage, Spine Stickers and Book Plates
  4. Securing a domain and website host for The Black Bookshelf Project
  5. The recruitment of lawyers and other professionals to assist us with gaining NPO status and applying for grants in the future.
  6. The development of age appropriate educational resources to accompany each book
  7. The development of merchandise that will help generate ongoing funding for this project once our campaign is over.

Other Ways You Can Help

Monetary contributions help immensely, but they are not the only contributions that matter.  Times are tough and remain uncertain. If you aren't currently in a position to donate financially - here are some other ways you can support The Black Bookshelf Project:

  1. Tell your friends and family about TBBP
  2. Follow us on Instagram @theblackbookshelfproject
  3. Share, Like and Comment on our posts
  4. Do you have any special skills? If you’re an accountant, a lawyer, a banker, or a digital marketing specialist, to name just a few, we might be able to use your help!
  5. We are always on the hunt for ways to grow, but there may be opportunities we miss. Share TBBP with local business organizations or municipal governments seeking ways to help!

story:
Who Are We and What Do You Do?

My name is Vernon E. Davis, II.  I am a 4th generation veteran and I am the Creator of ThankU4YourService.com.  This mission was founded out of love and respect for the men and women that have served our country, I felt that there had to be another way to say Thank You for Your Service, so I created one.  Since November 2012, we have thanked over 4000 veterans worldwide with a simple gift of a Thank You Card, Envelope and a Dog Tag that reads "Thank You For Your Service and Sacrifice You Are Appreciated".

The reason we are raising money is to help fund this mission.  Since it's inception the majority of the funds used to fuel this mission have come out of my own person funds.  I work a day job, I am also a professional stand up comedian (Longhorn The Comedian / www.LonghornComedy.com) so I use my own money and through donations of friends, family and fans.  

At this point the Thank You Packets cost right at $1.46 to produce and mail to veterans, We have done over 4000 thus far.  Yet, we have a goal to provide TYPs to various veterans groups, veterans hospitals, nursing homes...basically anywhere we can say thank you to a veteran is where we want to be.  Therefore we need to raise funds so that we may do just that.  100% of the donation that are made, do into this mission.  It is a giant mission and unfortunately, I am not financially wealthy enough to handle the responsibility of thanking so many myself.  Won't you please help?

Front and Back of the Thank You Card 

Middle Pages of the Thank You Card


Where will the Funds Go?

The funds we raise from this fund raiser will go towards the following

- Providing Thank You Packets to Veterans "Absolutely Free of Charge"     nationwide

- Help us complete the 501(c)3 process - We have the State of Missouri Nonprofit Accredidation, we are now in the process of receiving our Federal Accrediation. 

- Build a better web page  

In exchange for your contributions we will do the following:

Contribution of $100 - we will send you 50 TYPs for you to award to the veterans of your choice.

Contribution of $200 - we will send you 100 TYPs for you to award to the veterans of your choice.

Contributions of $500 - we will send you 250 TYPS for you to award to the veterans of your choice. 

Contributions of $1000 or more - you will receive 500 TYPs to award, you name or organization listed on the back of 1000 Thank You Cards, listed on our web page as a sponsor of ThankU4YourService.com 

Any and every contribution is appreciated greatly.


Thank you for reading our campaign.  We do this out of love for those that have served and we pray that you will help us to do the same.

My name is Vernon E. Davis, II.  I am a 4th generation veteran and I am the Creator of ThankU4YourService.com.  This mission was founded out of love and respect for the men and women that have served our country, I felt that there had to be another way to say Thank You for Your Service, so I created one.  Since November 2012, we have thanked over 4000 veterans worldwide with a simple gift of a Thank You Card, Envelope and a Dog Tag that reads "Thank You For Your Service and Sacrifice You Are Appreciated".
The reason we are raising money is to help fund this mission.  Since it's inception the majority of the funds used to fuel this mission have come out of my own person funds.  I work a day job, I am also a professional stand up comedian (Longhorn The Comedian / www.LonghornComedy.com) so I use my own money and through donations of friends, family and fans.  At this point the Thank You Packets cost right at $1.46 to produce and mail to veterans, We have done over 4000 thus far.  Yet, we have a goal to provide TYPs to various veterans groups, veterans hospitals, nursing homes...basically anywhere we can say thank you to a veteran is where we want to be.  Therefore we need to raise funds so that we may do just that.  100% of the donation that are made, do into this mission.  It is a giant mission and unfortunately, I am not financially wealthy enough to handle the responsibility of thanking so many myself.  Won't you please help?Front and Back of the Thank You Card Middle Pages of the Thank You CardWhere will the Funds Go?The funds we raise from this fund raiser will go towards the following- Providing Thank You Packets to Veterans "Absolutely Free of Charge"     nationwide- Help us complete the 501(c)3 process - We have the State of Missouri Nonprofit Accredidation, we are now in the process of receiving our Federal Accrediation. - Build a better web page  In exchange for your contributions we will do the following:Contribution of $100 - we will send you 50 TYPs for you to award to the veterans of your choice.Contribution of $200 - we will send you 100 TYPs for you to award to the veterans of your choice.Contributions of $500 - we will send you 250 TYPS for you to award to the veterans of your choice. Contributions of $1000 or more - you will receive 500 TYPs to award, you name or organization listed on the back of 1000 Thank You Cards, listed on our web page as a sponsor of ThankU4YourService.com Any and every contribution is appreciated greatly.    Thank you for reading our campaign.  We do this out of love for those that have served and we pray that you will help us to do the same.

story:
On December 20, 2015, we will be going downtown Toronto to share the joy and hope of Christmas with the homeless and we need your help!

VOLUNTEER!  DONATE!

We need volunteers to come out to hand out gift bags to the homeless.  Email us today to signup and for further details.

We need donations to purchase the gift bags.  Donate here (click the Contribute Now button or email us)                                                                       

DONATION CLOSES 15 DECEMBER, 2015 @ 23:59!

(to allow time for purchasing the gift bags)

Donate here or contact Edward Choi or Roy Wong (email addresses below).

Contact us to volunteer.  More details to follow.

We also thank all those who donated offline including: Tracy Wu, Maggie Li, Anney, Second Cup (Markham, Ontario).

What is Christmas Once Again???

To learn more about Christmas Once Again, please watch our introductory video:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4ilJvV93opM&amp...

Visit our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/events/1658017641148346/

And watch our 2015 Promo Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=op_CKyROOyk

Winter time is especially harsh for the homeless on the streets.  As many are celebrating inside their homes, the homeless are often alone on the cold winter streets with establishments closed for the holidays.  Throughout the past few years, we learned that a group of homeless chose not to live in shelters for a number of reasons (violence, policies, unlawful substances, psychological distress, financial, etc.) and this group is generally overlooked during Christmas time.  Our goal is to share with them some love, hope, joy, and happiness, and ensure that they feel remembered as human-beings.


Our Mission…

For many of us, Christmas time means a holiday off school and work; a perfect time to relax and enjoy good music, food and prepare for the new year.  Each year in most major cities around the world, hundreds of people are living on the streets without adequate food, clothing, shelter and hope.  Christmas time is one of the hardest times of the year due to the cold weather and that establishments are closed.

Our goal is to share with them, some love, hope, items, and hopefully some fun.  It will be a great opportunity for us to talk with them and spread the true meaning and joy of Christmas.  In return, we can provide whatever assistance possible.  We believe that the event will not only provide hope, happiness and a memorable experience for the homeless, but also allow us to learn about people with different backgrounds.

The C.O.A. Story…

In the autumn of 2007, Edward Choi and Roy Wong had dinner at a London, Ontario restaurant one Tuesday evening.  They discussed the idea of an event to spread the joy of Christmas to those in need.  During prior years, both individuals have encountered homeless people while travelling across several cities in Ontario.  It was believed that providing them with food, clothing, other essentials and understanding their needs would better serve the homeless than to provide monetary donations alone. 

They decided to approach the local university fellowships, the Asian Christian Fellowship (ACF) at the University of Western Ontario and the Laurier Chinese Christian Fellowship (LCCF) at Wilfrid Laurier University for support.  Both university fellowships supported this idea.  The first C.O.A. presentation was made at the ACF Christmas party and electronic correspondence was sent to LCCF.  During the first annual C.O.A. in 2007, we had 7 volunteers who actively handed out 80 gift bags to the homeless on the streets of downtown Toronto, which was made through $200.45 in donated funds.

Various organizations partnered with us throughout the years, including the University of Western Ontario’s Asian Christian Fellowship, Laurier Chinese Christian Fellowship, the University of Toronto Chinese Christian Fellowship, Logos Baptist Church (Markham  ON), Second Cup (Bur Oak & McCowan, Markham ON), the University of New Brunswick’s Intervarsity Christian Fellowship (Fredericton), and the Gideons International In Canada.  Our goal is to provide the joy and happiness to those in need.  Whether you are a volunteer, donor, partnering organization representative, or simply want to learn more about Christmas Once Again, we thank you for writing part of the C.O.A. story… To be continued…

(note: Indiegogo charges a 5% administrative fee plus credit card fee of approximately 3% - if you wish to make alternate arrangements, please contact us)

Video: https://youtu.be/4ilJvV93opM

Thank you for your support.

Edward Choi & Roy Wong, Co-Founders and Co-Organizers

Christmas Once Again 2015





Email:

Edward Choi:  edwardchoi@alumni.qmul.net

Roy Wong:  roybok@hotmail.com

COA: christmasonceagain@gmail.com


CHRISTMAS ONCE AGAIN 2015 - Sharing Christmas with the homeless since 2007!

JOIN US FOR THE 9th Annual CHRISTMAS ONCE AGAIN ON DECEMBER 20, 2015!
VOLUNTEER!  DONATE!

story:
What We Need & What You Get

Where the $125,000 funding will go:

  • Flights to Ireland (80 youth and 20 mentors/staff) - $25,000
  • Accommodation and meals (5 nights x 100 people) -  $40,000
  • Post-conference projects in their cities and sustainability - $60,000

Please check out our wonderful perks in the right column -> you will receive for generously supporting our crowdfunding campaign!

The Impact

All things being equal -- and they never are -- young Muslims from more economically deprived & less assimilated neighborhoods in their cities are more susceptible to radicalization, especially young Muslims from the “in between” generation. These are the sons and daughters of migrants who are caught between the pull of their parents’ native identity & the identity of the country in which they are born. They are absent a sense of belonging. Of all the factors drawing youth to terror networks like ISIS, the lack of a sense of “belonging” is the most pervasive. In ISIS they are provided with that sense & see themselves as part of a cause greater than themselves. It gives meaning & structure to their lives. Religion is rarely a defining factor.

GAME is a counter radicalization movement by default. It is a counterpoint to what terrorist networks provide: structure, meaning and purpose for its members, a sense of belonging to something greater than themselves, the knowledge that they can accomplish collectively what they cannot accomplish individually, nurturing self-esteem and instilling meaning in their lives that they can say “My Life Matters.”

GAME will provide these young people with opportunities to be at the center of the solution: to create new and affirming community activities, become advocates on their own behalf, develop a higher sense of purpose to a constructive cause, and connect with like-minded Muslim youth throughout the world to help foster a global movement. They will help generate a counter-narrative to the widely-held perceptions of Muslim youth embodying an unstated threat.

Post-conference projects will include activities such as building a website, training in community-building via social media, filmmaking, journalism, political organizing, and constructive activism.

Risks & Challenges

A movement takes time and energy.  We are committed to doing everything possible to help this movement succeed.  We need this funding for the inaugural conference to be a success.  We can not do it alone.

Please join us and spread the word about our campaign!

 

Padraig O'Malley 

 

For four decades Padraig has worked trying to help move cultures in conflict from violence to reconciliation. He has worked in Northern Ireland, South Africa, Iraq, Israel/Palestine and has written several award-winning books.  Padraig is the focus of a new documentary called The Peacemaker.

Nelson Mandela Website: http://bit.ly/2vfq0iA

Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Padraig_O%27Malley

The Peacemaker: http://www.peacemakermovie.com

GAME PARTNERS include: 

The Glencree Centre for Peace & Reconciliation, Glencree, Co. Wicklow, Ireland;

EPOS Intl. Mediating and Negotiating Operational Agency;

The Nansen Centre for Peace & Dialogue;

The London Tigers;

Moroccan Youth Association, Brussels;

Karame e.V., Berlin and Youth Initiative for Human Rights – Kosovo.

Please Follow Us On Social Media

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/GAME.Europe/

 

Game Pre-Planning Meeting in March

Members of the GAME communities discuss the Oct. conference.

story:
NO FLY ZONE OVER PALESTINE

We shall make a human chain with the children of Gaza to spell out NO FLY ZONE OVER PALESTINE so as to tell the world that Israel's bombings of Gaza must stop.

 

We intend to remind the world how the children of Palestine are terrorized and murdered by Israeli air power on a regular basis.  We intend to tell the story of how the people of Gaza suffer the effects of post-traumatic stress disorder from the horrific bombardment of Gaza during Operation Cast Lead.  We demand that the good people of the world acknowledge that Israeli planes simply flying over Palestine is an intentional source of panic and fear, of state sponsored terrorism, for countless people in Gaza, especially the children. 

 

There are kids in Gaza that wet themselves at night for fear of being bombed again when they hear Israeli aircraft overhead.  And this is a nearly daily occurrence.  There are children here that have seen loved ones crushed, bleeding, burned and dying, some hit with White Phosphorus, as a result of Israeli bombings.  Some of these children were seriously wounded themselves.  One 11-year-old girl I know personally (from the Samouni family) still has pieces of an Israeli rocket in her head from a bombing during Operation Cast Lead.  To this day this injury causes her to bleed from her nose and she has other neurological issues as yet undiagnosed and unresolved.  This is but one story but it makes the point that not only memories are embedded in these children forever, each time a jet, a drone or helicopter gunship flies overhead, the ongoing nightmare of what may come is re-visited. 

 

I ask every parent out there to imagine your child continuously traumatized and terrified in the name of “fighting terrorism”.  Ask yourself how you would feel about being continuously bombarded by the fourth largest military in the world and having no way at all to protect your child from fear or harm?  How would you feel? 

 

Now think about how you play a direct role in the terrorizing of children in Palestine if you are a UK or American citizen.  Your governments continue to supply the very same weapons used to carry out these missions.  Maybe you in particular should do something to stop this homegrown madness, and if you are already doing something then maybe you should do more?

 

Make no mistake; the flying of Israeli aircraft over Palestine is in itself a form of terrorism.  Bombing with “high precision” weapons that continue to hit innocent people is a war crime and terrorism; and this is happening regularly.  So what the hell are we doing about it?

 

Some may say; “what difference will a picture make?”  Well I believe the picture we seek to take will make a difference.  We will gather around 200 schoolchildren of Gaza on Thursday April 21, 2011 and these children will form a human chain that will spell out the words ‘NO FLY ZONE OVER GAZA’. 

 

As we do this let us face another shameful fact, the NO FLY ZONE OVER LIBYA is pure, unadulterated oil stealing hypocrisy posing as “humanitarian intervention”.  If there were ever anything genuinely humane about Western intervention a NO FLY ZONE OVER PALESTINE would have been implemented decades ago.  But the Palestinians have no oil, and they certainly have no air defenses, and so the innocent people of Gaza continue to be bombed with impunity.

 

How bloody stupid, powerless and hypocritical must we the people have become to allow unhindered bombings of Palestine for decades while doing nothing effective to stop it, meanwhile sitting back to watch a NO FLY ZONE OVER LIBYA be put into place in little more than a week or two? 

 

Face it people, we in the West remain staggeringly complacent and falsely inhumane when we allow such hypocrisies to be flaunted right in front of our faces.  And so it is that those of us who are still human are compelled to do something.    

 

Symbols have power and the extent of that power is derived from the meaning and intensity people affix to the symbols.  We intend to create a powerful global symbol made of a message sent directly from the children of Gaza, to the people of the world. Now whether the world listens and responds to these children is yet to be seen, but at the very least we shall send this message.  We hope that our photograph captures the message to such an extent that people are motivated to do more.  Ultimately seek to have this message heeded to such a point that Israeli aircraft will no longer be able to terrorize the people/children of Gaza/Palestine.  And if not, every single time another Israeli bomb drops on the innocents of Palestine, this picture shall be put forward as the demand of a truly sane and humane international community. 


The true cost of bringing 200 children to the spot to form the human chain is roughly $300 but the minimum amount to request with Indiegogo is $500, thus if we receive $500 or more we will look to bring more children as we must supply travel by bus and a minimum of refreshments for the kids.  If the amount we recieve is more than needed to do what we intend to do then the remainder will be given to the Samouni Project.

 

NO FLY ZONE OVER PALESTINE!
