story:
A CHILD YOU KNOW AND LOVE MAY BE IN DANGER. 

JOIN ME IN THE FIGHT AGAINST CHILD EXPLOITATION.

What would cause a pragmatic city-girl to move to the middle of farming country, hours away from friends, family, and the aerial community to work for free for the U.S. Attorney's Office for a year?

There could be only one thing important enough to call her to the wild - the chance to prosecute child exploitation cases (primarily child pornography/sexual abuse) on the front-lines, working to save the next generation of victims and to show those whose photos of their abuse are eternally available  in the dark vortex of the web that there are those willing to sacrifice to achieve whatever justice can be obtained on their behalf.

Why is this so important? Just look at a few of the facts:

-  An estimated 1 in 5 girls and 1 in 10 boys in the U.S. are sexually exploited during childhood.

-  69% of the children are sexually abused by an adult that they know and trust. Only 4% are abused by a stranger.

-  Between 1996 and 2005, arrests for child exploitation increased 2,325% and they continue to increase.

-  Nearly 50% of child pornography is produced in the United States.

-  In a 10 yr span, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC) reviewed and analyzed more than 104 million images of child pornography in an attempt to identify the victims and save them from further abuse. Many of the children are abused violently in images depicting bondage, sadism, and torture.

-  Due to the rapidly increasing spread of child pornography, the images are growing  more graphic and violent and the children being abused are getting younger and younger.

-  In 2010, 96.3% of offenders possessed images of prepubescent minors (under the age of 12) and 74.2% possessed sadomasochistic images. 19% of offenders possessed images of toddlers and infants.

POSSESSION OF CHILD PORNOGRAPHY IS NOT A “VICTIMLESS CRIME”

The global child pornography market is a 3 billion dollar industry that has attracted organized crime. But it doesn’t stop with career crimnals. Advances in technology have allowed for the creation of hidden websites where offenders can purchase or trade child pornographic images anonymously, knowing that it is very difficult for law enforcement to track them down, attracting offenders from all walks of life.

In order to be allowed access to other offenders’ collections of photographs, online community members must provide newer and more graphic images to share (and to show that they are not members of law enforcement). Because they have found a community that accepts them and encourages them to produce new materials, offenders quickly evolve from mere viewers to producers.

STUDIES HAVE SHOWN THAT ANYWHERE FROM 30% TO 80% OF POSSESSORS OF CHILD PORNOGRAPHY EVOLVE INTO HAVING SEXUAL CONTACT WITH CHILDREN. One study found that 76% of individuals arrested for possession of Internet child pornography admitted to sexually molesting a child.

VICTIMS ARE PERPETUALLY VICTIMIZED

Psychological problems experienced by child victims continue well into adulthood, as they have been victimized both by the original abusive acts and then repetitively by the knowledge that images of their abuse will permanently reside on the Internet, where the images can be viewed and used for sexual gratification by new offenders ad infinitum.

Most law enforcement agencies at all levels have dedicated divisions to uncovering these crimes and bringing the offenders to justice, but even with their combined efforts they focus their resources on those that they deem to be the worst and most dangerous offenders.

The prosecution for these offenders generally falls on the U.S. Attorney’s Office. Unfortunately, the cases keep increasing despite budgetary shortfalls. As a result, the U.S. Attorney’s Office has created voluntary prosecuting attorney positions to help handle the increase in criminal caseloads.

This is what I want to do! This is what I need your help to do!

WHY ME?

In 1989 my class was assigned to clip out images from magazines representing the path we wanted out lives to take. Among the Cosmopolitans and House & Gardens I managed to find a cartoon of an attorney standing before a judge and place it next to an image of a crying child.

On the back we were to tell our story. I wrote that I wanted to study law at UCLA while getting a tan (I always was a multitasker), then become a prosecutor and fight for victims, particularly child victims.

Although my life took a windy path full of unexpected twists, turns and even some detours, I did graduate from UCLA School of Law in 2008 where I received recognition for my litigation skills. I have spent considerable time volunteering for the City and District Attorney’s Offices in my quest to protect the vulnerable.

Now I am eager to join the fight against child exploitation on the front -ines. Believe me, to move a big city girl to the country, away from friends and family, to work for free was not anything I had ever anticipated doing, but I know in my heart this is something I need to do. I humbly ask you for your help.

As I said before, the prosecution position I have been offered is uncompensated, meaning I will be working long hours preparing cases for trial, for free. Not something I would have considered if not for the possibility to use the skills that I have selectively obtained in order to be able to help save children from abuse. That time is now.

But I need help to make this possible.

The reality is that no matter how sparsely I try to live, I cannot exist on my passion for the work alone. The more I can raise here, the less I will have to worry about how to cover the costs of necessities and the more I will be able to focus on the work. 

My initial goal here is to make enough to cover rent (approximately $12,000/year), health and car insurance (approximately $10, 080/year), a little more than half of what my anticipated basic living expenses for the year will be.

If the goal is exceeded, I will also be able to pay for food, medicine, gasoline, dry-cleaning and other necessities for my puppies and myself, allowing me to concentrate on the work that I will be doing. I will also be looking for ways to bring in income and decrease expenses.

Should the amount I receive exceed my living expenses for the year, I plan to give the remainder to other charities that work towards ending child exploitation, like the Center for Missing and Exploited Children, that maintains a tipline that receives millions of calls that require investigation to determine if a child can be identified so that he or she can receive help.

HOW CAN YOU HELP?

-  Obviously, a monetary donation will do the most to help send me on my way to the U.S. Attorney’s Office. Be creative – I’ve had friends already offer to hold bake sales and brainstorm other creative ways to raise money for this campaign.

-  Share my campaign on your social media sites. If you know me or have known a victim, personalize your post so that others understand why this is so important to you and to your community.

-  Educate yourself and others. While this alone won’t help me get to Fresno, knowing the facts and sharing them creates an awareness that will extend far beyond this campaign and that awareness may help save a child from victimization and abuse.

- Unlike other crowdfunding campaigns, I am not raising funds to produce a product or event, so it does not lend itself to the "perk" system. If you have a perk that you would like to donate to help me thank other donors, I would appreciate it and would obviously thank you and promote you on my facebook page in appreciation for your donation.

If you would like more information on this subject, please check out my facebook page (click FB button below).

I hope you will consider donating, sharing and encouraging your family and friends to do the same.

Help save the future generation of victim from knowing this pain and fear, and show current and past victims that we DO care, and that they are not alone and not to blame.

Thank you from the bottom of my heart.

~ B.J. Pettigrew

Also - special thanks to Eric Fritsch for editing my video for this campaign and to Esthero for her behind the camera magic to try to make me sound somewhat comfortable before the camera! You guys rock!
story_txt:
A CHILD YOU KNOW AND LOVE MAY BE IN DANGER.  JOIN ME IN THE FIGHT AGAINST CHILD
EXPLOITATION.
What would cause a pragmatic city-girl to move to the middle of farming country, hours away from friends, family, and the aerial community to work for free for the U.S. Attorney's Office for a year?There could be only one thing important enough to call her to the wild - the chance to prosecute child exploitation cases (primarily child pornography/sexual abuse) on the front-lines, working to save the next generation of victims and to show those whose photos of their abuse are eternally available  in the dark vortex of the web that there are those willing to sacrifice to achieve whatever justice can be obtained on their behalf.Why is this so important? Just look at a few of the
facts:
-  An
estimated 1 in 5 girls and 1 in 10 boys in the U.S. are sexually exploited
during childhood.
-  69% of the children are sexually abused by an adult that they know and
trust. Only 4% are abused by a stranger.
-  Between
1996 and 2005, arrests for child exploitation increased 2,325% and they continue to increase.
-  Nearly
50% of child pornography is produced in the United States.
-  In
a 10 yr span, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children (NCMEC)
reviewed and analyzed more than 104 million images of child pornography in an
attempt to identify the victims and save them from further abuse. Many of the
children are abused violently in images depicting bondage, sadism, and torture.
-  Due
to the rapidly increasing spread of child pornography, the images are
growing  more
graphic and violent and the children being abused are getting younger and
younger.
-  In
2010, 96.3% of offenders possessed images of prepubescent minors (under the age
of 12) and 74.2% possessed sadomasochistic images. 19% of offenders possessed
images of toddlers and infants.
POSSESSION OF CHILD PORNOGRAPHY IS NOT A “VICTIMLESS CRIME”
The global child pornography market is a 3 billion dollar
industry that has attracted organized crime. But it doesn’t stop with career crimnals.
Advances in technology have allowed for the creation of hidden websites where
offenders can purchase or trade child pornographic images anonymously, knowing
that it is very difficult for law enforcement to track them down, attracting offenders from all walks of life.
In order to be allowed access to other offenders’
collections of photographs, online community members must provide newer and
more graphic images to share (and to show that they are not members of law
enforcement). Because they have found a community that accepts them and
encourages them to produce new materials, offenders quickly evolve from mere
viewers to producers.
STUDIES HAVE SHOWN THAT ANYWHERE FROM 30% TO 80% OF
POSSESSORS OF CHILD PORNOGRAPHY EVOLVE INTO HAVING SEXUAL CONTACT WITH
CHILDREN. One study found that 76% of individuals arrested for possession of
Internet child pornography admitted to sexually molesting a child.
VICTIMS ARE PERPETUALLY VICTIMIZED
Psychological problems experienced by child victims continue
well into adulthood, as they have been victimized both by the original abusive
acts and then repetitively by the knowledge that images of their abuse will permanently
reside on the Internet, where the images can be viewed and used for sexual gratification by new offenders ad infinitum.
Most law enforcement agencies at all levels have dedicated
divisions to uncovering these crimes and bringing the offenders to justice, but
even with their combined efforts they focus their resources on those that they
deem to be the worst and most dangerous offenders. 
The prosecution for these offenders generally falls on the
U.S. Attorney’s Office. Unfortunately, the cases keep increasing despite budgetary shortfalls. As a result, the U.S. Attorney’s Office has created voluntary prosecuting attorney positions to help handle the
increase in criminal caseloads.
This is what I want to do! This is what I need your help to
do!

magazines representing the path we wanted out lives to take. Among the

attorney standing before a judge and place it next to an image of a crying
child.

But I need help to make this possible.

story:
WHO ARE WE?

ONLY First Defense Legal Aid (FDLA) provides free legal defense to anyone in Chicago Police Custody --24 hours a day, 365 days a year since 1995-- at the first and most critical stage of the criminal justice process: at the time of arrest, when no Public Defender is available.

WHY A CAMPAIGN?

First Defense urgently needs your help now. Through no fault of our own, grants that provided over 75% of First Defense's very modest funding were discontinued. By donating towards this campaign you will help us stay afloat while we pursue other grants and individual donations.

WHAT DO WE DO?

First Defense attorneys go to police stations and help people in custody understand, assert, and protect their constitutional rights, gather information about arrest and detainment, document evidence of police brutality, advocate for medical treatment, inform families and friends about their loved ones in custody throughout the process—AND help prevent false confessions.

First Defense also brings Street Law to schools, community groups and the streets to teach people what to do if they are stopped, searched, or arrested by the police, how to assert their rights on the street and at the station, and what to do if they feel that the police have violated their rights.

WHAT CAN YOU DO?

First Defense helps people in their time of need.  Please defend us now. We NEED to continue to protect and advocate for people in custody of the Chicago Police Department!

We work 24/7/365. PLEASE Give $7, $24, $365 or any amount today! No donation is too small. 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT THE CAMPAIGN.

SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT FDLA'S SERVICES.   

AND IF YOU ARE A LICENSED ILLINOIS ATTORNEY, OR 711 LAW STUDENT PLEASE SIGN UP FOR TRAINING TO LEARN HOW TO BE A VOLUNTEER ATTORNEY WHO GOES TO THE POLICE STATION TO PROTECT AND ADVOCATE  FOR PERSONS IN CPD CUSTODY. YOU CAN FIND THAT INFORMATION BY CLICKING ON OUR WEBSITE LISTED BELOW.

ABOVE ALL, THANK YOU FOR TAKING THE TIME TO READ OUR CAMPAIGN!

story:
Gay Bashed. Again.

What are the odds for being savagely beaten for being gay.
Twice.
Even when you’re not?

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HSdWeW2HyGo


On October 9th, 2013, my brother was savagely beaten by an unknown attacker. A man he had never met kicked and punched him and left him bleeding with a broken jaw and 4 broken teeth, all because he mistook him for being gay.

    My name is Robin Street, I'm Kerry's brother. I started this campaign to help raise funds to pay for my brothers dental work. The attack has left him beaten, bruised, bewildered and now it threatens to leave him broke to boot.

    With your assistance I hope to raise enough money to cover his costs so that this heinous act of violence does not cost him any more than it already has in dignity, blood and teeth.

    What We Need From You

    Anything you can spare really, even a single dollar brings us closer to our goal and every little bit helps and is greatly appreciated.

    Any additional funds that we receive above and beyond the costs will be donated to groups that are against violence and discrimination toward the LGBT community and people in general.

    Violence

    We have all been touched by violence in some way in our lives no matter who we are, or what creed or life choices we follow whether personally, through friends and family or through hearing it on the news. It affects us all and we feel it as a community.

    When acts like these are perpetrated it's easy to become jaded and think that there is no good left in the world, but that's where you come in! You can make a difference! You can be the hero that rights the wrong and saves the day! You have an opportunity to help get one victim back on his feet with a smile on his face and that can make a world of difference.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you just can't afford to spare any money, we understand, times are tight and bills need to get paid. While we will sincerely appreciate every cent that comes in, you can also help by spreading this around and getting the word out. There are bad people in this world, let's not let them win!

    • Post this on your social media site of choice and encourage your friends to check it out and help if they can.
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word!

    Thank you to any and all supporters from the deepest parts of my heart for your kindness and generosity, you are what's good in this world!


    -Robin Street

    Please see below for more information related to this incident as well as Kerry's own personal video about this grievous attack on his person.

    http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HSdWeW2HyGo

    http://www.thenownewspaper.com/straight-surrey-man-savagely-beaten-for-being-gay-again-1.656110

story:
We've been busy.

Over the last year, Bay Area Intactivists held more than
forty events with an average of over three per month. Our community
outreach to raise awareness of the human right to genital integrity
has included protests, bike rides, educational booths, marches, plus a
documentary film screening. We have numerous events planned for the
coming months including our participation in the San Francisco LGBT
Pride Parade and a 4th of July booth at the Berkeley Marina.

But we need your help.

Even though our dedicated volunteers lend their time and talents, we
still incur various expenses such as registration fees, liability
insurance, protest signs, and promotional materials. We also must
continually replenish our stock of leaflets, stickers, bracelets, and
buttons that we distribute at our events.

By making a donation, you can help offset these costs.

Please show your appreciation of our work to end genital mutilation
and help ensure that Bay Area Intactivists will continue to be a
strong force in the fight for the human right to genital integrity.

Thanks for your support!

story:
Resumen

Somos OTD Chile, "Organizando Trans Diversidades." Desde este espacio trabajamos para mejorar las condiciones de vida de las personas trans. A través del seguimiento legislativo del proyecto de Ley de Identidad de Género que está en el Congreso Nacional ya hace más de 4 años, además participamos activamente en la creación de protocolos de Salud y Educación, pero principalmente nos hemos esforzado en el empoderamiento de las personas trans en Chile.

We are OTD Chile, “Organizing Trans Diversities.” In this space, we work to improve the living conditions of trans people. We engage in legislative activism surrounding the proposed Gender Identity Law, which has languished in Congress for more than four years. We also actively participate in the creation of health and education protocols, but our primary goal is the empowerment of trans people in Chile.

Pero aún así, hoy tenemos un proyecto de ley de identidad de género que nos exige certificados psiquiátricos y no incluye a nuestros niños, niñas y adolescentes trans, excluyéndoles de acceder a un justo reconocimiento y a su desarrollo integral. Sin ir más lejos el 83% de las personas trans intenta suicidarse por primera vez entre los 11 y los 18 años.

Nonetheless, the current draft of the proposed law requires us to present psychiatric certification of our identities, and does include children and teens, excluding them from recognition and preventing their development as whole people. 83% of trans people attempts suicide for the first time between the ages of 11 and 18.

Sin duda nos falta mucho por hacer para emparejar la cancha, y una de las formas es seguir visibilizandonos y ser una faro para que más personas trans, que hoy no nos conocen y creen que no hay ninguna salida para vivir sus vidas, tengan esperanza.

As you can see, there is much to do to level the playing field, and one of the best ways to do this is make ourselves visible as a beacon for trans people who do not yet know we exist, and who feel hopeless about their futures.

Por eso es que nos celebrarnos con orgullo y nos unimos a las reivindicaciones mundiales del Octubre Trans, en contra de la patologización Trans a través de muchas actividades, en especial queremos contarte de una de las más importantes, que se hará el día sábado 21 de Octubre, ahí celebraremos el Primer Festival por la Despatologización de las Identidades Trans TransFest, que convoca a la comunidad Trans en el Parque Gómez Rojas, en la comuna de Recoleta acá en la cuidad de Santiago a pasos del Metro Baquedano, a celebrarnos, diversificarnos y empoderarnos de manera feliz!

This is why we are gathering to celebrate our identities with pride, and why we join with celebrations of Trans Octubre around the world, against the pathologization of trans identities. We want to tell you about one in particular, which will take place on Saturday, October 21, when we will hold Chile’s first festival for the depathologization of trans identities, Transfest. Transfest brings together to the trans communities in Gómez Rojas Park, in the Recoleta neighborhood of Santiago, just steps from Metro Baquedano, where we will celebrate our diversity and have fun!

Lo que necesitamos 

Para llevar a cabo este proyecto es necesario reunir la cantidad de 10 mil dólares. Los fondos se usarán, entre otras cosas, para comprar comida, bebida, y materiales, pagar a lxs artistas, contratar a intérpretes de lengua de señas, ¡¡Para eso puedes colaborar en esta página y además compartir!! ¡¡Tu ayuda es imprescindible!! Te invitamos a hacerte parte y compartir.

To carry out this project, we need to raise $10,000. The funds will be used, among other things, to buy food, drinks, and supplies, pay artists, and hire sign language interpreters. You can help us by donating here, and sharing the page in your networks! Your help is crucial! We invite you to join us and share!​

El impacto

Tu colaboración ayudará a brindarle visibilidad a la comunidad trans chilena, cuyos derechos fundamentes aún no se respetan. El Transfest es una oportunidad para estar en comunidad y demostrarle al mundo la urgencia de que se nos respete como personas integrales.

Your donation will help give visibility to Chile’s trans community, whose fundamental rights are still not respected. Transfest is an opportunity to bring the community together and demonstrate the urgency of the recognition of trans people as whole people.

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Si no puedes colaborar en este momento, puedes ayudar difundiendo nuestra campaña en las redes sociales, usando los hashtags #soytrans #transfest y #transfriendly. También pueden darle "Me Gusta" a nuestra página de Facebook y seguirnos en Twitter @OTDChile

Sin no tienes tarjeta de crédito o débito, puedes colaborar haciendo transferencia bancaria a la cuenta de ASOCIACION OTD 291-7-066033-0 del Banco Estado.

If you can’t donate right now, you can help us by sharing our campaign on social media, using the hashtags #soytrans #transfest y #transfriendly. You can also “like” our page on Facebook and follow us on Facebook @OTDChile.

Por eso es que nos celebrarnos con orgullo y nos unimos a las reivindicaciones mundiales del Octubre Trans, en contra de la patologización Trans a través de muchas actividades, en especial queremos contarte de una de las más importantes, que se hará el día sábado 21 de Octubre, ahí celebraremos el Primer Festival por la Despatologización de las Identidades Trans TransFest, que convoca a la comunidad Trans en el Parque Gómez Rojas, en la comuna de Recoleta acá en la cuidad de Santiago a pasos del Metro Baquedano, a celebrarnos, diversificarnos y empoderarnos de manera feliz!
This is why we are gathering to celebrate our identities with pride, and why we join with celebrations of Trans Octubre around the world, against the pathologization of trans identities. We want to tell you about one in particular, which will take place on Saturday, October 21, when we will hold Chile’s first festival for the depathologization of trans identities, Transfest. Transfest brings together to the trans communities in Gómez Rojas Park, in the Recoleta neighborhood of Santiago, just steps from Metro Baquedano, where we will celebrate our diversity and have fun!

Lo que necesitamos 
Para llevar a cabo este proyecto es necesario reunir la cantidad de 10 mil dólares. Los fondos se usarán, entre otras cosas, para comprar comida, bebida, y materiales, pagar a lxs artistas, contratar a intérpretes de lengua de señas, ¡¡Para eso puedes colaborar en esta página y además compartir!! ¡¡Tu ayuda es imprescindible!! Te invitamos a hacerte parte y compartir.
To carry out this project, we need to raise $10,000. The funds will be used, among other things, to buy food, drinks, and supplies, pay artists, and hire sign language interpreters. You can help us by donating here, and sharing the page in your networks! Your help is crucial! We invite you to join us and share!​

El impacto
Tu colaboración ayudará a brindarle visibilidad a la comunidad trans chilena, cuyos derechos fundamentes aún no se respetan. El Transfest es una oportunidad para estar en comunidad y demostrarle al mundo la urgencia de que se nos respete como personas integrales.
Your donation will help give visibility to Chile’s trans community, whose fundamental rights are still not respected. Transfest is an opportunity to bring the community together and demonstrate the urgency of the recognition of trans people as whole people.

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar
Si no puedes colaborar en este momento, puedes ayudar difundiendo nuestra campaña en las redes sociales, usando los hashtags #soytrans #transfest y #transfriendly. También pueden darle "Me Gusta" a nuestra página de Facebook y seguirnos en Twitter @OTDChile
Sin no tienes tarjeta de crédito o débito, puedes colaborar haciendo transferencia bancaria a la cuenta de ASOCIACION OTD 291-7-066033-0 del Banco Estado.
If you can’t donate right now, you can help us by sharing our campaign on social media, using the hashtags #soytrans #transfest y #transfriendly. You can also “like” our page on Facebook and follow us on Facebook @OTDChile.

story:
Add Your Voice!

The Voice for Vylit Board of Directors is a group of passionate community leaders who want to see our children treat each other better in a loving and accepting community. We all know a child or a friend of a child who is struggling with bully behavior and we must end it today!

Every dollar that we raise will go directly to educate, facilitate and empower our youth to make better choices in the words they use and to help re-learn respect for others and self.

What We Need & What You Get

For 2018, we need $10,000 which will go towards funding things such as: 

  •      4-minute high definition (high quality, yet affordable) video that we can place on our website (www.voiceforvylit.com) and be played during speaking engagements we plan to have at Whatcom and Skagit County schools. 
  •      Exhibition table materials such as a Voice for Vylit tent that will make us stand out in the crowd of other tables to get the word out that we are here to help parents with their children and to help us recruit others to help us in this endeavor. 
  •      Rally support to get more youth, parents and others involved in the endeavors we have planned in 2018.
  •     No one is going to be paid full-time, but there will be costs incurred to make flyers, and other marketing materials---some small contracts will be offered to local vendors.

All funds, regardless if we make our $10,000 goal will go towards efforts to curb bully behavior in schools and online. 

The Impact

There aren't many groups out in the world that is dedicated to helping protect our children from bully behavior. We need your help--in any capacity (either time, talent or treasure).

When we make impact and reduce bully behavior in our schools, we will be helping to build-up respectful, giving children who will one day become even better adults. We need your help now!

Risks & Challenges

Our Board of Directors are movers and shakers in the Whatcom County area. They know first-hand that there are risks and challenges with any endeavors they have been successful with. The mountain is high to reduce bully behavior, but every dollar will count and every donated minute will add up to helping the future of our world--our children, our most prized assets in our family.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please make it a point to share this campaign with your friends and relatives. They need to know that there is a group of passionate people that want to see all of our children protected from vicious bully tactics. We also want to let people know that we are helping the bully as well because we know they too have been bullied.

Please share this as much as you can via social media!

story:
Our (Her) Story

I would like to introduce to all of you â€“ my mother-in-law, Jere, or known to some, â€œThe Bag Lady". This is my "Hero" for all that she does for her community and our Homeless. Maybe because itâ€™s the holiday season why I feel that I need to share her story, and because it is this time of year that we find in most of us that we want to give a little extra. This in a way is somewhat sad, because we only do it seasonal, this is about a lady that gives unconditionally every day. She is known as â€œThe Bag Ladyâ€ because for over (10) years she has made bags for theHomeles ; containing of a small lunch and soaps, shampoos, toothbrushes, ect. She has even opened up her home to some of the people, offering a place to stay or a home cooked meal. I find this lady amazing because she does this on her own and out of her own money, unconditionally working through the lord. This is a lady that only works part time and yet she still finds it in her heart to share what she has to feed and give to a goal of max (30) Homeless people every Sunday before church. Jere has blessed many hearts over the years and I hope that this message can touch some of yours â€“ and that it might inspire you to give a little more to the ones in need not only through the holiday season but throughout the year. Maybe with some of your help, Jere can give a little more. Thank you for reading this and I pray that all of you have a blissful holiday and a new year filled with many blessings.

The Impact

The Impact on what this gift will contribute would be for her to be able to help more than (30) people a week. Every Sunday before church there are over (30) people that come to wait for her to give them a "Bag". This bag varies each week, containing at least a bologna sandwich, soaps, toothbrushes, and any type of hygiene stuff that she can pick up at the dollar store. I am only asking for $3,000.00. I would like to ask for more, but I feel since Jere only makes $10.00 an hour, working part time and she has been able to pay her rent, bills and still budget herself to feed (30) people a week. 3K will give her enough to start the non-profit and to ensure that she will be able to buy some bulk items to hand out for the winter months. It would be nice for her to be able to give not only food, hygiene products, but also be able to supply some things to help keep them warm through this winter. By giving this gift, this will allow her to feed and give to more than her limited (30) goal a week.

What We Need & What You Get

With these funds, we will be able to set up a Non-Profit Organization for Jere called the "The Bag Lady" so that she will be able to receive gifts allowing a Tax Benefit to the givers. She will also with these funds be able to go on ebay and purchase hats, gloves and clothes at bulk to help keep our homeless warm throughout the winter months. We have found bulk deals but they are costing over $100.00 per order and she does not have that extra amount at a time to be able to purchase these items. With what funds remaining will be set in a separate account for her to purchase a little more healthy food than bologna sandwiches for her Homeless that she feeds. This amount should feed at least the (30) people through plus some for the next several (winter) months.  What you will get is an update every week from Jere herself on how many people she was able to touch. 100% of these funds will be used to set up the non-profit and for food or products for our Homeless. An Updated account will be given.


Other Ways You Can Help

(Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others' by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Don't forget to remind them about the share tools!)

story:
Short Summary

My wife - who works for a humanitarian organization - travelled to Ghana last month and was very touched by the Liberian people that need to be relocated from the closing Buduburam refugee camp. She was guided through the camp by Mr. Jordan Parker, a refugee himself and a minister at the camp (http://gtinternational.webs.com/aboutthefounder.htm)

Because of the closure of the Buduburam refugee camp in Ghana, many Liberian refugees will become illegal aliens if they can not return home.

We have stayed in touch with Mr. Jordan Parker, and I have asked him if there was a way to be able to help him and his people in their situation.

This campaign is an effort to help 19 of these refugees return home to Liberia, avoiding being detained as illegals in Ghana.

What We Need & What You Get

Initially, 21 of their members needed transportation assistance. Two of them were transported recently by one pastor who saw the need. Now we are talking about 19 persons who still need help now to go back home.

Each of them needs $165.00(USD) to go back home. This means that all 19 of them will need $3,135.00USD. If funding is available, they will take them by road as going by air is very expensive indeed. It will take them 3 days to reach home on Bus.

We're asking for $3,500 to cover this plus incidentals including the cost to transfer the money.

If the target is not reached, at least each $165 will allow 1 refugee to return home.

PS I understand that something like this may sound a bit fishy, especially with the usual Nigerian email scams out there, however this is all very real. If you have any doubts, please feel free to contact me on my cell phone and I can vouch for it. (604 809 4252)

 

Your Help would be greatly appreciated.

Martijn Spronk,

(on behalf of Mr Jordan Parker)

story:
The Team

 

My name is Mariano Marquez III. I'm a San Francisco filmmaker who's shooting a documentary feature about the homeless situation in Central California's City of Fresno. After witnessing the overwhelming circumstances of thousands of homeless people in downtown Fresno, I knew I had to go a step further beyond filmmaking. That's why I established the Pam Kincaid Memorial Fund. If you would like to know more about me, please read my Artist Statement:

 

http://www.lightningraypictures.com/about

 

This campaign is sponsored by the Eco Village Project of Fresno, a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization. The board of directors of the Eco Village Project of Fresno include:

 

  • Arthur Dyson
  • Mike Rhodes
  • Dixie Salazar
  • Gerry Bill

 

Mike Rhodes is editor of Fresno's Community Alliance newspaper and an activist for homeless rights. Dixie Salazar is a local artist frequently seen reaching out to Fresno's homeless community, while Gerry Bill is Professor Emeritus of Fresno City College and a longtime activist. Finally, Arthur Dyson is a world-renowned architect and Dean Emeritus of the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture. Dyson has designed a plan for green and sustainable Eco Villages. His vision not only offers a solution to end global homelessness, but a blueprint for job training and self-empowerment.

 

The Pam Kincaid Story

 

For over a decade, the City of Fresno has been home to thousands of homeless people who live in communities known as 'tent cities' or 'encampments.' Pam Kincaid was a prominent leader & activist for Fresno's homeless community. In 2006, she was the lead-plaintiff in a class-action lawsuit that was filed against the City of Fresno for street clean-ups that resulted in the immediate destruction of homeless property that sometimes included valuable personal items like family photos, clothes and urns with the remains of loved ones.

 

In 2008, the lawsuit resulted in the biggest settlement for homeless defendants in U.S. history, requiring the City of Fresno to pay 2.3 million dollars. Unfortunately, Kincaid did not live to see this historic victory. On August 1, 2007, Kincaid died under mysterious circumstances after falling to her death from a 4th story balcony at a local hospital.

 

For more information, please read the following articles:

 

http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2007/08/08/18439524.php

http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2006/10/25/18323305.php

http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2007/06/22/18429489.php

http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2007/08/18/18441458.php

http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/05/13/18498973.php

http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/06/06/18504842.php

 

The Mission

 

The mission of the Pam Kincaid Memorial Fund is to provide Fresno's homeless with a respectable standard of living via basic services. Our current funding goal is a starting point for Project Homeless Dignity. As the Eco Village Project of Fresno works towards housing the homeless, these funds will provide hundreds of homeless people with access to things like portable toilets, trash bins, sleeping bags, covers, clothes, food and bottled water for 1 year. It will cost much more to accomplish this goal, but about $15,000 has already been covered by the generous contributions of local donors. With your help, we can go beyond our starting point of $16,500. The more we exceed our goal, the greater the impact on our homeless community.

 

All donations are tax-deductible. Campaign contributions go directly to the Eco Village Project of Fresno, a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization. Members of the Eco Village Project of Fresno believe wholeheartedly in the mission of the United Nations:

 

"Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services, and the right to security in the event of unemployment, sickness, disability, widowhood, old age or other lack of livelihood in circumstances beyond his control."

— Article 25, Universal Declaration of Human Rights

 

The Message

 

If you can't donate to the fund, the best way to help is by spreading the word. We believe everyone has a right to help however they can, whenever they can. If you have an account on Twitter, Facebook, Google+, a blog or any other form of social media... you can be a member of this campaign. As a special thanks to those who help get the word out, you'll receive website credit as:

'Messenger of the Homeless'

 

Contribution Perks

 

$10 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 10 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update.

$15 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 15 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update.

$25 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 20 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update and a digital flipbook that includes pictures, special notes and your name.

$50 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 30 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update and a digital flipbook that includes pictures, special notes and your name. As a bonus, you're entitled to a special 'Thank You' video featuring your name.

$75 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 40 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update and a digital flipbook that includes pictures, special notes and your name. As a bonus, you're entitled to a special 'Thank You' video featuring your name. As a second bonus, your special 'Thank You' video will include a unique 'In Honor' or 'In Memory' dedication to a person or organization of your choice.

 

Thank You

 

Thanks in advance to all the contributors of this campaign.

I also thank and acknowledge the following people for their generous contributions to Fresno's homeless community:

 

  • Alphonso Williams – Founder of the Free United Homeless Coalition (FUHC) & Homeless Advocate
  • Arthur Dyson – Architect & Homeless Advocate
  • Bill Simon – Chair of Fresno Chapter, ACLU & Homeless Advocate
  • Christopher Herring – PhD Student at University of California, Berkeley & Homeless Advocate
  • Chris Schneider – Executive Director at Central California Legal Services & Homeless Advocate
  • Christy Wong – Homeless Advocate
  • Dixie Salazar – Artist & Homeless Advocate
  • Donna Lopez – Cook at Fresno Food Not Bombs
  • Donna Taylor – Director at Fresno County Department of Behavioral Health & Homeless Advocate
  • Doreen Eley – Administrative Director at Poverello House & Homeless Advocate
  • Floyd Harris – Reverend & Homeless Advocate
  • Georgia Williams – Chair of Fresno Chapter, Peace and Freedom Party & Homeless Advocate
  • Gerry Bill – Professor Emeritus of Fresno City College & Homeless Advocate
  • Gloria Hernandez – Homeless Advocate
  • Jean Kennedy – Professor at Fresno City College & Homeless Advocate
  • Jim Grant – Host at KNXT TV, Fresno & Homeless Advocate
  • Judy Hess – Chair of Fresno Chapter, Progressive Democrats of America & Homeless Advocate
  • Kevin Hamilton – Deputy Chief of Programs at Clinica Sierra Vista
  • Kelly Borkert – Coordinator at Fresno Food Not Bombs & Homeless Advocate
  • Laura Rose Pierce – Homeless Advocate
  • Laura Tanner-McBrien – Coordinator of Project ACCESS at Fresno Unified School District & Homeless Advocate
  • Linda Cano – Executive Director at Fresno Art Museum & Homeless Advocate
  • LoriAnne Tennison – Artist & Homeless Advocate
  • Michele L. Tutunjian – Director at EOC Sanctuary and Youth Services & Homeless Advocate
  • Mike Rhodes – Editor of the Community Alliance & Homeless Advocate
  • Nancy Waidtlow – Founder of the Dakota EcoGarden & Homeless Advocate
  • Paul M. Orduno – Homeless Advocate
  • Ray Polk – Homeless Minister & Advocate
  • Salvador Sandoval – Medical Doctor & Homeless Advocate
  • Sandy Perry – Justice Minister & Homeless Advocate
  • Sarah Williams – Homeless Advocate
  • Sharen "Big Sue" Bobbitt – Homeless Advocate
  • Tina Borkert – Volunteer at Fresno Food Not Bombs & Homeless Advocate
  • Vance Cantu – Homeless Minister & Advocate

 

Additional thanks goes to all homeless advocates from the following organizations:

 

  • American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU)
  • Bishop John Steinbock Homeless Advocacy Committee
  • California State University, Fresno
  • Central California Legal Services
  • Clinica Sierra Vista
  • Community Alliance
  • Community Homeless Alliance Ministry (CHAM)
  • Dakota Eco Garden
  • Firewood Brigade
  • Free United Homeless Coalition (FUHC)
  • Fresno Art Museum
  • Fresno Center for Non-Violence
  • Fresno Economic Opportunities Commission
  • Fresno Food Not Bombs
  • Fresno Homeless Advocates
  • Grace Community Church of Fresno
  • Hope Lutheran Church of Fresno
  • KNXT-TV, Fresno
  • Parkside Crew
  • Roman Catholic Diocese of Fresno
  • Sacramento Homeless Organizing Committee (SHOC)
  • To Know Him Ministry of Fresno
  • Unitarian Universalist Church of Fresno
  • Wesley United Methodist Church of Fresno
  • Western Regional Advocacy Project (WRAP)

 

There are countless others fighting for the rights of Fresno's homeless...

Thank you all for your support, and most importantly, thank you for providing dignity to Fresno's homeless.

 

Links

 

http://www.lightningraypictures.com

http://www.fresnoalliance.com

http://www.arthurdyson.com

http://www.dixiesalazar.com

http://www.centerfornonviolence.org

http://www.fresnostate.edu

http://www.fresnoartmuseum.org

http://www.clinicasierravista.org

http://www.centralcallegal.org

http://www.fresnoeoc.org

http://www.knxt.tv

http://www.dioceseoffresno.org

http://www.uufresno.org

http://www.wesleyfresno.org

http://www.hopelutheranfresno.org

http://www.cham-ministry.org

http://www.aclu.org

http://www.sacshoc.org

http://www.wraphome.org

http://www.fresnoalliance.com/FNB

For over a decade, the City of Fresno has been home to thousands of homeless people who live in communities known as 'tent cities' or 'encampments.' Pam Kincaid was a prominent leader & activist for Fresno's homeless community. In 2006, she was the lead-plaintiff in a class-action lawsuit that was filed against the City of Fresno for street clean-ups that resulted in the immediate destruction of homeless property that sometimes included valuable personal items like family photos, clothes and urns with the remains of loved ones.
 
In 2008, the lawsuit resulted in the biggest settlement for homeless defendants in U.S. history, requiring the City of Fresno to pay 2.3 million dollars. Unfortunately, Kincaid did not live to see this historic victory. On August 1, 2007, Kincaid died under mysterious circumstances after falling to her death from a 4th story balcony at a local hospital.
 
For more information, please read the following articles:
 
http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2007/08/08/18439524.php
http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2006/10/25/18323305.php
http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2007/06/22/18429489.php
http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2007/08/18/18441458.php
http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/05/13/18498973.php
http://www.indybay.org/newsitems/2008/06/06/18504842.php
 
The Mission
 
The mission of the Pam Kincaid Memorial Fund is to provide Fresno's homeless with a respectable standard of living via basic services. Our current funding goal is a starting point for Project Homeless Dignity. As the Eco Village Project of Fresno works towards housing the homeless, these funds will provide hundreds of homeless people with access to things like portable toilets, trash bins, sleeping bags, covers, clothes, food and bottled water for 1 year. It will cost much more to accomplish this goal, but about $15,000 has already been covered by the generous contributions of local donors. With your help, we can go beyond our starting point of $16,500. The more we exceed our goal, the greater the impact on our homeless community.
 
All donations are tax-deductible. Campaign contributions go directly to the Eco Village Project of Fresno, a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization. Members of the Eco Village Project of Fresno believe wholeheartedly in the mission of the United Nations:
 
"Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services, and the right to security in the event of unemployment, sickness, disability, widowhood, old age or other lack of livelihood in circumstances beyond his control."
— Article 25, Universal Declaration of Human Rights
 
The Message
 
If you can't donate to the fund, the best way to help is by spreading the word. We believe everyone has a right to help however they can, whenever they can. If you have an account on Twitter, Facebook, Google+, a blog or any other form of social media... you can be a member of this campaign. As a special thanks to those who help get the word out, you'll receive website credit as:
'Messenger of the Homeless'
 
Contribution Perks
 
$10 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 10 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update.
$15 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 15 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update.
$25 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 20 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update and a digital flipbook that includes pictures, special notes and your name.
$50 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 30 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update and a digital flipbook that includes pictures, special notes and your name. As a bonus, you're entitled to a special 'Thank You' video featuring your name.
$75 donations receive permanent credit on my website, a 'thank you' on Facebook & Twitter and 40 high-resolution production photos from the feature documentary, Encampment. Many of the pics are beautiful portraits of homeless people taken at Fresno's tent cities. You also receive a video update and a digital flipbook that includes pictures, special notes and your name. As a bonus, you're entitled to a special 'Thank You' video featuring your name. As a second bonus, your special 'Thank You' video will include a unique 'In Honor' or 'In Memory' dedication to a person or organization of your choice.
 
Thank You
 
Thanks in advance to all the contributors of this campaign.
I also thank and acknowledge the following people for their generous contributions to Fresno's homeless community:
 


Alphonso Williams – Founder of the Free United Homeless Coalition (FUHC) & Homeless Advocate

Floyd Harris – Reverend & Homeless Advocate

Gerry Bill – Professor Emeritus of Fresno City College & Homeless Advocate


Gloria Hernandez – Homeless Advocate

Additional thanks goes to all homeless advocates from the following organizations:

There are countless others fighting for the rights of Fresno's homeless...
Thank you all for your support, and most importantly, thank you for providing dignity to Fresno's homeless.

story:
The recent executive order has dramatically impacted the lives of refugees both inside and outside the United States.  We have always been a country of immigrants, and our diversity is what makes America great.  Many of us at Indiegogo come from immigrant families or are immigrants ourselves.  

In response to the ban, the International Rescue Committee just announced an emergency appeal to help refugees - mostly women and children - who have come to the United States to start new lives. 

The IRC’s 29 offices provides necessary aid for people from all over the world who are fleeing unspeakable violence. This appeal will go towards filling funding gaps associated with the ban, including housing, cultural orientation, health care, education, employment, and immigration services.

Please consider joining Indiegogo today to show the world that refugees are and always will be welcome in the United States. Click "BACK IT" above and enter your donation amount - any amount helps!

Indiegogo will be matching the first $5,000 in employee donations.

__________________________________________

In Partnership with
