story:
>>>> German version:

(The english version you can find below)

Es kann nicht sein, dass LGBT-Flüchtlinge in unser Land fliehen und hier in den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen, in denen sie mind. 6 Monate oder meist länger als ein Jahr verweilen müssen, von ihren Landsleuten bespuckt, verprügelt, mit Steinen beworfen und ausgegrenzt werden. Das akzeptiere ich in unserem Land nicht. Wenn unsere Regierung dieses Thema nicht in Angriff nimmt, dann möchte ich wenigstens gemeinsam mit dem Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin, dem LSVD und dem CSD in Dresden den Menschen helfen, bei denen es am Schlimmsten ist. Wir brauchen eure Unterstützung!

Die Washington Post berichtete über uns: 
https://goo.gl/jooo3T


Rainbow Refugees hilft ankommenden LGBT-Flüchtlingen in Deutschland in ein neues Leben zu starten.


Wer ist Rainbow Refugees?

Rainbow Refugees ist ein Zusammenschluss aus mehreren LGBTi- Organisationen und Vereinen in Deutschland. Gemeinsam setzen wir uns auf Bundesebene für den besonderen Schutz der schwulen, lesbischen, bisexuellen und transsexuellen (LGBT) Flüchtlinge ein und helfen in Deutschland ankommenden LGBT-Flüchtlingen:

CSD-Dresden  (der CSD Dresden kümmert sich nicht nur um die CSD Parade sondern übernimmt im Land wachsen die Vorreiterrolle in der LGBT Flüchtlings Problematik und kümmert sich aktiv vor Ort um LGT Flüchtlinge)

LSVD (Lesben und Schwulenverband in Deutschland)

Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin  

Rainbow Refugees Karlsruhe

Vorwort

Vorab weise ich darauf hin, dass ich hier nicht unsere Regierung als diskriminierend hinstellen möchte. Ich bin der Meinung, dass aufgrund der generell hohen Anzahl an Flüchtlingen derzeit viele Dinge nicht bearbeitet werden können. Es mangelt an Personal und oftmals herrscht Chaos.

Jeder Flüchtling, egal ob hetero, schwul, lesbisch, bisexuell, transsexuell, verheiratet, mit oder ohne Kinder wird derzeit in Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen in ganz Deutschland verteilt und untergebracht. Hier müssen alle ankommenden Flüchtlinge verweilen, bis der Staat Ihre Registrierung aufgenommen hat. Dies dauert aufgrund der derzeit hohen Anzahl an Flüchtlingen oftmals Monate. Auch bis über den Asylantrag entschieden wurde vergehen nochmals mehrere Monate. 

Alle Flüchtlinge, die aufgrund von Krieg und Verfolgung fliehen, bekommen eine Aufenthaltserlaubnis. 

Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen sind umfunktionierte Wohnheime, Zeltstädte im Freien, oder bestehende Gebäude (umfunktionierte Turnhallen oder Kasernen). 

Hier werden alle Flüchtlinge, auch LGBT-Flüchtlinge untergebracht. Es gibt keine Privatsphäre: Bis zu zehn Personen werden in beengten Zimmern mit Stockbetten untergebracht. Hunderte Flüchtlinge müssen in Turnhallen leben und übernachten – ohne eine trennende und schützende Wand.

Behinderte Flüchtlinge, allein reisende Flüchtlingsfrauen und Flüchtlingsmütter mit Kindern gelten in unserem Land als besonders schutzbedürftig. Diese kommen in separate Hotels oder besonders geschützte und betreute Einrichtungen.

LGBT-Flüchtlinge werden nicht als besonders schutzbedürftig anerkannt. 

Oftmals erfahren wir, dass insbesondere schwule, lesbische und bisexuelle Flüchtlinge ihre Sexualität verheimlichen sollen. Da dies einer der Gründe der Flucht ist, ist das für uns als Rainbow Refugees Organisation nicht ok. 

Die LGBT-Flüchtlinge wohnen oftmals mit den Menschen in Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen zusammen, vor denen Sie geflohen sind. Landsleute, die verachtend über LGBT´s denken und handgreiflich gegenüber LGBT-Flüchtlingen werden.

Und hier endet mein Verständnis!

Es kann nicht sein, dass LGBT-Flüchtlinge in unser Land fliehen und hier in den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen, in denen sie mind. 6 Monate oder meist länger als ein Jahr verweilen müssen, von ihren Landsleuten bespuckt, verprügelt, mit Steinen beworfen und ausgegrenzt werden. Das akzeptiere ich in unserem Land nicht. Wenn unsere Regierung dieses Thema nicht in Angriff nimmt, dann möchte ich wenigstens gemeinsam mit dem Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin, dem LSVD und dem CSD in Dresden den Menschen helfen, bei denen es am Schlimmsten ist.

Der CSD Dresden betreut derzeit 30 LGBT-Flüchtlinge. Weitere 4 LGBT-Flüchtlinge werden kurzfristig hinzu kommen. Die Schwulenberatung Berlin betreut derzeit  70 Flüchtlinge. Jedoch sind es noch viele mehr, die wir ohne eure Unterstützung nicht betreuen können.

Gemeinsam mit eurer Unterstützung holen wir die LGBT-Flüchtlinge aus den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen raus und bringen Sie sicher unter.


Fakten 

Warum in Dollar?

Indiegogo bietet die Unterstützung mit Kreditkarte nicht in EURO an. Daher haben wir uns entschieden, die Kampagne in Dollar auszuführen. 


1. LGBT Flüchtlinge

Laut Umfragen sind mindestens ein Prozent aller Menschen lesbisch, schwul, bisexuell oder transsexuell. Schätzungen kommen auf fünf bis zehn Prozent. Von den 1.000.000 Flüchtlingen, die 2015 nach Deutschland kommen, müssten also mindestens 10.000 dieser Gruppe angehören. Die tatsächliche Zahl solcher Schutzsuchenden wird aufgrund der extrem hohen Todesgefahr, in der sich LGBT-Flüchtlinge etwa in radikalislamischen ISIS-Gebieten und dem Iran befinden, höher sein.

2. Wovor fliehen Sie? 

In Kriegsgebieten, die vom IS besetzt werden, müssen Schwule, Lesben Bisexuelle und Transsexuelle mit der Todesstrafe durch Steinigung oder Hinrichtung rechnen. Die Angst vor Verfolgung und Tod, teilweise durch die eigene Familie, ist so akut, dass ihnen nur noch die Flucht bleibt. Oftmals fliehen sie vor Verfolgung, Krieg, Diskriminierung oder einer Gesellschaft, die LGBT`s nicht aktzeptiert.

3. Woher kommen die LGBT-Flüchtlinge?

Die LGBT-Flüchtlinge kommen teilweise aus Kriegsgebieten wie Syrien, Libyen, Afghanistan, Pakistan und der Ukraine. Aber auch aus Ländern, in denen die sexuelle Orientierung von LGBT´s unter Strafe steht, z.B. Russland.

4. Wieso fliehen Sie nach Deutschland?

Deutschland ist ein liberales Land. Unsere Gesellschaft akzeptiert und toleriert LGBT´s. In Deutschland feiern wir jährlich in verschiedenen Städten den Christopher Street Day, der mittlerweile auch von vielen Familien mit Kindern besucht wird. Viele der beliebtesten Komiker, TV Unterhalter und Stars in unserem Land sind schwul, lesbisch, bisexuell oder transsexuell und stehen offen zu ihrem Lebensstil. Auch in der Politik muss man sich nicht mehr verstecken.

5. Wie kommen die LGBT-Flüchtlinge in unser Land?

Die LGBT-Flüchtlinge kommen meistens nach einer gefährlichen Überquerung des Mittelmeeres in der EU an.  Die weitere Reise nach Deutschland erfolgt zu Fuß.  Alles, was sie noch besitzen ist ihre Kleidung, Ausweisdokumente und ein Handy.

6. Aktuelle Situation der LGBT-Flüchtlingshilfe

Nachdem wir die LGBT-Flüchtlinge aus den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen rausgeholt haben werden diese derzeit bei ehrenamtlichen Helfern und privaten Unterstützern untergebracht. Diese Möglichkeiten sind jedoch stark begrenzt und nur für wenige Tage verfügbar. 

Das ist jedoch keine Dauerlösung und reicht nicht aus, um alle LGBT-Flüchtlinge, die derzeit in Deutschland ankommen und noch zu uns kommen werden, dauerhaft sicher außerhalb der Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen unterzubringen. Behördengänge, Sprach- und Integrationskurse erfolgen oftmals auf ehrenamtlicher Basis und sind nicht ausreichend. Gemeinsam mit eurer Unterstützung werden wir  unser Programm ausweiten.

In Berlin haben LGBT-Flüchtlinge tagsüber die Möglichkeit in der Tagesstätte des Schwulenberatungszentrum Zeit zu verbringen, müssen jedoch Abends wieder zurück in die Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen.

7. Wofür wird eure Unterstützung verwendet?

Derzeit gibt es diese ganze Unterstützung bereits auf freiwilliger Basis, aber diese reicht nicht aus. Viele Freiwillige können nicht wochenlang umsonst arbeiten, da sie selbst von etwas leben müssen. Auch Wohnungen werden von uns freiwillig gestellt, meist für ein bis zwei Wochen. Das reicht leider nicht aus, um den LGBT-Flüchtlingen eine dauerhafte und sichere Wohnlösung zu bieten.

Eure Unterstützung kommt zielgerichtet an:

Anlaufstellen

Derzeit koordinieren wir bundesweit Anlaufstellen für LGBT-Flüchtlinge. Dadurch können Mitarbeiter von Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen direkt an uns wenden.

Sicherer Wohnraum und Schutz vor LGBT feindlichen Flüchtlingen

Um die LGBT-Flüchtlinge aus den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen rauszuholen, müssen wir als alternative Lösung Wohnungen anmieten, Heizkosten bezahlen und etwas Einrichtung bereitstellen. Allerdings sind unsere finanziellen Mittel im Moment stark begrenzt. 

Psychologische Betreuung

Teilweise begegnen uns die LGBT-Flüchtlinge mit einem schweren Trauma. Mit eurer Unterstützung bezahlen wir dringend notwendige psychologischer Unterstützung. Nur durch professionelle, psychologische Betreuung kann das Erlebte aufgearbeitet werden.

Dolmetscher & Behördengänge

Die LGBT-Flüchtlinge sprechen oft schlechtes Englisch oder können sich nur in Ihrer Landessprache verständigen. Wir werden Dolmetscher engagieren um Behördengänge möglich zu machen.

Einfach mal einen schönen Tag erleben

Mit eurer Hilfe würde ich gerne ein Lächeln verschenken. Ein Lächeln nach einem schönen Tag.

Wenn ich ehrlich bin würde ich den Jungs und Mädels, die zu uns kommen und so viel Schlimmes erlebt haben einfach mal einen schönen Tag ermöglichen. Einen Tag im Zoo oder Kino. In der Hoffnung, dass sie auf andere Gedanken kommen können und nicht ganz so alleine sind.

Sprach- und Integrationskurse

Die staatlichen Sprach- und Integrationskurse sind überfüllt und man wartet Monate auf eine Zuteilung. Mit eurer Unterstützung beschleunigen wir die Integration und versuchen eigene Sprach- und Integrationskurse in Zusammenarbeit mit dem Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin und dem CSD Dresden zu organisieren.

LGBT-Flüchtlingsheim

Mein bzw. unser größter Wunsch wäre es von eurer Unterstützung ein Heim für mehrere LGBT-Flüchtlinge dauerhaft anmieten zu können und den deutschen Staat damit unter Druck zu setzen. Dieser muss endlich handeln und LGBT-Flüchtlinge als besonders schützenswerte Flüchtlinge anerkennen.

8. Was uns antreibt 

Jeder von uns LGBT´s ist in seinem Leben bereits ein- oder mehrmals ausgegrenzt oder Opfer von Gewalttaten geworden. Oftmals nur, weil wir so sind wie wir sind. Ein nicht sehr schönes Gefühl. 

-> Stellt euch vor, Ihr würdet in einem Land leben, in dem Ihr verfolgt, öffentlich schikaniert und für eure Persönlichkeit gesteinigt und ermordet werdet. Und dann kann es nicht sein, dass Regenbogen Flüchtlinge zu uns kommen, in der Hoffnung in einem liberalen Land wie Deutschland Schutz und Freiheit zu finden und hier in den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen exakt das Gleiche erleben müssen wie in ihrer Heimat. Das darf in unserem Land keinem LGBT-Flüchtling wiederfahren!

Wir können alle mit den LGBT-Flüchtlingen mitfühlen. Wenn wir uns in deren Lage versetzen wären wir dankbar, wenn wir von Gleichgesinnten aufgefangen und unterstützt werden. Und uns diese Gleichgesinnten auch bei Integration und Behördengängen helfen.

LGBT-Flüchtlinge kommen mit nichts nach Deutschland. Sie kehren ihrem alten Leben den Rücken. Sie kommen zu uns, weil Sie frei sein wollen. Hier dürfen Sie sein, wie sie sind.

Wieso ich mich an euch wende? Weil ich in der Hoffnung bin das wir, alle LGBT´s in der Welt, zusammenhalten und gemeinsam etwas erreichen können und ein Statement setzen.

Jeder Beitrag zählt. 

Falls ihr uns zu dem Thema bekannter machen könnt ist dies auch ein großer Beitrag für uns um auf unser aktuelles Thema aufmerksam zu machen.


Danke :)


>>> English version:


It can’t be true that LGBT refugees flee to our country, only to spend at least six months – usually longer than a year – in a reception center where they might be spit on, beaten, hit with stones, and ostracized by their countrymen. I cannot accept this situation in our country.We need your support! 


The Washington Post reports about us:

    https://goo.gl/jooo3T

(The english version you can find below)

Rainbow Refugees is helping LGBT refugees arriving in Germany to start a new life.


Who is Rainbow Refugees? 

Rainbow Refugees is a coalition of multiple LGBTi organizations and associations in Germany. Together, we are working on the federal level to ensure special protections for gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) refugees, and are offering support to LGBT refugees arriving in Germany:

CSD-Dresden  (Christopher Street Day Organization Dresden Saxony Germany)

The CSD-Dresden organize not only the Christopher Street Parade, they  help LGBT refugees in Saxony currently for their accommodation.

LSVD (Lesbian and Gay Association Germany)

Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin (Gay Advisory Center Berlin)

Rainbow Refugees Karlsruhe


Preface

What has happened up to now with LGBT refugees arriving in Germany? This is where my sympathy ends!

I would like to make an initial remark that I do not intend to condemn our government as discriminatory here. I am of the opinion that there are a large number of issues that can’t be dealt with currently due to the large number of refugees involved. We lack personnel, often resulting in chaotic situations.

Every refugee, no matter whether they are heterosexual, gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, married, a parent, or single, is currently being distributed across Germany to refugee reception centers where they are housed. All incoming refugees have to wait in these centers until the state has accepted their registration. Due to the high number of incoming refugees at the present, this can often take months. Making a decision on an asylum application can also take many additional months.

All refugees fleeing due to war and persecution receive a residency permit.

Refugee reception centers are repurposed dormitories, tent cities outdoors, or existing buildings (repurposed gymnasiums or barracks).

All refugees, including LGBT refugees, are housed in these facilities. There is no private sphere: up to 10 people stay in narrow rooms filled with bunk beds. Hundreds of refugees have to live in gymnasiums, where they spend the night without walls to separate or protect them.

Handicapped refugees, refugee women traveling alone, and refugee mothers with children are granted special protections in our country. They are housed in separate hotels or in facilities that provide additional protection and supervision.

LGBT refugees are not recognized as deserving of special protection. 

We often hear that gay, lesbian, and bisexual refugees feel they have to hide their sexuality. Since this is one of the reasons they become refugees in the first place, we at the Rainbow Refugees organization feel this is a major problem.  

LGBT refugees often live together in refugee housing facilities with exactly the people they are attempting to flee. These are their countrymen, who might despise LGBT people and even become violent against LGBT refugees.

This is where my sympathy ends!

It can’t be true that LGBT refugees flee to our country, only to spend at least six months – usually longer than a year – in a reception center where they might be spit on, beaten, hit with stones, and ostracized by their countrymen. I cannot accept this situation in our country. If our government won’t take up this topic, then I at least will work alongside the Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin, the LSVD, and the CSD in Dresden to help the people who need it most.

CSD Dresden is currently providing help and counseling to 30 LGBT refugees. Another 4 LGBT refugees will be added to this group shortly. The Schwulenberatung Berlin is currently providing help and counseling to 70 refugees. But there are still many more people we won’t be able to help without your support.

With your support and your engagement, we will get LGBT refugees out of refugee reception centers and provide them safe housing.

Facts

1. LGBT refugees 

According to surveys, at least one percent of all people are lesbian, gay, bisexual, or transgender. Estimates can even reach as high as five to ten percent. Of the 1,000,000 refugees coming to Germany within 2015, this means that at least 10,000 individuals belong to this group. Due to the extremely severe level of life-threatening danger LGBT refugees face in radicalized ISIS-held areas and in Iran, the actual number of individuals seeking protection is likely higher.

2. What are they fleeing from?

In war-torn areas occupied by IS, gays, lesbians, bisexuals, and transgender individuals are exposed to the death penalty through stoning or summary execution. The fear of persecution and death, sometimes at the hands of a person’s own family, is so acute that the only path remaining to them is to escape. They are often fleeing persecution, war, discrimination, or a society that doesn’t accept the LGBT “lifestyle.”

3. Where do LGBT refugees come from?

Some LGBT refugees come from war-torn areas such as Syria, Libya, Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Ukraine. But some come from other areas in which those with LGBT sexual orientations and gender expressions are punished, such as Russia.

4. Why are they fleeing to Germany? 

Germany is a liberal country. Our society accepts and tolerates LGBT people. We celebrate Christopher Street Day in Germany every year in cities across the country, a festival even visited by families with children. Many of our country’s most beloved comedians, TV personalities, and stars are gay, lesbian, bisexual, or transgender, and live in a very open manner. Not even politicians need to hide their identities today.

5.  How do LGBT refugees reach our country?

LGBT refugees usually come to the EU after a dangerous journey across the Mediterranean Ocean. They make their continued journey to Germany on foot. All they possess is their clothing, documents and identification, and a cell phone.

6. Current status of LGBT refugee relief

After we’ve removed LGBT refugees from reception centers, they will be housed initially with volunteer helpers and private supporters. These accommodations are, however, very limited and only available for a few days.

This is not a long-term solution, and will not be sufficient to house all LGBT refugees currently arriving in Germany, nor those who will arrive in the future safely outside of refugee reception centers. Access to authorities and language and integration courses are often provided on a volunteer basis, and are not sufficient. With your support, we will expand our program together.

In Berlin, LGBT refugees have the opportunity to spend time in the daytime facility in the Schwulenberatungszentrum during the day. In the evenings, however, they have to return to the refugee reception centers.

7. What do we accomplish with your support?

Currently, all support we receive is on an volunteer basis. This is not enough.

Many volunteers can´t work for weeks on end without pay, since they need to hold careers to support themselves. We are also providing housing on a volunteer basis, typically for one to two weeks. Unfortunately, this is not sufficient to be able to offer LGBT refugees on a long-term and secure housing solution.

Your support will be used to target the following areas:

Contact points

We are currently coordinating contact points nationwide for LGBT refugees. Employees in refugee reception centers can reach us directly through these.

Secure housing and protection from anti-LGBT refugees

To get LGBT refugees out of refugee reception centers, we have to rent apartments as an alternative solution, paying heating costs and providing some furnishings. Our financial means to do so, however, are severely limited at the moment.

Psychological counseling

LGBT refugees sometimes come to us having suffered severe trauma. With your support, we will be able to pay for urgently needed psychological support. The only way for them to work through what they have experienced is with professional psychological counseling.

Interpreters & access to authorities

LGBT refugees often speak poor English or can only understand their native languages. We will hire interpreters in order to allow them to visit authorities as needed.

Simply enjoying a nice day

With your help, I would love to give someone a smile. A smile after a nice, normal day.

To be honest, I would like to make it possible for the boys and girls who come to us having suffered so much to simply have a nice day. A day at the zoo or the movies, in the hopes that this will help them change their thinking and not feel so alone.

Language and integration courses

State-run language and integration courses are overcrowded, and refugees can wait months for a slot. With your support, we can speed up integration and attempt to organize some language and integration courses in collaboration with the Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin and CSD Dresden.

LGBT refugee house

My, and our, greatest wish would be to use your support to rent a home for multiple LGBT refugees in the long term, placing some pressure on the German government. This would force it to act, finally, to recognize LGBT refugees as a group deserving of special protection.

8. What drives us to do what we do

Every LGBT person has been ostracized at some point in their lives, and may have even been the victim of a violent act. Often just for being who we are. It’s not exactly a good feeling.

-> Imagine you lived in a country where you were persecuted, publicly humiliated, and stoned and murdered because of who you are as a person. It shouldn’t be that rainbow refugees come to us in the hopes that they will find protection and freedom in a liberal country like Germany, only to have to experience exactly the same things in the refugee reception center that they did in their homelands. This shouldn’t happen to any LGBT refugee who comes into our country!

We can all feel sympathy with LGBT refugees. If we put ourselves in their position, we’d be thankful to be received and supported by others like us. We would also appreciate these supporters helping us with issues of integration and access to authorities.

LGBT refugees come to Germany with nothing. They turn their backs on their old lives. They come to us because they want to be free. Here, they can be who they are.

Why am I turning to you? Because I hope that we, all LGBT individuals in the world, can join to achieve something together and to make a statement.

Every contribution is important. Every dollar helps.

If you are able to spread our message, this would also be a major contribution, allowing us to bring more attention to this topic.

9. Why dollars? 

Indiegogo doesn’t support credit card payments in euros. This is why we have decided to fund our campaign using dollars.


Thank you :)
story_txt:
>>>> German version:


(The english version you can find below)



Es kann nicht sein, dass LGBT-Flüchtlinge in unser Land fliehen und hier in den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen, in denen sie mind. 6 Monate oder meist länger als ein Jahr verweilen müssen, von ihren Landsleuten bespuckt, verprügelt, mit Steinen beworfen und ausgegrenzt werden. Das akzeptiere ich in unserem Land nicht. Wenn unsere Regierung dieses Thema nicht in Angriff nimmt, dann möchte ich wenigstens gemeinsam mit dem Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin, dem LSVD und dem CSD in Dresden den Menschen helfen, bei denen es am Schlimmsten ist. Wir brauchen eure Unterstützung!


Die Washington Post berichtete über uns: https://goo.gl/jooo3T


Rainbow Refugees hilft ankommenden LGBT-Flüchtlingen in Deutschland in ein neues Leben zu starten.

Wer ist Rainbow Refugees?
Rainbow Refugees ist ein Zusammenschluss aus mehreren LGBTi- Organisationen und Vereinen in Deutschland. Gemeinsam setzen wir uns auf Bundesebene für den besonderen Schutz der schwulen, lesbischen, bisexuellen und transsexuellen (LGBT) Flüchtlinge ein und helfen in Deutschland ankommenden LGBT-Flüchtlingen:



CSD-Dresden  (der CSD Dresden kümmert sich nicht nur um die CSD Parade sondern übernimmt im Land wachsen die Vorreiterrolle in der LGBT Flüchtlings Problematik und kümmert sich aktiv vor Ort um LGT Flüchtlinge)

LSVD (Lesben und Schwulenverband in Deutschland)
Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin  
Rainbow Refugees Karlsruhe
Vorwort
Vorab weise ich darauf hin, dass ich hier nicht unsere Regierung als diskriminierend hinstellen möchte. Ich bin der Meinung, dass aufgrund der generell hohen Anzahl an Flüchtlingen derzeit viele Dinge nicht bearbeitet werden können. Es mangelt an Personal und oftmals herrscht Chaos.
Jeder Flüchtling, egal ob hetero, schwul, lesbisch, bisexuell, transsexuell, verheiratet, mit oder ohne Kinder wird derzeit in Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen in ganz Deutschland verteilt und untergebracht. Hier müssen alle ankommenden Flüchtlinge verweilen, bis der Staat Ihre Registrierung aufgenommen hat. Dies dauert aufgrund der derzeit hohen Anzahl an Flüchtlingen oftmals Monate. Auch bis über den Asylantrag entschieden wurde vergehen nochmals mehrere Monate. 
Alle Flüchtlinge, die aufgrund von Krieg und Verfolgung fliehen, bekommen eine Aufenthaltserlaubnis. 
Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen sind umfunktionierte Wohnheime, Zeltstädte im Freien, oder bestehende Gebäude (umfunktionierte Turnhallen oder Kasernen). 
Hier werden alle Flüchtlinge, auch LGBT-Flüchtlinge untergebracht. Es gibt keine Privatsphäre: Bis zu zehn Personen werden in beengten Zimmern mit Stockbetten untergebracht. Hunderte Flüchtlinge müssen in Turnhallen leben und übernachten – ohne eine trennende und schützende Wand.
Behinderte Flüchtlinge, allein reisende Flüchtlingsfrauen und Flüchtlingsmütter mit Kindern gelten in unserem Land als besonders schutzbedürftig. Diese kommen in separate Hotels oder besonders geschützte und betreute Einrichtungen.
LGBT-Flüchtlinge werden nicht als besonders schutzbedürftig anerkannt. 
Oftmals erfahren wir, dass insbesondere schwule, lesbische und bisexuelle Flüchtlinge ihre Sexualität verheimlichen sollen. Da dies einer der Gründe der Flucht ist, ist das für uns als Rainbow Refugees Organisation nicht ok. 
Die LGBT-Flüchtlinge wohnen oftmals mit den Menschen in Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen zusammen, vor denen Sie geflohen sind. Landsleute, die verachtend über LGBT´s denken und handgreiflich gegenüber LGBT-Flüchtlingen werden.
Und hier endet mein Verständnis!
Es kann nicht sein, dass LGBT-Flüchtlinge in unser Land fliehen und hier in den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen, in denen sie mind. 6 Monate oder meist länger als ein Jahr verweilen müssen, von ihren Landsleuten bespuckt, verprügelt, mit Steinen beworfen und ausgegrenzt werden. Das akzeptiere ich in unserem Land nicht. Wenn unsere Regierung dieses Thema nicht in Angriff nimmt, dann möchte ich wenigstens gemeinsam mit dem Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin, dem LSVD und dem CSD in Dresden den Menschen helfen, bei denen es am Schlimmsten ist.Der CSD Dresden betreut derzeit 30 LGBT-Flüchtlinge. Weitere 4 LGBT-Flüchtlinge werden kurzfristig hinzu kommen. Die Schwulenberatung Berlin betreut derzeit  70 Flüchtlinge. Jedoch sind es noch viele mehr, die wir ohne eure Unterstützung nicht betreuen können.
Gemeinsam mit eurer Unterstützung holen wir die LGBT-Flüchtlinge aus den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen raus und bringen Sie sicher unter.

Fakten 


Warum in Dollar?
Indiegogo bietet die Unterstützung mit Kreditkarte nicht in EURO an. Daher haben wir uns entschieden, die Kampagne in Dollar auszuführen. 

1. LGBT Flüchtlinge

Laut Umfragen sind mindestens ein Prozent aller Menschen lesbisch, schwul, bisexuell oder transsexuell. Schätzungen kommen auf fünf bis zehn Prozent. Von den 1.000.000 Flüchtlingen, die 2015 nach Deutschland kommen, müssten also mindestens 10.000 dieser Gruppe angehören. Die tatsächliche Zahl solcher Schutzsuchenden wird aufgrund der extrem hohen Todesgefahr, in der sich LGBT-Flüchtlinge etwa in radikalislamischen ISIS-Gebieten und dem Iran befinden, höher sein.
2. Wovor fliehen Sie? 
In Kriegsgebieten, die vom IS besetzt werden, müssen Schwule, Lesben Bisexuelle und Transsexuelle mit der Todesstrafe durch Steinigung oder Hinrichtung rechnen. Die Angst vor Verfolgung und Tod, teilweise durch die eigene Familie, ist so akut, dass ihnen nur noch die Flucht bleibt. Oftmals fliehen sie vor Verfolgung, Krieg, Diskriminierung oder einer Gesellschaft, die LGBT`s nicht aktzeptiert.
3. Woher kommen die LGBT-Flüchtlinge?
Die LGBT-Flüchtlinge kommen teilweise aus Kriegsgebieten wie Syrien, Libyen, Afghanistan, Pakistan und der Ukraine. Aber auch aus Ländern, in denen die sexuelle Orientierung von LGBT´s unter Strafe steht, z.B. Russland.
4. Wieso fliehen Sie nach Deutschland?
Deutschland ist ein liberales Land. Unsere Gesellschaft akzeptiert und toleriert LGBT´s. In Deutschland feiern wir jährlich in verschiedenen Städten den Christopher Street Day, der mittlerweile auch von vielen Familien mit Kindern besucht wird. Viele der beliebtesten Komiker, TV Unterhalter und Stars in unserem Land sind schwul, lesbisch, bisexuell oder transsexuell und stehen offen zu ihrem Lebensstil. Auch in der Politik muss man sich nicht mehr verstecken.
5. Wie kommen die LGBT-Flüchtlinge in unser Land?
Die LGBT-Flüchtlinge kommen meistens nach einer gefährlichen Überquerung des Mittelmeeres in der EU an.  Die weitere Reise nach Deutschland erfolgt zu Fuß.  Alles, was sie noch besitzen ist ihre Kleidung, Ausweisdokumente und ein Handy.
6. Aktuelle Situation der LGBT-Flüchtlingshilfe
Nachdem wir die LGBT-Flüchtlinge aus den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen rausgeholt haben werden diese derzeit bei ehrenamtlichen Helfern und privaten Unterstützern untergebracht. Diese Möglichkeiten sind jedoch stark begrenzt und nur für wenige Tage verfügbar. 
Das ist jedoch keine Dauerlösung und reicht nicht aus, um alle LGBT-Flüchtlinge, die derzeit in Deutschland ankommen und noch zu uns kommen werden, dauerhaft sicher außerhalb der Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen unterzubringen. Behördengänge, Sprach- und Integrationskurse erfolgen oftmals auf ehrenamtlicher Basis und sind nicht ausreichend. Gemeinsam mit eurer Unterstützung werden wir  unser Programm ausweiten.
In Berlin haben LGBT-Flüchtlinge tagsüber die Möglichkeit in der Tagesstätte des Schwulenberatungszentrum Zeit zu verbringen, müssen jedoch Abends wieder zurück in die Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen.
7. Wofür wird eure Unterstützung verwendet?
Derzeit gibt es diese ganze Unterstützung bereits auf freiwilliger Basis, aber diese reicht nicht aus. Viele Freiwillige können nicht wochenlang umsonst arbeiten, da sie selbst von etwas leben müssen. Auch Wohnungen werden von uns freiwillig gestellt, meist für ein bis zwei Wochen. Das reicht leider nicht aus, um den LGBT-Flüchtlingen eine dauerhafte und sichere Wohnlösung zu bieten.
Eure Unterstützung kommt zielgerichtet an:
Anlaufstellen
Derzeit koordinieren wir bundesweit Anlaufstellen für LGBT-Flüchtlinge. Dadurch können Mitarbeiter von Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen direkt an uns wenden.
Sicherer Wohnraum und Schutz vor LGBT feindlichen Flüchtlingen
Um die LGBT-Flüchtlinge aus den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen rauszuholen, müssen wir als alternative Lösung Wohnungen anmieten, Heizkosten bezahlen und etwas Einrichtung bereitstellen. Allerdings sind unsere finanziellen Mittel im Moment stark begrenzt. 
Psychologische Betreuung
Teilweise begegnen uns die LGBT-Flüchtlinge mit einem schweren Trauma. Mit eurer Unterstützung bezahlen wir dringend notwendige psychologischer Unterstützung. Nur durch professionelle, psychologische Betreuung kann das Erlebte aufgearbeitet werden.
Dolmetscher & Behördengänge
Die LGBT-Flüchtlinge sprechen oft schlechtes Englisch oder können sich nur in Ihrer Landessprache verständigen. Wir werden Dolmetscher engagieren um Behördengänge möglich zu machen.
Einfach mal einen schönen Tag erleben
Mit eurer Hilfe würde ich gerne ein Lächeln verschenken. Ein Lächeln nach einem schönen Tag.
Wenn ich ehrlich bin würde ich den Jungs und Mädels, die zu uns kommen und so viel Schlimmes erlebt haben einfach mal einen schönen Tag ermöglichen. Einen Tag im Zoo oder Kino. In der Hoffnung, dass sie auf andere Gedanken kommen können und nicht ganz so alleine sind.
Sprach- und Integrationskurse
Die staatlichen Sprach- und Integrationskurse sind überfüllt und man wartet Monate auf eine Zuteilung. Mit eurer Unterstützung beschleunigen wir die Integration und versuchen eigene Sprach- und Integrationskurse in Zusammenarbeit mit dem Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin und dem CSD Dresden zu organisieren.
LGBT-Flüchtlingsheim
Mein bzw. unser größter Wunsch wäre es von eurer Unterstützung ein Heim für mehrere LGBT-Flüchtlinge dauerhaft anmieten zu können und den deutschen Staat damit unter Druck zu setzen. Dieser muss endlich handeln und LGBT-Flüchtlinge als besonders schützenswerte Flüchtlinge anerkennen.
8. Was uns antreibt 
Jeder von uns LGBT´s ist in seinem Leben bereits ein- oder mehrmals ausgegrenzt oder Opfer von Gewalttaten geworden. Oftmals nur, weil wir so sind wie wir sind. Ein nicht sehr schönes Gefühl. 
-> Stellt euch vor, Ihr würdet in einem Land leben, in dem Ihr verfolgt, öffentlich schikaniert und für eure Persönlichkeit gesteinigt und ermordet werdet. Und dann kann es nicht sein, dass Regenbogen Flüchtlinge zu uns kommen, in der Hoffnung in einem liberalen Land wie Deutschland Schutz und Freiheit zu finden und hier in den Erstaufnahmeeinrichtungen exakt das Gleiche erleben müssen wie in ihrer Heimat. Das darf in unserem Land keinem LGBT-Flüchtling wiederfahren!
Wir können alle mit den LGBT-Flüchtlingen mitfühlen. Wenn wir uns in deren Lage versetzen wären wir dankbar, wenn wir von Gleichgesinnten aufgefangen und unterstützt werden. Und uns diese Gleichgesinnten auch bei Integration und Behördengängen helfen.
LGBT-Flüchtlinge kommen mit nichts nach Deutschland. Sie kehren ihrem alten Leben den Rücken. Sie kommen zu uns, weil Sie frei sein wollen. Hier dürfen Sie sein, wie sie sind.
Wieso ich mich an euch wende? Weil ich in der Hoffnung bin das wir, alle LGBT´s in der Welt, zusammenhalten und gemeinsam etwas erreichen können und ein Statement setzen.
Jeder Beitrag zählt. 
Falls ihr uns zu dem Thema bekannter machen könnt ist dies auch ein großer Beitrag für uns um auf unser aktuelles Thema aufmerksam zu machen.

Danke :)

I cannot accept this situation in our country.We need your support! 
The Washington Post reports about us:    https://goo.gl/jooo3T(The english version you can find below)
Rainbow Refugees is helping LGBT refugees arriving in Germany to start a new life.



Who is Rainbow Refugees? 
Rainbow
Refugees is a coalition of multiple LGBTi organizations and associations in
Germany. Together, we are working on the federal level to ensure special
protections for gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) refugees, and
are offering support to LGBT refugees arriving in Germany:CSD-Dresden  (Christopher Street Day Organization Dresden Saxony Germany)The CSD-Dresden organize not only the Christopher Street Parade, they  help LGBT refugees in Saxony currently for their accommodation.
LSVD (Lesbian and Gay Association Germany)
Schwulenberatungszentrum
Berlin (Gay
Advisory Center Berlin)
Rainbow Refugees KarlsruhePrefaceWhat has happened up to now with LGBT refugees arriving in Germany? This is where my sympathy ends!I would like to make an initial remark that I do not intend to condemn our government as discriminatory here. I am of the opinion that there are a large number of issues that can’t be dealt with currently due to the large number of refugees involved. We lack personnel, often resulting in chaotic situations.Every refugee, no matter whether they are heterosexual, gay, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, married, a parent, or single, is currently being distributed across Germany to refugee reception centers where they are housed. All incoming refugees have to wait in these centers until the state has accepted their registration. Due to the high number of incoming refugees at the present, this can often take months. Making a decision on an asylum application can also take many additional months.All refugees fleeing due to war and persecution receive a residency permit.Refugee reception centers are repurposed dormitories, tent cities outdoors, or existing buildings (repurposed gymnasiums or barracks).All refugees, including LGBT refugees, are housed in these facilities. There is no private sphere: up to 10 people stay in narrow rooms filled with bunk beds. Hundreds of refugees have to live in gymnasiums, where they spend the night without walls to separate or protect them.Handicapped refugees, refugee women traveling alone, and refugee mothers with children are granted special protections in our country. They are housed in separate hotels or in facilities that provide additional protection and supervision.LGBT refugees are not recognized as deserving of special protection. We often hear that gay, lesbian, and bisexual refugees feel they have to hide their sexuality. Since this is one of the reasons they become refugees in the first place, we at the Rainbow Refugees organization feel this is a major problem.  LGBT refugees often live together in refugee housing facilities with exactly the people they are attempting to flee. These are their countrymen, who might despise LGBT people and even become violent against LGBT refugees.This is where my sympathy ends!It can’t be true that LGBT refugees flee to our country, only to spend at least six months – usually longer than a year – in a reception center where they might be spit on, beaten, hit with stones, and ostracized by their countrymen. I cannot accept this situation in our country. If our government won’t take up this topic, then I at least will work alongside the Schwulenberatungszentrum Berlin, the LSVD, and the CSD in Dresden to help the people who need it most.CSD Dresden is currently providing help and counseling to 30 LGBT refugees. Another 4 LGBT refugees will be added to this group shortly. The Schwulenberatung Berlin is currently providing help and counseling to 70 refugees. But there are still many more people we won’t be able to help without your support.With your support and your engagement, we will get LGBT refugees out of refugee reception centers and provide them safe housing.Facts1. LGBT refugees 
According
to surveys, at least one percent of all people are lesbian, gay, bisexual, or
transgender. Estimates can even reach as high as five to ten percent. Of the
1,000,000 refugees coming to Germany within 2015, this means that at least
10,000 individuals belong to this group. Due to the extremely severe level of
life-threatening danger LGBT refugees face in radicalized ISIS-held areas and
in Iran, the actual number of individuals seeking protection is likely higher.
2. What are they fleeing from?

In war-torn
areas occupied by IS, gays, lesbians, bisexuals, and transgender individuals
are exposed to the death penalty through stoning or summary execution. The fear
of persecution and death, sometimes at the hands of a person’s own family, is
so acute that the only path remaining to them is to escape. They are often
fleeing persecution, war, discrimination, or a society that doesn’t accept the
LGBT “lifestyle.”
3. Where do LGBT refugees come from?

Some
LGBT refugees come from war-torn areas such as Syria, Libya, Afghanistan,
Pakistan, and Ukraine. But some come from other areas in which those with LGBT
sexual orientations and gender expressions are punished, such as Russia.
4. Why are they fleeing to Germany? 
Germany is a liberal country. Our society accepts and tolerates LGBT people. We
celebrate Christopher Street Day in Germany every year in cities across the
country, a festival even visited by families with children. Many of our
country’s most beloved comedians, TV personalities, and stars are gay, lesbian,
bisexual, or transgender, and live in a very open manner. Not even politicians
need to hide their identities today.
5. 
How do LGBT refugees reach our
country?
LGBT
refugees usually come to the EU after a dangerous journey across the
Mediterranean Ocean. They make their continued journey to Germany on foot. All
they possess is their clothing, documents and identification, and a cell phone.
6. Current status of LGBT refugee relief

After
we’ve removed LGBT refugees from reception centers, they will be housed
initially with volunteer helpers and private supporters. These accommodations
are, however, very limited and only available for a few days.
This
is not a long-term solution, and will not be sufficient to house all LGBT
refugees currently arriving in Germany, nor those who will arrive in the future
safely outside of refugee reception centers. Access to authorities and language
and integration courses are often provided on a volunteer basis, and are not
sufficient. With your support, we will expand our program together.
In
Berlin, LGBT refugees have the opportunity to spend time in the daytime
facility in the Schwulenberatungszentrum during the day. In the
evenings, however, they have to return to the refugee reception centers.

7. What do we accomplish with your support?

Currently, all support we receive is on an volunteer basis. This is not enough.



Many volunteers can´t work for weeks on end without pay, since they need to hold careers to support themselves. We are also providing housing on a volunteer basis, typically for one to two weeks. Unfortunately, this is not sufficient to be able to offer LGBT refugees on a long-term and secure housing solution.
Your support will be used to target the following areas:
Contact
points
We
are currently coordinating contact points nationwide for LGBT refugees.
Employees in refugee reception centers can reach us directly through these.
Secure
housing and protection from anti-LGBT refugees
To
get LGBT refugees out of refugee reception centers, we have to rent apartments
as an alternative solution, paying heating costs and providing some
furnishings. Our financial means to do so, however, are severely limited at the
moment.
Psychological
counseling
LGBT
refugees sometimes come to us having suffered severe trauma. With your support,
we will be able to pay for urgently needed psychological support. The only way
for them to work through what they have experienced is with professional
psychological counseling.
Interpreters
& access to authorities

LGBT
refugees often speak poor English or can only understand their native
languages. We will hire interpreters in order to allow them to visit
authorities as needed.
Simply
enjoying a nice day

With
your help, I would love to give someone a smile. A smile after a nice, normal
day.
To
be honest, I would like to make it possible for the boys and girls who come to
us having suffered so much to simply have a nice day. A day at the zoo or the
movies, in the hopes that this will help them change their thinking and not
feel so alone.

Language
and integration courses

State-run
language and integration courses are overcrowded, and refugees can wait months
for a slot. With your support, we can speed up integration and attempt to
organize some language and integration courses in collaboration with the Schwulenberatungszentrum
Berlin and CSD Dresden.

LGBT
refugee house

My,
and our, greatest wish would be to use your support to rent a home for multiple
LGBT refugees in the long term, placing some pressure on the German government.
This would force it to act, finally, to recognize LGBT refugees as a group
deserving of special protection.
8. What drives us to do what we do
Every
LGBT person has been ostracized at some point in their lives, and may have even
been the victim of a violent act. Often just for being who we are. It’s not
exactly a good feeling.
->
Imagine you lived in a country where you were persecuted, publicly humiliated, and
stoned and murdered because of who you are as a person. It shouldn’t be that
rainbow refugees come to us in the hopes that they will find protection and
freedom in a liberal country like Germany, only to have to experience exactly
the same things in the refugee reception center that they did in their
homelands. This shouldn’t happen to any LGBT refugee who comes into our
country!
We
can all feel sympathy with LGBT refugees. If we put ourselves in their
position, we’d be thankful to be received and supported by others like us. We
would also appreciate these supporters helping us with issues of integration
and access to authorities.
LGBT
refugees come to Germany with nothing. They turn their backs on their old
lives. They come to us because they want to be free. Here, they can be who they
are.
Why
am I turning to you? Because I hope that we, all LGBT individuals in the world,
can join to achieve something together and to make a statement.
Every
contribution is important. Every dollar helps.
If
you are able to spread our message, this would also be a major contribution,
allowing us to bring more attention to this topic. 

9. Why dollars? 

Indiegogo
doesn’t support credit card payments in euros. This is why we have decided to fund
our campaign using dollars.Thank you :)

story:
Short Summary

We are an independent group of people, aged between 26-35, who feel very strongly about the lack of accountability and clean governance in Malta. Crime and corruption, rather than condemned, have pretty much been promoted on the island, specifically in the last few months, and we cannot just sit and read the news in anger. Moaning and name-calling behind a screen isn't going to work; things need to get done and we hope that by getting started we would be empowering people to do the same and most importantly sending a clear message and hope for a clean government. 

We have understood that protests in Malta, more often than not, tend to go unnoticed and disregarded by both the public and those on top. However, we are certain that by organising art installations, setting up education billboards and other creative projects, these would have a much more positive effect, than the ordinary traditional street-walking protests. More importantly the pride one takes into actively contributing towards such a project, whether it is physically or financially, is overwhelming- the feeling that you are standing up for the better of your own country! So, we want to show people, who share the same anger as us, that taking part and/or contributing to such projects is extremely rewarding, and people shouldn't feel afraid.
story_txt:
Short Summary
We are an independent group of people, aged between 26-35, who feel very strongly about the lack of accountability and clean governance in Malta. Crime and corruption, rather than condemned, have pretty much been promoted on the island, specifically in the last few months, and we cannot just sit and read the news in anger. Moaning and name-calling behind a screen isn't going to work; things need to get done and we hope that by getting started we would be empowering people to do the same and most importantly sending a clear message and hope for a clean government. 
We have understood that protests in Malta, more often than not, tend to go unnoticed and disregarded by both the public and those on top. However, we are certain that by organising art installations, setting up education billboards and other creative projects, these would have a much more positive effect, than the ordinary traditional street-walking protests. More importantly the pride one takes into actively contributing towards such a project, whether it is physically or financially, is overwhelming- the feeling that you are standing up for the better of your own country! So, we want to show people, who share the same anger as us, that taking part and/or contributing to such projects is extremely rewarding, and people shouldn't feel afraid.

story:
ABOUT OUR GARDEN HAITI

Our Garden Haiti (OGH) was selected in 2014 and 2015 as a Clinton Global Initiative Commitment to Action that promotes economic empowerment with a family-based approach. The objective is to provide a free summer camp for children living in poverty in the community of Pont Salomon in Les Cayes. The camp will primarily be for former street children and girls living in the rural areas of Les Cayes who are at risk of becoming child domestic workers, known as Rèstavèk. By running a free summer camp for approximately 25 children, OGH will provide various trainings on sustainable agriculture techniques, while collaborating with participating households in Pont Salomon to emphasize the importance of entrepreneurship, financial literacy, and self-sufficiency along with creative workshops for the children. For most of these kids it will be the first time they will have such experience. Through this summer camp they will gain skills that will allow them to replicate what they've learned in their immediate community. 


    

ABOUT OUR PROJECT

In partnership with Little Footprints Big Steps (LFBS), a local NGO located in Les Cayes providing educational, psychological, and medical support to former street children, we will provide the participants and their families with a community hub where they will come to share ideas and continue to address their issues together. With the involvement of the Botanical Garden of Les Cayes, the only botanical garden in the country involved in helping the state to conserve Haitian biodiversity and develop environmental program to educate the population, their expert staff will lead the workshops and training activities for participants while Moreen will engage the children in different eco-friendly activities such as separating trash for compost, preparing seeds for sale in the local market with their parents. In partnership with Impact Ayiti, a Haitian youth-led group who trains disadvantage youth on personal finance and small business design, Moreen will lead workshops for women and girls on the importance of personal finance and how to maximize their earnings.


      


WHAT WE NEED + WHAT YOU GET

Below are the expenses your generosity will help to cover:


     

ABOUT OUR FOUNDER

Moreen Tonny was born and raised in Haiti and recently graduated from Mount Holyoke College in South Hadley, MA. with a bachelors degree in International Relations and a minor in Development Studies. Growing up in Haiti, she witnessed the abuse of countless child domestic workers and street children in her own town. When Moreen was younger she also organized week-long summer gatherings at her house for less fortunate kids in her neighborhood to learn and play. Moreen's mother, as a child, experienced many of what these children go through everyday. However she was lucky enough to receive an education and learn multiple trades. Her struggles growing up are what inspired Moreen to create this camp. With the realization that it could have been her story, Moreen is fully committed to provide every child in need that she can reach with an opportunity to acquire the necessary skills to live a free, happy and healthy life - especially young girls.  



ABOUT OUR IMPACT

According to UNICEF more than 250,000 children aged between 5 and 14 years are child domestic workers in Haiti. Since the 2010 earthquake, the number has increased because, according to United Nations Children’s Fund, nearly 380,000 children became orphans. The International Initiative to End Child Labor reported that 10% of children in domesticity are 10 years old or under. Due to the lack of documentation and access to the most isolated communities in rural Haiti, it is not possible to know the exact number of child domestic workers in the country.

Our Garden Haiti’s model is innovative in many aspects. The teaching method will take into account the children’s lifestyle as well as their environment i.e. customs, and zone patterns such as the type of products/crops their community relies on and consume all year long. The camp will also have experiential-based field learning. Experienced agronomists will work with the children during field visits to the Botanical Gardens of Les Cayes. They will receive hands on training by agricultural experts on soil preservation and resilient gardening techniques.


ABOUT OUR CHALLENGES

Attempting to change a practice that is embedded in a nation’s social and cultural structure is a tremendous task. However in every society there is a threshold between what is considers a cultural tradition and human right violation. OGH is adopting a right-based approach to train children to develop life skills. This approach consists not only of applying universal norm of human rights but helps satisfy needs and restore human dignity where they could otherwise be overlooked.

In Haiti, it is very common for a better off relative or family friend to offer to provide for a child born into a poor rural family. This is one of the many socio-cultural traditions of the Haitian people. In a happy case the children who are cared for are sent to school like all other kids in the households, they sleep in a clean room and are fed properly. On the other hand when a parent living in extreme poverty gives a child away in quest for a better life the story does not always ends on such a positive note. Therefore one of the challenges that OGH may face with the summer camp is resistance from certain parents who still believe that sending their child away to become a child domestic worker is a safe way to live a better life instead of keeping them. To overcome this challenge, we will conduct weekly meeting with parents to raise awareness of the impact of such practice on their children's lives while being cautious of their reality. 


ABOUT OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

With only $5 you can provide a lovely child in need with an enriching summer. Please how these children that they matter by donating and sharing this campaign with your friends and family. We also accept in-kind donations, please contact us directly. Thank you!

story:
Marissa Alexander's current fundraising campaign can be found HERE!

January 28, 2015 UPDATE: 

Marissa Alexander Released from Prison;

Supporters Celebrate, Demand FULL FREEDOM!

Supporters of Marissa Alexander in Jacksonville, across the US, and all around the world are overjoyed that she has been released from jail after serving 3 years behind bars for defending her life.  In 2010, Marissa Alexander, a black mother of three from Jacksonville, Florida, was forced to defend her life from a life-threatening attack by her estranged husband by firing a single warning shot that caused no injuries.  State Prosecutor Angela Corey prosecuted Marissa, pursuing a 60 year mandatory minimum sentence.  On November 24, 2014, Marissa accepted a plea deal that included time served of nearly 3 years in prison, 65 additional days in the Duval County jail, and 2 years of probation while under home detention.  January 27, 2015 marked the end of her time behind bars.

We are thrilled that Marissa will finally be reunited with her children, her family, and her community. Today’s hearing revealed that Marissa intends to attend school to become a paralegal and she is a wonderful mother to her children who urgently need her.  Amazingly, the State continued their campaign of punishment by trying to add two more years of probation on top of the two years of house detention included in the plea. Fortunately, they failed. Marissa and her family will need time to begin recovering from this arduous and traumatic experience. It’s been a long and painful journey and, though her release from jail is definitely a win -- no 60 years -- the journey of seeking ultimate freedom is not over.  Marissa will be forced to be on strict home detention while being under surveillance for two years.  This is by no means freedom in the sense we feel she deserves.  Our next agenda is to seek full restoration for Marissa and her family, including the expunging of her so-called criminal record, and a systemic transformation that prevents black women and all survivors of domestic violence from experiencing the hostile and brutal treatment from policing, prosecution, and prison systems that Marissa has endured. We will push for improved legislation and monitoring of systems that penalize victims of domestic violence who choose to save their lives by force. This is by no means a conclusion.  FMN's full press release is here, and we also recommend this reflection by Mariame Kaba, member of Chicago Alliance to Free Marissa Alexander.

We are filled with gratitude for the hundreds of people who have donated and organized fundraisers all around the world.  We want to be very clear: The reason Marissa is finally out of prison for good is directly because of your political and financial support.  Your donations were CRUCIAL in supporting her pro bono legal team to offer exceptional legal advocacy and your activism ensured that her case stayed in the public eye, which pressured Florida's politicians to pay attention.  Every one of us has a hand in this victory!  Thank you, thank you, thank you.

We're going to take a short break, but we'll be back with more specific thank you's and shout outs soon (there are so many!).  In the meantime, feel free to continue to donate to the CURRENT FUND and help Marissa Alexander cover the very expensive process of rebuilding her life.

Towards freedom, 

Free Marissa Now Mobilization Campaign

Find us on facebook, twitter, tumblr, & e-mail listserv

---

Marissa Alexander is an African American mother of three and survivor of domestic violence from Jacksonville, FL.  In 2010, she fired a warning shot upwards into a wall to defend herself from a life-threatening beating from her estranged husband. Despite the fact that Marissa caused no injuries and has no previous criminal record, and despite the fact that Florida’s self-defense law includes the right to “Stand Your Ground,” she was subsequently arrested, prosecuted, and sentenced to 20 years in prison.  She won an appeal, but was then re-prosecuted and threatened with a 60 year sentence.  She accepted a plea deal in November 2014 that included almost 3 years of time served in prison, 65 additional days in Duval County Jail, and 2 years of house detention while wearing and paying for an ankle surveillance monitor.  On January 27, 2015, Marissa was finally released from jail and reunited with her family.  Free Marissa Now continues to demand her full freedom.

FULL ACQUITTAL: A Movement Behind The Trial

Free Marissa Now, an alliance of organizers and thousands of people all around the world, have been organizing for Marissa's freedom from prison and intend to keep going until she is free.  Because State Attorney Angela Corey refuses to drop the case against Marissa Alexander, continuing a pattern of unjust targeting and prosecution, our movement turns to supporting Marissa, her family, and her legal team in winning her full freedom.

WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

This fundraiser is accountable to Marissa Alexander and her family.  All proceeds from this fundraiser go to the Marissa Alexander Legal Defense Fund which is administered by Marissa's family on her behalf. You can find the link to this fundraiser on the family's website:http://justiceformarissa.blogspot.com/.

Contact us at freemarissanow@gmail.com if you have questions.

THANK YOU!

Marissa's supporters are the greatest!  Every step of the way, you have shown up and given deep support and love.  Your donation is just one more way that you give life to the movement to free Marissa and highlight the need to support all survivors who have been criminalized while trying to navigate the conditions of violence.  Thank you so much for your donation!

PS:

If you want to send a donation via check, please make the check out to:

Global Alliance, Inc.
For: The Marissa Alexander Legal Defense Fund

Mail to:

Global Alliance, Inc.
P.O. Box 290956
Columbia, SC 29229

But please e-mail a note to us at freemarissanow@gmail.com so we can include your donation in our fundraising total!

story:
The Story

On Wednesday July 24th, 2013, Mike Roy, Bailey Lamon, and Dan Beaudoin, were arrested for allegedly painting 2  bricks, then posting a picture of it on facebook.  All 3 were also charged for possession of marijuana.

The police raided the apartment, and confiscated all of Mike and Baileys computers, camera's, and other assorted hardware and are holding them until the case is resolved.

How you can help!

This is a callout to help Mike and Bailey replace the equipment that was taken by the police, so that they can continue their impressive work covering social justice stories in Canada. 


Find the whole story on http://TheIndignants.org/

story:
Why A Wall?

      Students for Justice in Palestine - UIUC focuses on raising awareness on campus about the daily struggles Palestinians face.  While reasoned arguments, statistics, news reports, etc. provide a mountain of support for our cause, they can be confusing, intimidating, and frankly uninteresting to the average student.  The experience of Palestinian daily life is the most powerful tool of them all.  

     That's where the wall comes in.  SJP wants to bring a small taste of life under occupation to students at the U of I. The wall will serve as a stage on which we will set the scene of oppression and invite our audience to immerse themselves in the experience.  Students will be able to see its winding route, sense the imposing eyes of the watchtowers, and stand next to this immense structure and feel the inhumanity of it all.

      In addition to seeing the physical structure, SJP will use the wall as a forum to present those arguments, statistics, and reports I mentioned above.  

    As you can see from this image of a similar wall at UCLA, it is much more than a flat, gray structure.  

Our Needs

     As you can imagine, this venture will be quite expensive.  We are attempting to raise approximately $1,000.  That amount will allow us to build the full wall to fit the display area.  Most of the funds will go directly towards materials: 4x8 boards and supports.  We will also need some funds to go towards pictures and graphics and supplies to put on the face of the wall.  

Our minimum is $500.  Without the full amount, we will have to scale down the size, leaving empty space in places, but still covering the basic plan.  The design is segmental, so we can tailor the size specifically to our funds.

Our needs aren't too great, so with a fair number of supporters, we should have no problem reaching our goals!  Every little bit helps, so please consider donating!  (And don't forget to forward this to your friends!)

story:
A trend of systematic dismantling of civil and human rights by various governments, financial institutions, and private groups threatens human welfare.  Existing international courts are inadequate to address these violations of international law.  The Arbitration Court of International Justice (ACIJ) was founded to fill this need, utilizing previously ignored global statutes which allow the creation of a truly independent global court of human rights, with universal jurisdiction and the power to enforce its judgments.

Five years of volunteer efforts by human rights advocates, lawyers, and international judges, and over 3 million dollars in private & personal contributions, have built the necessary legal infrastructure and established the ACIJ's statutory authority under international law. We are ready to move forward - and now you can make the crucial difference.  The ACIJ is not funded by governments or special interest groups, but must be funded by the people, for the people.

The ACIJ is designed to be expandable without limit, by endowment funding. Total global demand of approximately 100,000 cases per year could be handled by 10,000 full-time judges.  The court already has access to more than twice that number of certified international judges.  Funding is now needed for full-time operations/admin staffing, foundation building and judicial salaries to process plaintiffs’ cases. 

The ACIJ can only operate on the grass-roots and institutional funding available to the host NGO, Ignita Veritas University, a tax-exempt non-profit licensed institution,  Grants SHALL NOT imply any influence beyond the stated public purposes of the ACIJ.  All funds shall be used exclusively to uphold the letter and spirit of Human Rights Laws.

The ACIJ is tax-exempt by statutory 501(a) non-profit status, and all donations are tax-deductible under 170(c)(2).

PHASE I FUNDING OBJECTIVES

* Public Rules of Court – Expert work by specialized Judges to complete consolidation of 70 years of international law into the ACIJ Rules of International Judicial Procedure, Rules of Administration of Judicial Evidence (RAJE), and Statute of International Criminal Offenses (SICO), positioning the Court for later public operations

* Judiciary Networking – Multimedia content development, educational video production, international travel and accommodations, and networking events, to educate and recruit Judiciary professionals to support and further populate the Court

* Public Awareness – Multimedia content development, informational video production, and social media campaigns, to raise public awareness, attract, establish and mobilize a global grass-roots base of support for the Court

* Full-Time Management Staff – Establish sustainable operations for core management staff to train and coordinate worldwide efforts of volunteers

PHASE II OBJECTIVES

* Judges’ Manual for Enforcement of Human Rights – Expert work by an accredited International Judge assisted by an association of Judges, to complete an authoritative handbook for effective application of human rights laws, for use by Judges, human rights lawyers and advocates, and even by plaintiff-victims worldwide

* Recruit Investigators & Enforcers – Recruiting, basic training and accreditation of Instruction Judges for investigations, and Compliance Judges for enforcement of judgments

* Secure Communications Infrastructure – Establish and deploy systems for secure and encrypted mobile and international communications, for protection of Judiciary operations, officers of the Court, witnesses and plaintiff-victims

* Full-Time Judiciary Administration Staff – Establish sustainable operations for expanded staff to manage worldwide activities of investigating Instruction Judges, enforcement Compliance Judges, and adjudicating Presiding Judges of the Court

PHASE III OBJECTIVES

* Legal Research & Development – Specialized academic and legal research on worldwide precedents, plaintiff and defense arguments, for common types of cases expected to be adjudicated by the Court, as a proprietary body of in-house reference works to accelerate effective processing of cases

* Retaining Outsourced Law Firms – Arranging for long-term, routine and on-call outsourced support from choice law firms specializing in defending human rights, to supplement the in-house resources of the Court and its Judges

* Full-Time Presiding Judges & Clerks – Establish sustainable operations for a core team of Presiding Judges, each accompanied by assigned support staff, to maintain exclusive full-time work for Judiciary functions of the Court

* Outreach to Victim Advocacy Groups – Establishing cooperation with advocacy groups specializing in civil rights, human rights and international law, who are in a position to refer victims and cases to the Court with substance and evidence.

Further details may be found at this link:

http://www.iv-university.org/international-justice-court/
story_txt:
A trend of systematic dismantling of civil and human rights by various governments, financial institutions, and private groups threatens human welfare.  Existing international courts are inadequate to address these violations of international law.  The Arbitration Court of International Justice (ACIJ) was founded to fill this need, utilizing previously ignored global statutes which allow the creation of a truly independent global court of human rights, with universal jurisdiction and the power to enforce its judgments.Five years of volunteer efforts by human rights advocates, lawyers, and international judges, and over 3 million dollars in private & personal contributions, have built the necessary legal infrastructure and established the ACIJ's statutory authority under international law. We are ready to move forward - and now you can make the crucial difference.  The ACIJ is not funded by governments or special interest groups, but must be funded by the people, for the people.

The ACIJ is designed to be expandable without limit, by endowment funding. Total global demand of approximately 100,000 cases per year could be handled by 10,000 full-time judges.  The court already has access to more than twice that number of certified international judges.  Funding is now needed for full-time operations/admin staffing, foundation building and judicial salaries to process plaintiffs’ cases.  


The ACIJ can only operate on the grass-roots and institutional funding available to the host NGO, Ignita Veritas University, a tax-exempt non-profit licensed institution,  Grants SHALL NOT imply any influence beyond the stated public purposes of the ACIJ.  All funds shall be used exclusively to uphold the letter and spirit of Human Rights Laws. 
The ACIJ is tax-exempt by statutory 501(a) non-profit status, and      all donations are tax-deductible under 170(c)(2).
PHASE I FUNDING OBJECTIVES
* Public Rules of Court – Expert work by specialized Judges to complete consolidation of 70 years of international law into the ACIJ Rules of International Judicial Procedure, Rules of Administration of Judicial Evidence (RAJE), and Statute of International Criminal Offenses (SICO), positioning the Court for later public operations
* Judiciary Networking – Multimedia content development, educational video production, international travel and accommodations, and networking events, to educate and recruit Judiciary professionals to support and further populate the Court
* Public Awareness – Multimedia content development, informational video production, and social media campaigns, to raise public awareness, attract, establish and mobilize a global grass-roots base of support for the Court
* Full-Time Management Staff – Establish sustainable operations for core management staff to train and coordinate worldwide efforts of volunteers
PHASE II OBJECTIVES
* Judges’ Manual for Enforcement of Human Rights – Expert work by an accredited International Judge assisted by an association of Judges, to complete an authoritative handbook for effective application of human rights laws, for use by Judges, human rights lawyers and advocates, and even by plaintiff-victims worldwide
* Recruit Investigators & Enforcers – Recruiting, basic training and accreditation of Instruction Judges for investigations, and Compliance Judges for enforcement of judgments
* Secure Communications Infrastructure – Establish and deploy systems for secure and encrypted mobile and international communications, for protection of Judiciary operations, officers of the Court, witnesses and plaintiff-victims
* Full-Time Judiciary Administration Staff – Establish sustainable operations for expanded staff to manage worldwide activities of investigating Instruction Judges, enforcement Compliance Judges, and adjudicating Presiding Judges of the Court
PHASE III OBJECTIVES
* Legal Research & Development – Specialized academic and legal research on worldwide precedents, plaintiff and defense arguments, for common types of cases expected to be adjudicated by the Court, as a proprietary body of in-house reference works to accelerate effective processing of cases
* Retaining Outsourced Law Firms – Arranging for long-term, routine and on-call outsourced support from choice law firms specializing in defending human rights, to supplement the in-house resources of the Court and its Judges
* Full-Time Presiding Judges & Clerks – Establish sustainable operations for a core team of Presiding Judges, each accompanied by assigned support staff, to maintain exclusive full-time work for Judiciary functions of the Court
* Outreach to Victim Advocacy Groups – Establishing cooperation with advocacy groups specializing in civil rights, human rights and international law, who are in a position to refer victims and cases to the Court with substance and evidence.
Further details may be found at this link:
http://www.iv-university.org/international-justice-court/

story:
From Tiananmen to Ferguson: A Movement of the Self

Dear friends,

Like many of you,

Michael Brown woke me up.

Eric Garner woke me up.

These and many other brutal acts of violence -- from Oakland to Oklahoma to South Carolina to Baltimore -- are a wake up call to the sickness of racial and social injustice and oppression that continues to plague our communities day in and day out.

Certainly, the pain and suffering of injustice and inequity are as old as history itself. As a Chinese American, I’ve endured my fair share of ridicule and alienation when I came to this country at ten years old. I also don’t have to look very far in my own family history to find tragedies of political turmoil, where my grandfather was repeatedly arrested by the Communist government, and where my parents endured unspeakable hardships during the Cultural Revolution.

In June 1989, when I was living in China with my family, we watched as students, after weeks of hunger strikes, faced an army of tanks in Tiananmen Square. Six months later, my family immigrated to America.

We were worried about the direction that China was headed. We were afraid of a government that would use its military to turn against its own people, people who were unarmed and engaged in peaceful protest.

25 years after Tiananmen, here in America, the images of Ferguson are eerily familiar.

Like thousands of others, like those at Occupy Wall Street, at the Umbrella Revolution, at the Black Lives Matter protests throughout the country, I was shaken by the images of brutality and heard the cries of injustice.

I feel that it is my duty to join the movement.

I also know that marches and protests by themselves won’t change the deep-seated beliefs and perceptions that are ingrained in us, passed on from generation to generation. They continue to poison the personal, social, and economic well-being of millions of lives. They breed fear, anger, frustration, resentment, guilt, shame, and helplessness in so many of us.

If we wish to make a lasting impact, we first need to learn to face these traumas in ourselves. We must train to work with our own pains, judgments, and biases and transform them into skillful views and actions that can heal these traumas with courage, compassion, and forgiveness, without causing further violence or harm.

I know this movement of compassion begins with me.

This is why I’m joining a dozen other leaders from around the country to participate in the Institute for Compassionate Leadership. The faculty of this six-month program is made up of seasoned meditation teachers, activists, and management professionals. Currently, every week, we study and practice various foundational self awareness techniques, such as meditation and mindful communication. These practices are subtly and profoundly life-changing. They help me stay present and grounded, which in turn allow me to expand my capacity for connection with and compassion for others. 

We also study community organizing strategies, along with tools for effective organizational management and leadership. These trainings take the personal mindful practices into organizational and societal spaces. In fact, I am actively applying what I’m learning in my current professional role as the Operations Director for ioby, a national nonprofit that provides crowdfunding and community organizing services for neighborhood-based civic projects.

Through the Institute of Compassionate Leadership and its supporters, I’ve already received a generous $4,000 scholarship, That’s more than half of the program fee. Personally, I am able to contribute another $2,000. This leaves $1,500 to cover the remaining cost of the program.

And it would mean a lot to have your support. 

To be honest, asking for your help is difficult for me. It makes me feel vulnerable, as a part of me feels that I should be able to do this all by myself. But I also know the work I’m doing is greater than just me. This is my work, but it’s also work that affects all of us. 

Fear and anger can spread. So can courage, understanding, and compassion. 

By starting with me -- by practicing being more present, grounded, open, understanding, and compassionate during every moment, with every interaction -- I am cultivating my capacity to connect with others to begin the work of reconciliation, healing, and transformation towards common ground and shared purpose. Only from there can we create effective and lasting strategies and solutions that lead to long-term systemic changes.

Your support, whatever the amount, and your help to spread the word and share this with others you know, would mean a lot to me. I deeply believe that in the face of pain and violence, compassion is the only way to achieve meaningful and lasting change. Your support strengthens my courage and resolve to dedicate my life and this practice towards the work of social justice.

Thank you for taking the time to read this. I’m truly grateful for your support.

With peace, kindness, and gratitude,

W. Kerry Huang
